questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic for a routine check-up. The mother mentions that the child can draw a circle and has recently built a tower with nine cubes. What is the expected developmental age of this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3 years

 

  • At the age of 3 years, a child typically achieves several developmental milestones, including drawing a circle and building a tower of nine cubes.
  • These milestones indicate fine motor skill development appropriate for a 3-year-old.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 year: At 1 year of age, children typically develop a mature pincer grasp and can stand without support. They are not yet capable of drawing shapes or building complex structures like a tower of seven cubes.

 

Option B. 2 years: At 2 years of age, children can build a tower of six blocks, make vertical and circular strokes, and undress themselves. They do not yet have the fine motor skills to build a tower of nine blocks or draw a circle.

 

Option C. 2 ½ years: While some fine motor skills continue to develop at 2 ½ years, children of this age generally do not yet have the ability to consistently draw circles or build a tower of nine cubes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • By the age of 3 years, children typically can build a tower of nine blocks and draw a circle, indicating significant development in fine motor skills.

questions.text:
Match the following light measurement units with their correct descriptions:

 

Column A

 

  1. Candela
  2. Lumen
  3. Lux
  4. Lambert

 

Column B

 

  1. Flow of light
  2. Amount of light reaching surface
  3. Amount of light re-emitted by surface
  4. Luminous intensity
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4-c

 

1. Candela - (d) Luminous intensity: Candela measures the brightness of a light source.

 

2. Lumen - (a) Flow of light: Lumen measures the luminous flux, which is the flow of light.

 

3. Lux - (b) Amount of light reaching surface: Lux measures the illuminance, indicating how much light reaches a surface.

 

4. Lambert - (c) Amount of light re-emitted by surface: Lambert measures the luminance, which is the amount of light re-emitted by a surface.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide is decreased in patients with:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Emphysema

 

  • Emphysema leads to reduced diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) due to destruction of alveolar walls, decreasing the surface area for gas exchange.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar haemorrhage: Initially might increase DLCO due to blood's affinity for carbon monoxide.

 

Option B. Congestive heart failure: May decrease DLCO due to thickening of the alveolar-capillary membrane, but more typically associated with symptoms like edema.

 

Option C. Asthma: Usually shows normal or increased DLCO unless there is an alveolar complication.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

  • DLCO and A-a gradient is used to assess the diffusion across the alveolar-capillary membrane.
  • DLCO measures time taken from diffusion of CO from alveolus to the blood.

choices.text: Mallampati classification
Thyromental distance
Upper lip bite test
Sternomental distance

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of obesity and obstructive sleep apnea is scheduled for elective surgery. During the preoperative assessment, the anesthesiologist evaluates the patient's airway to predict the potential difficulty of intubation. Which of the following test is considered the most predictive for a difficult intubation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper lip bite test

 

  • The Upper lip bite test involves the patient biting the upper lip with the lower incisors.
  • It is considered more predictive of difficult intubation because it combines flexibility of the temporomandibular joint and the range of motion of the cervical spine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mallampati classification: Mallampati classification relates the visibility of structures in the oral cavity with the tongue protruding; a higher class can indicate a potentially difficult airway.

 

Option B. Thyromental distance: It measures the distance from the thyroid notch to the mentum; a shorter distance can suggest a difficult airway due to anatomical constraints.

 

Option D. Sternomental distance: It measures the distance from the sternum to the mentum with the head extended; a smaller distance can be associated with a difficult airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Upper lip bite test is a reliable and simple bedside test to predict difficult intubation; it evaluates both the mandibular space and the patient's ability to move the jaw and neck, which are crucial for intubation.

choices.text: His total calorie intake is 3000 kcal
The proportion of proteins, fats, and carbohydrates is correct and in accordance with a balanced diet
He has a negative nitrogen balance
30% of his total energy intake is derived from fat

questions.text: A 35-year-old man weighing 68 kg visits a nutritionist for advice on his diet. His current diet consists of 325 grams of carbohydrates, 65 grams of protein, and 35 grams of fat daily. He wants to know if his diet is balanced. Which of the following statements is most applicable?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The proportion of proteins, fats, and carbohydrates is correct and in accordance with a balanced diet

 

  • According to a balanced diet, proteins should constitute 10-15% of the total daily energy intake, fats should constitute 15-30%, and carbohydrates should make up the remaining energy.
  • The man's diet contains 325 grams of carbohydrate, 65 grams of protein, and 35 grams of fat, which provides the following energy breakdown:

 

Carbohydrates: 4 kcal/g × 325 g = 1300 kcal (68% of total energy)

 

Proteins: 4.2 kcal/g × 65 g = 275 kcal (15% of total energy)

 

Fats: 9 kcal/g × 35 g = 315 kcal (17% of total energy)

 

Total energy intake: 1300 kcal + 275 kcal + 315 kcal = 1890 kcal

 

The proportions of proteins, fats, and carbohydrates in his diet align with the recommendations for a balanced diet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. His total calorie intake is 3000 kcal: This is incorrect. The total calorie intake calculated from the given macronutrients is 1890 kcal.

 

Option C. He has a negative nitrogen balance: This is incorrect. The given information does not provide enough details to determine his nitrogen balance.

 

Option D. 30% of his total energy intake is derived from fat: This is incorrect. Only 17% of his total energy intake is derived from fat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A balanced diet consists of proteins making up 10-15% of total energy intake, fats 15-30%, and carbohydrates the remaining energy.
  • The proportions in the given diet align with these recommendations, confirming it as a balanced diet.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a palpable lump in her left breast. She reports no pain or nipple discharge. A mammogram reveals an area of calcifications, and a biopsy confirms ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Based on the histological subtype, which type of DCIS is most likely to result in a palpable abnormality in the breast?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Comedo DCIS

 

  • Comedo DCIS is a subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by high-grade nuclei and central necrosis within the ducts.
  • This type often results in extensive ductal involvement, leading to the formation of a palpable mass or lump in the breast.
  • The central necrosis and high cellular turnover contribute to the firmness and detectability of the lesion.
  •  Comedo DCIS is also associated with calcifications, which can be detected on mammography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apocrine DCIS: Apocrine DCIS is a less common subtype characterized by cells with abundant granular cytoplasm. It is less likely to form a palpable mass compared to comedo DCIS.

 

Option B. Neuroendocrine DCIS: Neuroendocrine DCIS is another rare subtype that usually does not present as a palpable mass. It tends to be more indolent and may not form significant masses detectable by physical examination.

 

Option C. Well-differentiated DCIS: Well-differentiated DCIS is typically low-grade and slow-growing. It is less likely to form a palpable mass compared to high-grade forms like comedo DCIS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Comedo DCIS is the subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ most likely to present as a palpable abnormality in the breast due to its high-grade features and central necrosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a traumatic spinal cord injury. He is hypotensive, bradycardic, and has warm, dry skin. The physician suspects neurogenic shock. Which of the following findings is NOT typically seen in neurogenic shock?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased cardiac output

 

  • Neurogenic shock is characterized by a loss of sympathetic tone due to disruption of the sympathetic nervous system.
  • This leads to venous and arterial vasodilation, decreased venous return, decreased stroke volume, and decreased cardiac output.
  • The parasympathetic response also causes bradycardia, further reducing cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous and arterial vasodilation: A result of loss of sympathetic tone.

 

Option B. Decreased venous return: Due to vasodilation and pooling of blood in the extremities.

 

Option D. Decreased stroke volume: Due to reduced venous return and cardiac output.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neurogenic shock typically presents with decreased cardiac output, decreased stroke volume, venous and arterial vasodilation, and decreased venous return due to loss of sympathetic tone.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatric clinic with a palpable abdominal mass. An ultrasound of the abdomen reveals a mass with stippled calcifications and displacement of the kidney inferolaterally without distortion of the collecting system. The mass is non-mobile and appears to cross the midline. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neuroblastoma

 

  • Neuroblastoma is an extrarenal tumor that commonly arises from the adrenal glands or paravertebral sympathetic ganglia.
  • It is characterized by stippled calcifications and displacement of the kidney inferolaterally without distortion of the collecting system.
  • Neuroblastomas are also known for their potential to cross the midline and have a higher incidence of intraspinal extension compared to Wilms tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilms tumor: Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, primarily originates intrarenally and is usually confined to the flank. It displaces adjacent structures but does not typically encase vessels. Stippled calcifications are uncommon in Wilms tumor.

 

Option B. Hepatoblastoma: Hepatoblastoma is a rare liver tumor in children and would not typically present with displacement of the kidney or stippled calcifications as described in the question.

 

Option D. Renal cell carcinoma: Renal cell carcinoma is rare in children and is more common in adults. It does not typically present with the described features of stippled calcifications and significant midline crossing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neuroblastoma often presents with a non-mobile abdominal mass with stippled calcifications, arises extrarenally (commonly from adrenal glands), and may cross the midline.
  • It can also cause displacement of the kidney without distortion of the collecting system and has a higher incidence of intraspinal extension compared to Wilms tumor.

choices.text: Pyloric muscle thickness of >1-2 mm or a pyloric length >10-12 mm
Pyloric muscle thickness of >3-4 mm or a pyloric length >15-18 mm
Pyloric muscle thickness of >5-6 mm or a pyloric length >20-22 mm
Pyloric muscle thickness of >7-8 mm or a pyloric length >25-28 mm

questions.text: What are the ultrasound (USG) criteria for diagnosing congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyloric muscle thickness of >3-4 mm or a pyloric length >15-18 mm

 

  • The ultrasound criteria for diagnosing congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis include a pyloric muscle thickness of greater than 3-4 mm and a pyloric length of greater than 15-18 mm.
  • These measurements indicate significant hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, which is diagnostic of the condition in the presence of functional gastric outlet obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyloric muscle thickness of >1-2 mm or a pyloric length >10-12 mm: Incorrect criteria, as these measurements are too low to diagnose hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

 

Option C. Pyloric muscle thickness of >5-6 mm or a pyloric length >20-22 mm: Incorrect criteria, as these measurements are higher than those typically used for diagnosis.

 

Option D. Pyloric muscle thickness of >7-8 mm or a pyloric length >25-28 mm: Incorrect criteria, as these measurements are much higher than those typically used for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ultrasound criteria for congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis include a pyloric muscle thickness of >3-4 mm and a pyloric length of >15-18 mm.

questions.text: The figure below illustrates the mechanism of action of which of the following drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nilotinib

 

  • Nilotinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that specifically targets the BCR-ABL fusion protein found in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
  • It works by binding to the ATP-binding site of the BCR-ABL protein, thereby preventing the phosphorylation of tyrosine residues on substrate proteins.
  • This inhibition blocks the downstream signaling pathways that promote cell proliferation and survival.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methotrexate:   Incorrect. Methotrexate is an antimetabolite and antifolate drug that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, interfering with DNA synthesis, repair, and cellular replication.

 

Option C. Pertuzumab:  Incorrect. Pertuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the HER2 receptor, preventing dimerization and signaling in HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Option D. Cisplatin:   Incorrect. Cisplatin is a platinum-based chemotherapeutic agent that causes DNA cross-linking, leading to apoptosis in rapidly dividing cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tyrosine kinase activated by abl-bcr fusion result in CML. This enzyme can be inhibited by –

 

B: Bosutinib

I: Imatinib

N: Nilotinib

D: Dasatinib

Proteins: Ponatinib

 

Mnemonic – BIND Proteins

questions.text: Which intracellular molecule is primarily responsible for mediating the effects of ANP?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) cGMP 

 

  • cGMP (cyclic Guanosine Monophosphate) is the correct mediator for the actions of Atrial Natriuretic Peptide (ANP).
  • ANP functions by binding to its receptors on vascular smooth muscle and kidney cells, which activates guanylate cyclase.
  • This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of GTP to cGMP.
  • Elevated levels of cGMP lead to smooth muscle relaxation (vasodilation) and increased sodium excretion in the kidneys (natriuresis), which collectively contribute to blood pressure reduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. cAMP (cyclic Adenosine Monophosphate): Incorrect because while cAMP is a critical second messenger in many hormonal signaling pathways, including some that regulate cardiovascular functions, it is not the mediator for ANP’s effects.

 

Option B. Inositol phosphate: Incorrect as Inositol phosphates are involved in cell signaling processes related to cell growth, survival, and insulin signaling rather than the cardiovascular and renal actions mediated by ANP.

 

Option D. DAG (Diacylglycerol): Incorrect because DAG activates protein kinase C in other signaling pathways, such as those triggered by hormones like angiotensin II, but does not participate in ANP signaling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cyclic GMP (cGMP) is the key intracellular mediator for Atrial Natriuretic Peptide, essential in its role to reduce hypertension through vasodilation and promoting natriuresis.
  • Understanding this pathway is crucial for managing and understanding the pharmacological treatment of hypertension.

choices.text: Thermodynamically possible only when gluconeogenesis occurs
Needs protein kinase for its activation
Enzyme is present in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER), glucose 6-phosphate needs to be transported into the SER
Steric inhibition of phosphatase by albumin

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the biochemical pathways involved in glucose metabolism within liver cells. He is particularly focused on understanding why glucose 6-phosphate in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes is not immediately acted upon by glucose 6-phosphatase after its formation. Which of the following options listed below could be the reason?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enzyme is present in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum SER, glucose 6-phosphate needs to be transported into the SER

 

  • Glucose 6-phosphatase is an enzyme located in the membrane of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) in hepatocytes.
  • For glucose 6-phosphate to be hydrolyzed into glucose and inorganic phosphate, it must first be transported into the SER where glucose 6-phosphatase resides.
  • This compartmentalization ensures that glucose 6-phosphate is not prematurely dephosphorylated in the cytoplasm, which is essential for proper regulation of glucose metabolism, especially during processes like gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thermodynamically possible only when gluconeogenesis occurs: This statement is incorrect as the thermodynamics of the reaction do not restrict glucose 6-phosphatase activity to gluconeogenesis. The enzyme can function during both gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis.

 

Option B. Needs protein kinase for its activation: This statement is incorrect because glucose 6-phosphatase does not require activation by protein kinase. Its activity is regulated by the presence and transport of its substrate, glucose 6-phosphate.

 

Option D. Steric inhibition of phosphatase by albumin: This statement is incorrect as there is no evidence that albumin or steric hindrance by albumin affects glucose 6-phosphatase activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glucose 6-phosphate in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes must be transported into the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) to be acted upon by glucose 6-phosphatase, ensuring proper regulation of glucose metabolism.

questions.text: Identity the procedure shown in the image, done for a patient presenting with swelling in the groin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TEP (Totally extraperitoneal)

 

  • The image depicts the TEP (totally extraperitoneal) repair for inguinal hernia. In this procedure, the mesh is placed in the preperitoneal space without entering the abdominal cavity. A polypropylene mesh is placed in this space to reinforce the abdominal wall and prevent hernia recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TAPP: Transabdominal preperitoneal space repair involves placing the mesh in the preperitoneal space, accessed from the abdominal cavity.

 

Option C. IPOM: Intra-abdominal onlay mesh repair places the mesh within the peritoneal cavity on the defect.

 

Option D. TIPP: This option is not commonly used or recognized in standard hernia repair terminology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • TEP repair is a minimally invasive procedure for inguinal hernia where the mesh is placed in the preperitoneal space without entering the abdominal cavity, reducing the risk of complications associated with intra-abdominal procedures.

questions.text: A forensic expert is examining seeds, recovered from a crime scene to determine their toxicological significance. The active ingredient of the seeds shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Semecarpol

 

  • The seeds in the image are from the Semecarpus anacardium plant, commonly known as marking nuts.
  • The active ingredient in these seeds is semecarpol and bhilawanol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Croton: Croton seeds contain croton oil, which is a potent irritant but is not associated with the seeds shown in the image.

 

Option C. Abrin: Abrin is a highly toxic protein found in the seeds of the rosary pea (Abrus precatorius), not the seeds shown in the image.

 

Option D. Ricin: Ricin is a potent toxin found in castor beans (Ricinus communis), not the seeds depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Semecarpol is the active ingredient in Semecarpus anacardium seeds, known as marking nuts.

 

Medico-legal Aspects - 

 

  • It may be used by malingerers to produce conjunctivitis or to support a false charge of assault; lesions produced simulate bruises
  • Accidental poisoning may result from the administration of juice by quacks for treatment of rheumatic pain and worm infestation.
  • Juice may be introduced into the vagina, as a punishment for infidelity.
  • For criminal abortion, juice is applied to the cervical os by means of abortion stick.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida presents at 30 weeks of gestation with abdominal pain for 2 hours. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg. On examination, there is pallor, the uterus corresponds to 36 weeks, and it is tender. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abruption

 

  • The most probable diagnosis is abruption (placental abruption), which involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall. Key features supporting this diagnosis include:
    • Abdominal pain: A common symptom of placental abruption.
    • Hypertension (BP 160/100 mmHg): A risk factor for abruption.
    • Pallor: Suggests possible significant blood loss.
    • Uterine tenderness and a uterus larger than expected for gestational age: Indicating concealed bleeding and possible blood accumulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyhydramnios: This condition involves an excessive amount of amniotic fluid, which can cause uterine enlargement and discomfort. However, it does not typically present with acute pain, hypertension, or uterine tenderness.

 

Option B. Multiple pregnancy: Carrying more than one fetus can cause the uterus to be larger than expected for gestational age. However, it does not explain the acute pain, hypertension, pallor, or uterine tenderness.

 

Option C. Red degeneration of fibroid: This is a painful condition that occurs when a fibroid outgrows its blood supply and degenerates. It can cause acute abdominal pain and uterine tenderness but is less likely to be associated with the uterine size discrepancy and hypertension seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placental abruption should be suspected in a pregnant woman presenting with acute abdominal pain, hypertension, pallor, and uterine tenderness, especially when the uterine size is larger than expected for gestational age.

questions.text: A nephrology resident is planning a research study to assess renal function in patients with suspected chronic kidney disease. The study aims to accurately determine the filtration fraction of the kidneys using substances that are well-characterized in renal physiology. Which combination of substances should be used to measure glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renal plasma flow (RPF) for calculating the filtration fraction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PAH and inulin

 

  • PAH (para-aminohippuric acid) and inulin are the ideal substances for determining renal filtration fraction.
  • Inulin serves as an excellent marker for GFR because it is freely filtered at the glomerulus and neither reabsorbed nor secreted by the renal tubules, allowing for precise measurement of the filtration rate.
  • PAH is used to assess RPF due to its high clearance, as it is both filtered and actively secreted by the renal tubules, providing a comprehensive measure of the plasma effectively passing through the kidneys.
  • Together, these measurements allow for the accurate calculation of the filtration fraction, defined as the ratio of GFR to RPF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urea and diodrast: Incorrect because urea is partially reabsorbed by the renal tubules, which can lead to variable measurements, making it less ideal for accurate GFR assessment. Diodrast is primarily used in imaging studies and does not provide specific measurements necessary for RPF or GFR.

 

Option C. Insulin and mannitol: Incorrect because mannitol can measure extracellular fluid space but is not specifically used for renal filtration fraction calculations. Insulin, often confused with inulin, is not used in renal physiology for GFR measurements.

 

Option D. PAH and phenol red: Incorrect as phenol red is less commonly used in clinical practice for kidney function assessments and does not contribute to the precise calculation of either GFR or RPF like PAH does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inulin and PAH are used to accurately measure GFR and RPF, respectively, essential for calculating the renal filtration fraction, a key indicator of kidney function in patients with chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient reports to the clinic with sudden onset of intense fear, palpitations, trembling, and a sense of impending doom. He recalls having a COVID-19 infection approximately three months ago, which was a stressful experience for him. His current physical examination and all investigations, including cardiac workup, are within normal limits. Based on this clinical scenario, what is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alprazolam

 

  • In the acute setting, where a patient present with a sudden onset of intense fear, palpitations, trembling, and a sense of impending doom (symptoms suggestive of a panic attack), the immediate goal is to alleviate the acute distress.
  • Alprazolam is effective for rapid relief of acute panic symptoms due to its anxiolytic properties. It can quickly reduce the intensity of anxiety and physical symptoms associated with a panic attack.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Propranolol: It can help manage some physical symptoms of anxiety but does not address the core panic symptoms.

 

Option B. Sertraline: It is effective for long-term management of panic disorder but not for immediate symptom relief.

 

Option D. CBT (Cognitive behavioural therapy): It is an effective long-term treatment for panic disorder but not suitable for immediate symptom relief in an acute panic attack.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the acute management of a panic attack, immediate relief of symptoms can be provided by short-term use of benzodiazepines like alprazolam. Long-term management of panic disorder involves CBT and SSRIs.

choices.text: Number of institutional deliveries in comparison to last year
Number of cases of TB/Leprosy detected as compared to last year

questions.text: A public health researcher is conducting a study to evaluate the effectiveness of ASHA in improving community health. The researcher is using various indicators to assess the impact of ASHA's work over the past year. Which of the following is NOT considered an impact indicator for evaluating ASHA's work?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Number of institutional deliveries in comparison to last year

 

  • This is an outcome indicator, not an impact indicator.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indicators for Monitoring and Evaluation of ASHA’s Work

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester comes to the clinic for a routine check-up. Which of the following is NOT a normal physiological change during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased functional residual capacity

 

  • During pregnancy, various physiological changes occur to accommodate the growing fetus.
  • The functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation. In pregnancy, FRC decreases due to the upward displacement of the diaphragm by the enlarging uterus.
  • This displacement reduces the volume of the thoracic cavity, leading to a reduction in lung volumes, including the FRC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased GFR: Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) increases during pregnancy due to increased renal blood flow, which helps to meet the increased metabolic demands and excretory needs.

 

Option C. Increased cardiac output: Cardiac output increases significantly during pregnancy as a result of increased blood volume and heart rate. This supports the increased metabolic demands of both the mother and the fetus.

 

Option D. Increased total protein: Total protein levels typically do not increase during pregnancy. In fact, plasma protein concentrations may decrease due to hemodilution from the increased plasma volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During pregnancy, the functional residual capacity (FRC) decreases due to the upward displacement of the diaphragm by the growing uterus.

choices.text: Cells are p63 and p40 positive
Pathology is peripheral in location

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a long history of smoking presents to the clinic with a chronic non-productive cough that has persisted for 6 months. He also reports weight loss, anorexia, and intermittent chest pain. A chest CT scan reveals a mass lesion, and a biopsy is performed (image provided). Which of the following statements best describes the pathology seen in this patient's biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cells are p63 and p40 positive

 

  • The patient’s clinical presentation of a chronic non-productive cough, weight loss, anorexia, and chest pain, combined with a history of heavy smoking and the presence of a mass lesion on CT, suggests lung cancer.
  • The biopsy features (as seen in the provided image) the pleomorphism of the cells, a "squamous eddy" is seen at the upper left, but some of the cells at the right show little keratinization.
  • Are indicative of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung. Squamous cell carcinoma typically arises in the central bronchi and is strongly associated with smoking. Immunohistochemical staining for p63 and p40 is positive in SCC, confirming the diagnosis.
  •  These markers are highly specific for squamous cell carcinoma and help distinguish it from other types of lung cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. More common in females: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is more commonly found in males, particularly those with a significant history of smoking. It is not more common in females.

 

Option B. Azzopardi effect is seen: The Azzopardi effect, which refers to basophilic staining of vascular walls due to DNA deposition, is characteristic of small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC), not squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Option D. Pathology is peripheral in location: Squamous cell carcinoma typically presents as a centrally located mass, especially in the major bronchi, rather than peripherally. Peripheral location is more commonly associated with adenocarcinoma of the lung.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is often associated with a history of smoking, typically presents as a centrally located mass, and is confirmed by positive immunohistochemical staining for p63 and p40.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man of Mediterranean descent presents with fatigue, pallor, and jaundice. Laboratory findings reveal a hemoglobin level of 8 g/dL, MCV of 60 fL, and reticulocyte count of 5%. His peripheral blood smear shows microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells with target cells. Hemoglobin electrophoresis shows elevated HbA2 and HbF. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the HBB gene. Which of the following complications is most likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemosiderosis

 

  • Patients with beta-thalassemia major or intermedia often require regular blood transfusions, leading to iron overload (hemosiderosis).
  • The elevated HbA2 and HbF levels and the presence of a mutation in the HBB gene are indicative of beta-thalassemia.
  • Hemosiderosis is a common and severe complication due to repeated transfusions and increased intestinal iron absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenic infarction: Splenic infarction is more common in sickle cell disease, not typically in thalassemia.

 

Option C. Aplastic crisis: Aplastic crisis is usually seen in patients with hereditary spherocytosis or sickle cell disease due to parvovirus B19 infection.

 

Option D. Hypercoagulability: Hypercoagulability can occur but is less common than hemosiderosis in thalassemia patients who undergo frequent transfusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Beta-thalassemia patients are at high risk for hemosiderosis due to frequent blood transfusions and increased intestinal iron absorption, requiring regular monitoring and chelation therapy.

questions.text:
Match the following aspects of health service evaluation with their correct definitions:

 

Evaluation aspects:

  1. Relevance
  2. Adequacy
  3. Accessibility
  4. Acceptability
  5. Effectiveness
  6. Efficiency
  7. Impact

 

Definitions

  1. Socially and culturally acceptable
  2. Proportion of population expected to use the service
  3. How well resources are utilized
  4. Overall effect of programme/service on health and development
  5. Appropriateness (need) of a health service
  6. Sufficient attention to pre-determined course of action
  7. Extent of prevention/alleviation of underlying problem
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-e, 2-f, 3-b, 4-a, 5-g, 6-c, 7-d

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Relevance - (e) Appropriateness (need) of a health service
  2. Adequacy - (f) Sufficient attention to pre-determined course of action
  3. Accessibility - (b) Proportion of population expected to use the service
  4. Acceptability - (a) Socially and culturally acceptable
  5. Effectiveness - (g) Extent of prevention/alleviation of underlying problem
  6. Efficiency - (c) How well resources are utilized
  7. Impact - (d) Overall effect of programme/service on health and development

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Evaluation of health services involves multiple aspects including relevance, adequacy, accessibility, acceptability, effectiveness, efficiency, and impact.
  •  Understanding these components helps in assessing and improving health service programs comprehensively.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department complaining of difficulty inserting a tampon and feeling something in her vagina. On examination, a vaginal swelling arising from the anterolateral vaginal wall is observed, as shown in the image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gartner duct cyst

 

  • Gartner duct cysts are remnants of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct and can present as cystic swellings in the anterolateral vaginal wall.
  • These cysts are usually asymptomatic but can cause symptoms like difficulty inserting tampons or a sensation of a mass if they become large.
  • The appearance and location of the swelling in the provided image are consistent with a Gartner duct cyst.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bartholin cyst: These cysts typically occur at the posterior part of the vaginal introitus, near the Bartholin glands, and not along the anterolateral vaginal wall.

 

 

Option C. Uterine prolapse: This condition involves the descent of the uterus into the vaginal canal and often presents with a bulge at the vaginal introitus, but not specifically as an anterolateral vaginal wall swelling.

 

 

Option D. Sarcoma Botryoides: This is a rare type of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma that presents as a grape-like mass protruding from the vaginal or cervical opening in children. It is less likely to be the diagnosis in a 33-year-old woman with the described presentation.

 

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Gartner duct cysts present as cystic swellings in the anterolateral vaginal wall and can cause symptoms such as difficulty inserting tampons or a sensation of a mass.

questions.text: In the Global Hunger Index (GHI) 2021, India scored 27.5. Based on this score, what is the level of hunger in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serious

 

  • The Global Hunger Index (GHI) classification interprets the level of hunger based on scores. A score between 20 and 34.9 indicates a serious level of hunger.
  • India's score of 27.5 falls within this range.

 

GHI Classification and Interpretation:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Global Hunger Index (GHI)

 

  • The Global Hunger Index is a tool designed to comprehensively measure and track hunger at the global, regional, and country levels
  • The International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) calculates GHI scores each year to assess progress, or the lack thereof, in combating hunger
  • To capture the multidimensional nature of hunger, GHI scores are based on the following indicators:

 

 

  • India, Global Hunger Index GHI 2021: Score 27.5, Serious level of hunger (Rank 101st out of the 116 countries)

questions.text: Match the following conditions with their drug of choice:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-D, 2-E, 3-A, 4-C, 5-B

 

1-D, Cobra bite and Neostigmine: Neostigmine is used to treat symptoms of neurotoxic snake bites such as those from a cobra, by restoring proper muscle function affected by the venom.

 

2-E, Panuveitis and Steroids: Steroids are the mainstay treatment for reducing inflammation in conditions like panuveitis, effectively managing the immune response in the eye.

 

3-A, Septic shock and Noradrenaline: Noradrenaline is used to increase blood pressure in septic shock, helping to maintain adequate organ perfusion.

 

4-C, Drug-induced Parkinsonism and Benzhexol: Benzhexol (Trihexyphenidyl) is used to treat Parkinsonian symptoms induced by drugs, particularly those caused by antipsychotic medications.

 

5-B, Akathisia and Propranolol: Propranolol can help manage symptoms of akathisia, which often include severe restlessness, typically caused by antipsychotic drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of high cholesterol is undergoing treatment that involves the uptake of cholesterol-bound receptors into her cells for metabolism. This cellular uptake process relies on a specific protein to form vesicles. Which of the following proteins is responsible for mediating this type of endocytosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clathrin

 

  • Clathrin-mediated endocytosis is the process by which cells absorb molecules such as proteins by engulfing them.
  • This process involves the receptor proteins on the cell surface that specifically bind to the molecules being taken in.
  • Clathrin plays a crucial role by forming a coated pit and eventually a vesicle that helps in transporting these molecules into the cell.
  • The example of the woman with high cholesterol illustrates how cholesterol-bound receptors are internalized in a clathrin-dependent manner to manage her condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vimentin: Incorrect because Vimentin is a type of intermediate filament protein involved in maintaining cell integrity and providing support for cellular structures. It does not play a role in the endocytosis process.

 

Option B. Porine: Incorrect as Porine refers to proteins that form pores in cellular membranes, primarily in bacteria and mitochondria, allowing the passage of molecules. It is not involved in the endocytosis process.

 

Option C. Cytokine: Incorrect because cytokines are signaling molecules that modulate the immune response, inflammation, and cell growth. They do not have a direct role in the mechanism of endocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clathrin is essential for receptor-mediated endocytosis, a process crucial for internalizing molecules like cholesterol into cells.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with chronic hepatitis B infection presents for a follow-up visit. His recent laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following serological markers best indicates active viral replication in hepatitis B infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HBV DNA

 

  • Directly measures the viral genetic material in the blood.
  • Best indicator of active viral replication and infectivity.
  • Used to monitor the effectiveness of treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): Indicates an ongoing hepatitis B infection. Does not specifically indicate active viral replication.

 

Option C. HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen): Indicates active viral replication and higher infectivity. Presence suggests high levels of the virus but not as direct a measure as HBV DNA.

 

Option D. HBcAg (Hepatitis B core antigen): Found within liver cells and not typically measured in serum. Presence implied by detection of anti-HBc antibodies. Not used as a marker for active replication in clinical practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HBV DNA is the best serological marker to indicate active replication in Hepatitis B infection.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with headaches, seizures, and progressive neurological deficits. Imaging studies reveal a mass lesion in the brain, and a biopsy confirms the diagnosis of glioma. Which of the following receptors on the neuronal membrane is most associated with the development of glioma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CD133

 

  • CD133 (also known as prominin-1) is a transmembrane glycoprotein that is used as a marker for cancer stem cells, including glioma stem cells. It plays a crucial role in maintaining the stemness and self-renewal properties of these cells. Glioma stem cells expressing CD133 are believed to contribute to tumor initiation, progression, and recurrence. The presence of CD133 on glioma cells is associated with poor prognosis and resistance to conventional therapies, making it a critical target in glioma research.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD45: CD45 is a common leukocyte antigen found on all nucleated hematopoietic cells and is not specific to glioma or neuronal cells. It is not associated with the development of glioma.

 

Option C. CD33: CD33 is a sialic acid-binding immunoglobulin-like lectin found on myeloid cells. It is primarily associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and is not involved in glioma development.

 

Option D. CD24: CD24 is a cell adhesion molecule that is expressed on various cells, including hematopoietic and neural cells. While it has roles in tumor progression and metastasis in other cancers, it is not specifically associated with the development of glioma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CD133 is the receptor on the neuronal membrane most associated with the development of glioma, playing a significant role in the maintenance and proliferation of glioma stem cells.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman who remarried presents to the gynecology outpatient department with infertility after attempting to conceive for one year. She has a history of dilation and curettage (D&C) for a missed abortion with her first husband. Her menstrual cycles are regular. Pelvic ultrasound shows no abnormalities, and her current husband's semen analysis is normal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laparoscopy with chromopertubation

 

  • Laparoscopy with chromopertubation is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used to evaluate the patency of the fallopian tubes, which can be a critical factor in infertility.
  • Given the patient's history of a D&C for a missed abortion, there is a possibility of intrauterine adhesions (Asherman's syndrome) or tubal factor infertility.
  • Laparoscopy allows for direct visualization of the pelvic organs and can identify and treat conditions such as tubal occlusion, adhesions, or endometriosis that might not be detectable on ultrasound.
  • Chromopertubation involves the injection of dye through the cervix into the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes to assess tubal patency, providing valuable information on whether the tubes are open or blocked.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometrial biopsy: This procedure is typically used to evaluate the endometrial lining for abnormalities such as chronic endometritis or endometrial hyperplasia. It is not the next best step for evaluating infertility when the ultrasound and semen analysis are normal, and there is a history suggestive of possible tubal factor infertility.

 

Option B. Ovulation induction: This treatment is used for women with anovulation or oligo-ovulation. Since the patient has regular menstrual cycles, ovulation induction is not the appropriate next step.

 

Option C. IVF (In Vitro Fertilization): IVF is an advanced fertility treatment that involves fertilizing an egg outside the body and then implanting it into the uterus. While it is a potential option for infertility, it is typically considered after less invasive diagnostic and therapeutic options, such as laparoscopy with chromopertubation, have been explored and addressed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Laparoscopy with chromopertubation is the next best step in managing infertility when initial evaluations are normal but there is a history that suggests possible tubal factor infertility or intrauterine adhesions.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the components of neutrophils, particularly focusing on the primary granules. They are examining the specific substances stored in these granules, which are crucial for the neutrophils' role in the immune response. Which of the following is not present in the primary granules of neutrophils?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lactoferrin

 

  • Primary granules of neutrophils, also known as azurophilic granules, contain several key enzymes and antimicrobial proteins that play crucial roles in the immune response.
  •  These include myeloperoxidase, defensins, and acid hydrolases.
  •  However, lactoferrin is not found in primary granules; it is stored in secondary granules (specific granules) of neutrophils.
  •  Lactoferrin is an iron-binding protein that sequesters iron from bacteria, inhibiting their growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myeloperoxidase: Myeloperoxidase is present in the primary granules of neutrophils and is crucial for producing reactive oxygen species that help in killing pathogens.

 

Option B. Defensin:  Defensins are antimicrobial peptides stored in primary granules that disrupt microbial membranes and contribute to the killing of pathogens.

 

Option C. Acid hydrolases: Acid hydrolases, including various proteases, are enzymes found in primary granules that degrade cellular debris and pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lactoferrin is not present in the primary granules of neutrophils; it is found in the secondary granules.
  •  Primary granules contain myeloperoxidase, defensin, and acid hydrolases, which are crucial for the antimicrobial functions of neutrophils.

questions.text: A woman presents to the STI clinic with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) and is given a yellow kit for herself and a kit for her husband. Which of the following kits will be given to her husband?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gray kit (Kit 1)

 

  • In the management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs), specific treatment kits are designated for different infections.
  • For a woman with PID, the yellow kit (Kit 6) is provided.
  • Her husband should be given the gray kit (Kit 1), which is intended for the treatment of urethral discharge and is appropriate for male partners of women diagnosed with PID, as it covers the most common pathogens responsible for STIs that could lead to PID, such as Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green kit (Kit 2): This kit is used for the treatment of vaginal discharge syndrome in women, which includes trichomoniasis and bacterial vaginosis. It is not appropriate for her husband.

 

Option C. Red kit (Kit 4): This kit is used for the treatment of genital ulcer disease, particularly syphilis and chancroid. It is not relevant to the husband's treatment in this scenario.

 

Option D. Yellow kit (Kit 6): This kit is used for the treatment of pelvic inflammatory disease in women and is not appropriate for her husband.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of pelvic inflammatory disease, the male partner should be treated with the gray kit (Kit 1), which is designed for urethral discharge syndrome in men, covering the common pathogens that could cause STIs leading to PID.

questions.text: Identify the structure in the picture below that helps in demarcating between upper and lower GI bleed.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ligament of Treitz

 

  • The Ligament of Treitz, also known as the suspensory muscle of the duodenum, is an anatomical structure that helps demarcate between upper and lower gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.
  • Upper GI bleeding is defined as bleeding originating proximal to the Ligament of Treitz, whereas lower GI bleeding originates distal to this structure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pylorus: Marks the distal end of the stomach and the beginning of the duodenum but does not demarcate upper and lower GI bleeds.

 

Option B. Duodenum 2nd part: Serves as the demarcation point of foregut and midgut.

 

Option D. Ileocecal valve: Marks the junction between the small intestine and the large intestine but is not used for demarcating GI bleeds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Ligament of Treitz is the anatomical structure used to differentiate between upper and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: You need to evaluate the lung function in a group of 300 factory workers exposed to industrial pollutants. The distribution of forced expiratory volume (FEV) in these workers has a median value of 2.5 litres, with the first and third quartiles being 1.5 and 4.5 litres, respectively. Based on this data, how many workers are expected to have an FEV between 1.5 and 4.5 litres?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 150

 

  • Quartiles divide a distribution into four equal parts. The first quartile (Q1) and third quartile (Q3) cover the middle 50% of the distribution.
  • In this case, Q1 is 1.5 litres and Q3 is 4.5 litres, so the interquartile range (IQR) is from 1.5 to 4.5 litres. Since the IQR covers 50% of the data, 50% of the 300 workers, which is 150 individuals, are expected to have an FEV between 1.5 and 4.5 litres.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The interquartile range (IQR) represents the middle 50% of a distribution.

choices.text: Cuffed suction aid tracheostomy tube

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cuffed suction aid tracheostomy tube

 

  • The image shows a cuffed suction aid tracheostomy tube.
  • This tube resembles an ordinary cuffed tracheostomy tube but includes an additional suction tube that reaches above the cuff.
  •  This feature allows for the suctioning of pharyngeal secretions collected above the cuff.
  •  It is important to perform suctioning before deflating the cuff to prevent the aspiration of accumulated pharyngeal secretions into the trachea.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Fuller’s tracheostomy tube: Does not include a suction aid.

 

Option B. Jackson’s tracheostomy tube: Typically made of metal, without a cuff or suction aid.

 

Option C. Cuffed tracheostomy tube: Includes a cuff but lacks the suction aid feature.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

  • A cuffed suction aid tracheostomy tube includes a suction tube above the cuff to remove pharyngeal secretions, preventing aspiration into the trachea.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of shortness of breath and palpitations. On physical examination, you perform this test and you also hear a diastolic murmur over the left sternal border. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aortic regurgitation

 

  • Aortic regurgitation presents with a "water hammer" pulse, which is a bounding and forceful pulse, and a diastolic murmur heard over the left sternal border due to blood leaking back into the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral stenosis: Mitral stenosis typically presents with a mid-diastolic rumbling murmur and does not cause a "water hammer" pulse.
 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: Mitral regurgitation is associated with a holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla, not a "water hammer" pulse.
 

Option D. Aortic stenosis: Aortic stenosis presents with a systolic ejection murmur and can cause a weak and delayed pulse (pulsus parvus et tardus), not a "water hammer" pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aortic regurgitation should be suspected in patients with a "water hammer" pulse and diastolic murmur over the left sternal border.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with developmental delay, coarse facial features, and elevated lysosomal enzymes in the blood. Further investigation reveals a deficiency in phosphorylating enzymes responsible for adding a recognition marker to lysosomal enzymes, leading to I-cell disease. Which of the following recognition markers leads to I-cell disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mannose 6-phosphate

 

  • I-cell disease (inclusion-cell disease) is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a defect in the enzyme N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase.
  • This enzyme is responsible for phosphorylating mannose residues on lysosomal enzymes, forming mannose 6-phosphate (M6P).
  • The M6P marker is crucial for the proper targeting of enzymes to the lysosome.
  • In the absence of M6P, lysosomal enzymes are secreted into the extracellular space instead of being transported to lysosomes, leading to the accumulation of undigested substrates within cells and resulting in the characteristic clinical features of I-cell disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Galactose: Not involved in the recognition marker for lysosomal enzyme targeting.

 

Option B. GM2 ganglioside: Associated with Tay-Sachs disease, a different lysosomal storage disorder involving hexosaminidase A deficiency.

 

Option D. Globoside: Involved in other glycosphingolipid storage diseases, such as Fabry disease, but not related to the recognition marker in I-cell disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • I-cell disease results from a deficiency in the enzymes responsible for adding mannose 6-phosphate to lysosomal enzymes, leading to their misdirection and causing the disease's symptoms.

choices.text: Doses at 0 & 6-12 months if age is more than 15 years

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to her pediatrician for vaccine enquiry. Which of the following is not true regarding HPV vaccines?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Doses at 0 & 6-12 months if age is more than 15 years

 

  • The HPV vaccine is typically administered in a series of doses. For individuals aged 9 through 14 years, the vaccine is given in a 2-dose series at 0 and 6-12 months. For individuals aged 15 through 26 years, the vaccine is given in a 3-dose series at 0, 1-2 months, and 6 months.
  • Therefore, the statement "Doses at 0 & 6-12 months if age is more than 15 years" is not true, as individuals over 15 years should receive three doses, not two.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Recommended age is 9-26 years: The recommended age for HPV vaccination is 9-26 years.

 

Option C. Gardasil protects against HPV 6, 11, 16 & 18: Gardasil (also known as Gardasil 4) protects against HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18.

 

Option D. Cervarix protects against HPV 16 & 18: Cervarix protects against HPV types 16 and 18.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The HPV vaccine is recommended for individuals aged 9-26 years. For those aged 9-14 years, it is administered in a 2-dose series, and for those aged 15-26 years, it is administered in a 3-dose series.
  • Gardasil protects against HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18, while Cervarix protects against HPV types 16 and 18.

choices.text: Skin, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, dura mater, arachnoid mater
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, epidural space, dura mater
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space, dura mater, arachnoid mater
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, subdural space, arachnoid mater

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the hospital for an elective hernia repair surgery. The anesthesiologist decides to administer spinal anesthesia for the procedure. During the administration, the needle is carefully advanced through which anatomical layers to reach the subarachnoid space?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space, dura mater, arachnoid mater

 

  • This is the accurate sequence of layers that the needle pierces during spinal anesthesia, from the outermost to the innermost layer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Skin, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, dura mater, arachnoid mater: Incorrect. While this option lists several layers, it omits the subcutaneous tissue and ligamentum flavum and incorrectly skips the epidural space.

 

Option B. Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, epidural space, dura mater: Incorrect. This option fails to include the interspinous ligament and the arachnoid mater.

 

Option D. Skin, subcutaneous tissue, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, subdural space, arachnoid mater: Incorrect. The supraspinous ligament is not included in the list.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The proper sequence of anatomical layers pierced during spinal anesthesia is skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space, dura mater, and arachnoid mater.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient is admitted to the hospital with a suspected bloodstream infection. Blood cultures are drawn to identify the causative organism. In order to maintain diagnostic accuracy and reduce unnecessary treatments, what is the maximum accepted contamination rate for a blood culture?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3%

 

Explanation:

 

  • The maximum accepted contamination rate for a blood culture is 3%. Blood culture contamination can lead to false-positive results, unnecessary antibiotic use, and increased healthcare costs.
  • Maintaining contamination rates below this threshold is important for accurate diagnosis and appropriate patient management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The maximum accepted contamination rate for blood cultures is 3%, emphasizing the importance of proper collection techniques to minimize false-positive results and ensure accurate diagnosis.

questions.text: During a review of radiological techniques, a myelography study on a patient demonstrates an expanded contrast-filled space. Which condition is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intradural extramedullary tumor

 

  • In myelography, an intradural extramedullary tumor typically shows an expansion of the contrast-filled space because these tumors are located within the dural sheath but outside the spinal cord itself.
  • This location allows the tumor to displace the spinal cord and/or cauda equina, creating an expanded area where the contrast agent accumulates around, rather than within, the spinal cord.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Extradural tumor : Incorrect. An extradural tumor, located outside the dura mater, generally compresses the dura and might narrow the contrast-filled space rather than expanding it, as the tumor itself does not lie within the dural sac.

 

Option B. Spinal dysraphism: Incorrect. Spinal dysraphism refers to congenital defects in the neural tube closure but does not typically show an expanded contrast-filled space in myelography. It may show other anomalies depending on the specific type of dysraphism.

 

Option C. Intramedullary tumor:  Incorrect. Intramedullary tumors, which develop inside the spinal cord, may cause an irregular or distorted appearance of the cord in myelography, but they do not typically lead to an expanded contrast-filled space since the tumor is within the cord itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An expanded contrast-filled space in myelography is indicative of an intradural extramedullary tumor, reflecting the tumor's location within the dural sac but outside the spinal cord.

choices.text: Inhibits angiotensin I receptor and neprilysin
Inhibits the angiotensin II receptor and neprilysin enzyme
Inhibits Angiotensin converting enzyme and neprilysin
Inhibits Angiotensinogen and neprilysin enzyme

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with chronic heart failure and reduced ejection fraction is on optimal medical therapy, including ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, and diuretics. Despite this, he continues to  experience symptoms of dyspnea and fatigue. His cardiologist decides to switch his ACE inhibitor to an Omapatrilat. What is the mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibits angiotensin converting enzyme and neprilysin

 

  • Omapatrilat is a vasopetidase inhibitor that works by inhibiting two enzymes; angiotensin converting enzyme and neprilysin.
  • This dual action reduces vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and maladaptive remodeling, while enhancing natriuretic peptides that promote vasodilation and diuresis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Omapatrilat combine ACE inhibition and neprilysin inhibition to improve heart failure outcomes by reducing vasoconstriction and enhancing natriuretic peptide effects.

choices.text: Vertebral and anterior spinal artery
Intercostal and superior epigastric artery
Inferior phrenic and pericardiophrenic artery

questions.text: An Anatomy professor explains the compensation mechanisms in post-ductal coarctation of the aorta to medical students, focusing on how blood flow to the lower limbs is maintained despite the narrowing. Which of the following vessels are primarily involved in sustaining this blood flow?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intercostal and superior epigastric artery

 

  • In post-ductal coarctation of the aorta, where the narrowing occurs distal to the ductus arteriosus (typically just beyond the left subclavian artery), collateral circulation develops to bypass the obstruction and maintain blood flow to the lower body.
  • The intercostal arteries, which are branches of the aorta located below the coarctation, become enlarged and help in routing blood around the narrowed segment.
  • The superior epigastric arteries, branching from the internal thoracic arteries, also contribute to this collateral network, enhancing blood flow to the abdominal wall and lower limbs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Vertebral and anterior spinal artery: Incorrect. These arteries primarily supply the spinal cord and vertebral column, not the lower limbs.

 

Option C. Subcostal and umbilical artery: Incorrect. The subcostal arteries do participate in collateral circulation but are not the main contributors, and the umbilical artery is functionally insignificant postnatally as it becomes the medial umbilical ligament.

 

Option D. Inferior phrenic and pericardiophrenic artery: Incorrect. These arteries supply the diaphragm and pericardium respectively, and do not significantly contribute to lower limb circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In post-ductal coarctation of the aorta, the intercostal and superior epigastric arteries play a crucial role in maintaining adequate blood flow to the lower limbs through the development of collateral channels.

choices.text: Intercostal, Brachial, Epidural, Caudal
Intercostal, Epidural, Caudal, Brachial
Brachial, Intercostal, Caudal, Epidural
Caudal, Brachial, Intercostal, Epidural

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is scheduled for a series of minor surgical procedures that require the use of local anesthetics. The anesthesiologist must choose the route of administration to ensure the most appropriate and safe absorption of the local anesthetic. What is the correct order of routes for the absorption of local anesthetics from fastest to slowest?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intercostal, Brachial, Epidural, Caudal

 

  • The rate of absorption of local anesthetics is largely determined by the vascularity of the injection site. Intercostal injections are absorbed the fastest due to the rich vascular supply of the intercostal spaces.
  • This is followed by brachial plexus blocks, which are also highly vascularized.
  • Epidural and caudal blocks are absorbed more slowly because of the comparatively lower vascularity of these spaces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When administering local anesthetics, it's crucial to consider the rate of systemic absorption to avoid toxicity.
  • The intercostal route has the fastest absorption, followed by the brachial, with the epidural and caudal routes having slower absorption rates.

questions.text: Identify the provided histological slide:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thymus

 

The image clearly displays the lobular architecture typical of the thymus, where each lobule is separated by trabeculae - thin layers of connective tissue.

 

In this image, there are several key structural components:

 

  • Capsule: A dense, fibrous layer that encloses the thymus, visible at the top of the image.
  • Cortex: The darker, outer regions of the lobules where the majority of thymocytes (immature T cells) are located. The cortex appears denser due to the high density of lymphocytes.
  • Medulla: The lighter, central areas within the lobules, where thymocytes mature and where fewer lymphocytes are packed compared to the cortex.
  • Trabeculae (septa): These are extensions of the capsule that divide the thymus into lobules. They are made of connective tissue and help in structuring the organ into distinct compartments.

 

This structural characteristic is significant for the thymus gland, which is centrally involved in the immune system, specifically in the maturation of T-lymphocytes. Unlike other glands which may present varied structural features, the thymus' unique lobular division is key to its identification.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroid gland: Incorrect. A histological slide of the thyroid gland would display follicles lined with epithelial cells and filled with colloid, distinctly different from the trabecular and lobular structure shown in this image. The thyroid's role in hormone production is not aligned with the immune maturation depicted.

 

Option C. Spleen: Incorrect. The spleen would typically show a different histological appearance, characterized by areas of white and red pulp, which are not visible in the provided image. The spleen's structure facilitates its role in filtering blood and mounting immune responses, which differs from the lobular and trabecular structure seen in the image.

 

Option D. Tongue: Incorrect. The tongue's primary histological features include striated muscle fibers and taste buds in certain sections, none of which are present in this image. The tongue's muscular structure supports its functions in taste, speech, and food manipulation, not the immune function depicted here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The thymus gland is characterized by its unique lobular structure divided by trabeculae, playing a vital role in the immune system through the maturation of T-lymphocytes.

choices.text: Prevents degradation of imipenem in the kidney
Increases intestinal absorption of imipenem
Provides synergistic activity against Pseudomonas

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a complicated urinary tract infection is started on imipenem-cilastatin therapy. The addition of cilastatin to imipenem serves which of the following purposes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prevents degradation of imipenem in the kidney.

 

  • Imipenem is rapidly inactivated by renal dehydropeptidase I, so it is combined with cilastatin, an inhibitor of this enzyme.
  • Cilastatin increases the half-life of imipenem and also inhibits the formation of nephrotoxic metabolite.
  • Meropenem, doripenem and ertapenem are not metabolized by renal dehydropeptidase

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Increases intestinal absorption of imipenem:  Incorrect. Cilastatin does not affect the intestinal absorption of imipenem.

 

Option C. Inhibits beta-lactamase activity:   Incorrect. Cilastatin does not inhibit beta-lactamase. It specifically inhibits dehydropeptidase I in the kidneys.

 

Option D. Provides synergistic activity against Pseudomonas:  Incorrect. Cilastatin does not have antimicrobial activity and does not provide synergistic activity against Pseudomonas. Its role is to protect imipenem from renal degradation.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Cilastatin is combined with imipenem to prevent its degradation by renal dehydropeptidase I, thereby enhancing the antibiotic's efficacy and prolonging its activity in the body.

questions.text: A forensic expert is conducting a postmortem examination on a stillborn fetus to determine whether the fetus was viable at the time of death. Which center of ossification is commonly used as medico-legal evidence for fetal viability?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Talus

 

  • The appearance of the ossification center in the talus is a significant marker of fetal viability.
  • It typically appears around the 28th week (7th month) of gestation, a point at which the fetus is considered potentially viable outside the womb.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A & Option B. Head and distal end of femur: These ossify at different stages and are not as specific for viability.

 

Option D. Calcaneum: Appears around the 20-21st week of gestation and is less specific for the threshold of viability compared to the talus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the importance of the ossification center in the talus as a marker for fetal viability. 
  • Center of ossification for the calcaneum appears by the 5th month, four divisions of sternum by the 6th month, talus at the end of 7th month and lower end of femur by the 9th month (36th week).
  • At birth, a center of ossification is usually present for the cuboid and upper end of tibia

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with episodic headaches, sweating, and palpitations. His blood pressure is 180/110 mmHg. An abdominal CT scan is done as below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pheochromocytoma

 

  • Pheochromocytoma is characterized by episodic headaches, sweating, and palpitations due to catecholamine-secreting tumors, often causing hypertension.
  • Elevated metanephrines on lab tests and an adrenal mass on CT will confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary hyperaldosteronism: Primary hyperaldosteronism causes hypertension and hypokalemia but not episodic symptoms and elevated catecholamines.
 

Option C. Cushing's syndrome: Cushing's syndrome presents with weight gain, moon face, and hypertension, not episodic symptoms .
 

Option D. Adrenal adenoma: Adrenal adenoma can be non-functional or cause Cushing’s syndrome or hyperaldosteronism, but rarely the episodic symptoms seen in pheochromocytoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pheochromocytoma presents with episodic headaches, sweating, and palpitations, with elevated metanephrines and an adrenal mass on imaging.

choices.text: Increased S/D ratio – Absent end diastolic flow – Reversal of end diastolic flow
Absent end diastolic flow - Increased S/D ratio – Reversal of end diastolic flow
Reversal of end diastolic flow - Increased S/D ratio – Absent end diastolic flow
Increased S/D ratio – Reversal of end diastolic flow – Absent end diastolic flow

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of umbilical artery Doppler findings indicative of progressive worsening intrauterine fetal hypoxia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased S/D ratio – Absent end diastolic flow – Reversal of end diastolic flow

 

  • Umbilical artery Doppler findings are used to monitor fetal well-being, especially in cases of suspected intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) and fetal hypoxia.
  • The sequence of Doppler changes indicative of progressive worsening intrauterine fetal hypoxia is as follows:
    1. Increased S/D ratio: The systolic to diastolic (S/D) ratio is a measure of the resistance in the placental circulation. An increased S/D ratio indicates increased resistance, which is an early sign of placental insufficiency.
    2. Absent end diastolic flow: As hypoxia worsens, the diastolic component of the umbilical artery flow may become absent, indicating further compromised blood flow to the fetus.
    3. Reversal of end diastolic flow: This is a severe finding, suggesting critically compromised placental blood flow and significant fetal distress. It is associated with a high risk of adverse perinatal outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct sequence of umbilical artery Doppler changes indicating progressive worsening intrauterine fetal hypoxia is an increased S/D ratio, followed by absent end diastolic flow, and finally, reversal of end diastolic flow.

choices.text: Decreases the power of the test
Standard error of the mean decreases
Increases the precision of estimates

questions.text: A district health officer in a rural area is tasked to conduct a study to evaluate the effectiveness of a new health intervention program. To improve the reliability and robustness of the study's results, they decide to increase the sample size. Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the effects of increasing the sample size?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases the power of the test

 

  • Increasing the sample size generally increases the power of a statistical test, which means the test is more likely to detect a true effect if one exists.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Standard error of the mean decreases: As the sample size increases, the standard error of the mean decreases because the estimate of the population mean becomes more precise.

 

Option C. Confidence interval narrows: With a larger sample size, the confidence interval becomes narrower, indicating a more precise estimate of the population parameter.

 

Option D. Increases the precision of estimates: A larger sample size leads to more precise estimates of population parameters, reducing the margin of error.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increasing Sample Size

 

  • Decreases Confidence interval (resulting in more precise estimates)
  • Increases Power of a test (by decreasing probability of Type II error)
  • Decreases Alpha error (maximum probability threshold of Type I error)
  • Decreases Standard error of mean

questions.text: Earliest feature of spinal tuberculosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pain

 

SPINAL TUBERCULOSIS

 

  • The earliest feature of spinal tuberculosis or Pott’s disease is typically pain.
  • Initially, it may be localized to the affected area of the spine and may worsen with movement and weight-bearing.
  • The pain is insidious in onset and may be mild initially, before progressing as the disease advances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gibbus: Gibbus deformity is an angular kyphosis or hunchback deformity of the spine. It is a late manifestation of spinal tuberculosis, usually seen in advanced cases where there has been significant destruction of vertebral bodies.

 

Option B. Muscle spasm: Muscle spasm can occur in response to pain but is not typically the earliest feature of spinal tuberculosis. It may develop as a secondary response to inflammation and structural changes in the spine. Paravertebral muscle spasm results in stiffness in the affected region. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension, known as Coin test.

 

Option D. Psoas abscess: Psoas abscess is a collection of pus in the psoas muscle, which can occur as a complication of spinal tuberculosis. It is not an early feature of the disease but a late complication that may develop as the infection progresses and spreads.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pain in the back is the most common and earliest symptom in patients with spinal tuberculosis.
  • It may appear mild in the initial stages but worsens with movements and weight bearing, and as the disease progresses.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and rectal bleeding. Colonoscopy reveals continuous inflammation from the rectum extending proximally to the sigmoid colon. Which of the following findings is most characteristic of ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Crypt abscesses

 

  • Crypt abscesses, which are collections of neutrophils within the crypts of the colonic mucosa, are a hallmark histological feature of ulcerative colitis.
  • This chronic inflammatory condition typically involves continuous mucosal inflammation starting from the rectum and extending proximally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skip lesions: Skip lesions, or areas of normal mucosa interspersed with inflamed mucosa, are characteristic of Crohn's disease, not ulcerative colitis.

 

Option B. Cobblestone appearance: Cobblestone appearance is also characteristic of Crohn's disease due to transmural inflammation and deep ulceration.

 

Option C. Transmural inflammation: Transmural inflammation is a feature of Crohn's disease, whereas ulcerative colitis involves only the mucosa and submucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Crypt abscesses are characteristic of ulcerative colitis, differentiating it from Crohn's disease, which has skip lesions and transmural inflammation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a sedentary lifestyle and a BMI of 26 presents for a routine checkup. She recently quit smoking but has not been taking her advised calcium and vitamin D supplements. Her DEXA scan shows a T-score of -2.5. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bisphosphonates

 

  • Bisphosphonates are the first-line treatment for osteoporosis, especially in postmenopausal women with a T-score of -2.5 or lower, which indicates osteoporosis.
  • Bisphosphonates work by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, thereby increasing bone mineral density and reducing the risk of fractures.
  • Given the patient's DEXA scan results showing a T-score of -2.5, indicating she has osteoporosis, bisphosphonates are the most appropriate treatment to reduce the risk of future fractures and improve bone health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium + Vitamin D supplementation: While calcium and vitamin D are essential for bone health and should be included in the management plan, they are not sufficient as a sole treatment for osteoporosis. Supplementation helps to maintain bone density and support the action of other osteoporosis medications, but they do not effectively treat osteoporosis on their own.

 

Option B. Estrogen + Progesterone: Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) can help prevent bone loss in postmenopausal women but is generally not the first-line treatment for osteoporosis due to potential risks, including cardiovascular events and breast cancer. It is typically considered in women who also have menopausal symptoms that require management.

 

Option C. Teriparatide: This medication is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone that stimulates bone formation.
