It is used for treating severe osteoporosis, particularly in individuals with a very high risk of fractures or who cannot tolerate other osteoporosis treatments. While effective, it is usually reserved for cases where bisphosphonates are not suitable or have failed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bisphosphonates are the most appropriate first-line treatment for osteoporosis in postmenopausal women with a T-score of -2.5 or lower, as they effectively reduce the risk of fractures by inhibiting bone resorption.

choices.text: Decrease in the Duration of Expiration
Increase in the Depth of Expiration
Increase in the Depth of Inspiration
Decrease in the Duration of Inspiration

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the pulmonology clinic for evaluation of his lung function due to chronic shortness of breath. He is subjected to a spirometry test to assess his respiratory mechanics. During the test, the clinician mentions various reflexes involved in respiratory control, including the Hering-Breuer Deflation reflex to his senior resident. What is the primary effect of the Hering-Breuer Deflation reflex?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decrease in the Duration of Expiration

 

  • The Hering-Breuer Deflation reflex is a protective mechanism that helps regulate the depth and duration of breathing.
  • This reflex is initiated by stretch receptors located in the lungs. When the lungs deflate, these receptors signal to the respiratory centers in the brain to shorten the duration of expiration.
  • This action serves to protect the lungs from over-deflation, ensuring that the lung volume remains within safe limits.
  • Specifically, the Hering-Breuer Deflation reflex causes a decrease in the duration of expiration by signaling the brain to start the next inspiration sooner.
  • This results in more frequent but shallower breaths, helping to maintain appropriate lung volume and prevent excessive lung collapse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in the Depth of Expiration: This statement is incorrect. The Hering-Breuer Deflation reflex does not primarily affect the depth of expiration. Instead, it shortens the duration of expiration to prevent over-deflation of the lungs.

 

Option C. Increase in the Depth of Inspiration: This statement is incorrect. While there are reflexes that can increase the depth of inspiration, the Hering-Breuer Deflation reflex is specifically related to preventing over-deflation of the lungs by decreasing the duration of expiration, not increasing the depth of inspiration.

 

Option D. Decrease in the Duration of Inspiration: This statement is incorrect. The Hering-Breuer Deflation reflex does not affect the duration of inspiration. Its primary role is to decrease the duration of expiration to protect the lungs from over-deflation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary effect of the Hering-Breuer Deflation reflex is to decrease the duration of expiration to prevent over-deflation of the lungs.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with severe pain and swelling in his big toe. He is diagnosed with acute gouty arthritis. The diagram below illustrates the pathophysiology of gout and indicates the site of action for various anti-gout medications. Which of the following anti-gout drugs acts at the site marked by the arrow in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Colchicine

 

  • Colchicine acts at the site marked by the arrow in the image, which indicates the inflammatory process involving the release of prostaglandins (PG), leukotrienes (LT), and lysosomal enzymes from activated neutrophils.
  • Colchicine disrupts microtubule formation, inhibiting neutrophil chemotaxis and activation, thus reducing inflammation in gout.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Indomethacin: Incorrect. Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that reduces pain and inflammation by inhibiting cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, but it does not specifically target neutrophil chemotaxis or activation.

 

Option C. Allopurinol: Incorrect. Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that reduces uric acid production. It does not act directly on the inflammatory pathway shown in the image.

 

Option D. Rasburicase: Incorrect. Rasburicase is a recombinant urate oxidase that converts uric acid to allantoin, facilitating uric acid excretion. It does not act directly on the inflammatory pathway shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Colchicine acts by inhibiting neutrophil chemotaxis and activation, thus reducing the release of inflammatory mediators in gout.
  • It is effective in managing acute gouty arthritis by targeting the inflammatory process.

choices.text: Drug A in the graph is epinephrine
The effect on heart rate in graph A can be prevented by anti-muscarinic agents
Drug acting on graph B is isoprenaline
Drug acting in the graph C is nor-epinephrine

questions.text: A pharmacology resident is studying the cardiovascular effects of three different adrenergic drugs, labelled A, B, and C. They recorded blood pressure and heart rate responses to these drugs and plotted the results as shown in the graphs below. Based on the graphs, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The effect on heart rate in graph A can be prevented by anti-muscarinic agents

 

Decoding the graph

 

Drug A: It increases systolic as well as diastolic BP and cause bradycardia. These properties suggest that it is norepinephrine. Increased BP lead to reflex bradycardia due to vagal stimulation. This reflex decrease in heart rate can be prevented by anti-muscarinic drugs like atropine.

 

After giving atropine, same dose of nor-epinephrine produces tachycardia instead of bradycardia because of its direct action only.

 

Drug B: It increases systolic BP, slightly decreases diastolic BP and cause tachycardia. These features suggest the drug to be epinephrine.

 

Drug C: It increases systolic BP, markedly decreases diastolic BP and cause severe tachycardia. These findings suggest drug C to be isoproterenol (isoprenaline).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Norepinephrine causes an increase in blood pressure and reflex bradycardia, which can be prevented by anti-muscarinic drugs like atropine.
  • Epinephrine increases systolic BP and heart rate while slightly decreasing diastolic BP.
  • Isoproterenol causes significant tachycardia and a marked decrease in diastolic BP.

questions.text: In patients with renal failure, which imaging technique is appropriate for visualizing vessels without causing further renal impairment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Time-of-flight angiography

 

  • This technique is a non-invasive MRI method that does not require the use of contrast agents.
  • Time-of-flight angiography utilizes the flow of blood through the vessels to generate the image, making it ideal for patients with renal failure as it avoids the use of nephrotoxic contrast agents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT angiography : Incorrect. CT angiography typically requires iodinated contrast, which can be nephrotoxic and risky for patients with renal failure.

 

Option B. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT) : Incorrect. Like CT angiography, CECT also involves the use of iodinated contrast material, which is potentially harmful to patients with impaired renal function.

 

Option C. MRI Contrast-enhanced angiography : Incorrect. Although MRI contrast agents (like gadolinium) are less nephrotoxic than iodinated agents used in CT, they still pose a risk, particularly in patients with severe renal impairment, due to the associated risk of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For imaging vessels in patients with renal failure, techniques that do not require contrast media, such as Time-of-flight angiography, are preferred to minimize the risk of further renal damage.
  • This method provides effective visualization based on blood flow dynamics without the use of potentially harmful contrast agents.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with prolonged labor and no cervical dilation or fetal descent for 4 hours. On examination, the fetal head is deeply engaged in the pelvis, and the patient shows signs of exhaustion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obstructed labor

 

  • Obstructed labor is a condition where the fetal head is unable to progress through the birth canal despite strong contractions, leading to a lack of progress in cervical dilation and fetal descent.
  • The deeply engaged fetal head and signs of maternal exhaustion are key indicators of obstructed labor.
  • This condition is serious and requires prompt intervention to prevent complications for both the mother and the fetus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine rupture: Uterine rupture is characterized by sudden, severe abdominal pain, fetal distress, and maternal signs of shock. The patient in this case does not exhibit these acute symptoms, making uterine rupture less likely.

 

Option B. Occiput anterior position: The occiput anterior position is a normal fetal position where the back of the baby's head faces the front of the mother's pelvis, which is favorable for delivery. This position does not account for the lack of progress in labor and maternal exhaustion.

 

Option D. Normal latent phase: The normal latent phase involves gradual cervical dilation and can last up to 20 hours in first-time mothers. However, the lack of progress in cervical dilation and fetal descent, along with signs of maternal exhaustion, indicates a complication beyond the normal latent phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Obstructed labor should be suspected in a woman experiencing prolonged labor with no progress in cervical dilation and fetal descent, especially when accompanied by signs of maternal exhaustion.
  • Prompt recognition and management are crucial to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman in labor is being considered for vacuum extraction. Which of the following is NOT a contraindication for vacuum extraction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Internal rotation incomplete

 

  • Incomplete internal rotation is not a contraindication for vacuum extraction.
  • Vacuum extraction can sometimes assist with completing the internal rotation of the fetal head during delivery.
  • The procedure is designed to help guide the fetal head through the birth canal when there is difficulty in completing this process naturally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aftercoming head in breech: Vacuum extraction is contraindicated in breech presentations where the aftercoming head is involved. This position presents a high risk of trauma and complications due to the difficulty in securing an effective vacuum on the fetal head.

 

Option B. Mento-anterior presentation: In a mento-anterior presentation, the baby's chin is anterior, and vacuum extraction is contraindicated because this abnormal position can lead to significant complications and ineffective vacuum application.

 

Option D. Floating head: A floating head, where the fetal head is not engaged in the pelvis, is a contraindication for vacuum extraction. The procedure requires the head to be engaged and relatively low in the birth canal to be effective and safe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Incomplete internal rotation is not a contraindication for vacuum extraction, as the procedure can assist in completing the rotation of the fetal head during delivery.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent ear infections and recent complaints of hearing loss. On examination, there is no visible perforation of the tympanic membrane. Tympanometry is performed, and the results show a flat, dome-shaped graph. What type of tympanogram is most likely associated with serous otitis media?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type B

 

  • Type B tympanogram is characterized by a flat or dome-shaped graph, indicating no change in compliance with pressure changes. It is commonly seen in conditions with middle ear fluid, such as serous otitis media, or in cases with a thick tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type A: Indicates normal tympanogram with normal compliance and pressure.

 

Option C. Type C: Shows maximum compliance with significant negative pressure, seen in retracted tympanic membrane.

 

Option D. Type D: This option does not correspond to a recognized tympanogram type in standard classifications.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type B tympanogram is indicative of middle ear fluid, commonly associated with serous otitis media, and is characterized by a flat, dome-shaped graph with no change in compliance with pressure changes.

choices.text: Loss of elasticity of skin

questions.text: As a forensic expert, you are called to a crime scene to examine a body found in an abandoned warehouse. To estimate the time of death, you need to identify early signs of death. Which of the following is not considered an early sign of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loss of voluntary power

 

  • Loss of voluntary power is the immediate/ earliest sign of death.
  • They are found in cases of prolonged fainting attack, vagal inhibitory phenomenon, epilepsy, trance, catalepsy, narcosis, electrocution, etc

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corneal opacity (early sign): It can occur shortly after death due to dehydration of the corneal epithelium. The opacity is due to drying and is delayed for about two hours if the lids are closed after death. 

 

If the eyelids are open for a few hours after death, a film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera at each side of the iris, with base towards the margin of cornea and apex towards medial or lateral canthus of the eye, which become brown and then black called "tache noir" within 3 to 4 hours, upon which dust settles and the surface becomes wrinkled (artefact)

 

 

Option B. Loss of elasticity of skin (early sign): Skin becomes pale and ashy-white and loses elasticity within a few minutes of death. The lips appear dark-red to black, dry and hard due to drying.

 

Option D. Postmortem cooling/ Algor mortis (early sign): This refers to the body cooling down to match the ambient temperature after death, which begins as soon as circulatory and respiratory functions cease.

 

Rate of cooling is 0.4 to 0.6°C per hour for next 12 to 16 hours after death. In tropical climates the heat loss is roughly 0.4 to 0.6°C and in temperate countries 1°C per hour.

 

Educational Objective

 

The signs of death appear in the following order

questions.text: Which of the following indices is known for measuring the expectation of life free of disability?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sullivan’s index

 

  • This index measures the expectation of life free of disability by combining mortality and morbidity data.
  •  It provides an estimate of the number of years an individual can expect to live without disability, reflecting both the quantity and quality of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Park’s index: This index is not specifically related to measuring the expectation of life free of disability.

 

Option B. Smith’s index: This index is not commonly associated with the measurement of disability-free life expectancy. This is actually the index of soil heterogeneity, primarily used to derive optimum plot size. The index gives a single value as a quantitative measure of soil heterogeneity in an area.

 

Option D. Life index: This is a general term and not a specific index used for measuring disability-free life expectancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sullivan’s Index is the Life Expectancy MINUS Duration of disability (bed disability and inability to perform major activities).
  • It is one of the most advanced indicators currently available to measure ‘Disability free life expectancy (DFLE)’

 

Note - Disability Adjusted Life Years [DALYs]

 

  • Is BEST measure of burden of disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions
  • It expresses years lost to premature death and years lived with disability (adjusted for its’ severity)
  • DALYs can measure ‘both mortality and disability together’

questions.text: According to the biomedical waste management guidelines, into which of the following should a cardiac pacemaker be discarded?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blue cardboard box

 

  • Blue colour BMW category is used for BMW – Glassware and Metallic Body Implants. Herte, Cardboard boxes with blue colored marking are used for disposal.
  • Disposal mechanism include Sodium Hypochlorite/ Autoclaving/ Microwaving/ Hydroclaving followed by Recycling

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: It only focused on industrial development.
AIIMS, New Delhi was established with financial assistance from Canada.
Canada supplied Cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India.
The plan excluded health promotion activities.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about the Colombo Plan?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Canada supplied Cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India

 

  • This statement is true as part of the Colombo Plan's support for health promotion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It only focused on industrial development: This is incorrect as the Colombo Plan also focused on agricultural development and health promotion.

 

Option B. AIIMS, New Delhi was established with financial assistance from Canada: This is incorrect. AIIMS, New Delhi, was established with financial assistance from New Zealand.

 

Option D. The plan excluded health promotion activities: This is incorrect as the Colombo Plan did support health promotion, mostly via fellowships.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Colombo Plan of 1950 aimed to improve living standards through industrial and agricultural development and health promotion.
  •  Notably, Canada supplied Cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India, and AIIMS, New Delhi, was established with financial assistance from New Zealand.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with severe diarrhea after a prolonged course of antibiotics for a respiratory infection. Clostridium difficile infection is suspected. Which class of antibiotics is most commonly associated with Clostridium difficile diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluoroquinolones

 

  • Prolonged use of fluoroquinolones is a significant risk factor for Clostridium difficile diarrhea.
  • These antibiotics disrupt the normal colonic flora, increasing susceptibility to C. difficile infection.
  • However, all antibiotics, including vancomycin and metronidazole (which are the drugs of choice in C. difficile infection) have been found to carry a risk of infection, if given for prolonged duration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aminopenicillins: Although these are also implicated in hospital outbreaks of C. difficile infection, they are not as commonly associated as fluoroquinolones.

 

Option C. Macrolides: Macrolides are less commonly associated with C. difficile infection compared to aminopenicillins.

 

Option D. Carbapenems: Carbapenems are not commonly linked to C. difficile diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prolonged antimicrobial use is the most important risk factor for Clostridium difficile diarrhea

questions.text: In a surgical anatomy lecture, a professor explains the boundaries of the "Triangle of Doom," a critical area in inguinal hernia repair. Which of the following is NOT a boundary of this triangle?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cooper ligament

 

  • The "Triangle of Doom" is an anatomical region in the inguinal area, crucial in laparoscopic hernia repairs. It is bounded by the vas deferens and testicular vessels.
  • Cooper's ligament forms the floor of the inguinal canal and does not serve as a boundary of this specific triangle.
  • This triangle is significant because it contains vital structures like the external iliac vessels, making awareness of its boundaries critical to avoid vascular injury during surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Testicular vessels: Incorrect. The testicular vessels are one of the boundaries of the Triangle of Doom, highlighting the need for caution during surgical procedures to avoid damaging these structures.

 

Option C.  Reflected peritoneal fold: Incorrect. While not traditionally listed as a boundary, the reflected peritoneal fold is close to the region and can be considered in broader descriptions of pelvic anatomy, though it is less directly relevant compared to the vas deferens and testicular vessels.

 

Option D. Vas deferens: Incorrect. The vas deferens is a critical boundary of the Triangle of Doom and is a key landmark in identifying the correct anatomical site during surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cooper's ligament does not form a boundary of the "Triangle of Doom"; it is bounded by the vas deferens and testicular vessels.

choices.text: Voltage-gated potassium channelopathy impacting depolarization
Dysfunction of the sodium-potassium pump

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of muscle weakness and difficulty maintaining coordination. During her evaluation, it is noted that her neurons fail to reach the firing threshold of -55 mV, indicating an impairment in the depolarization process. Further tests suggest an underlying ion channelopathy. Which ion channel dysfunction is most likely responsible for this specific impairment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Voltage-gated sodium channelopathy

 

  • Neuronal depolarization is a critical process for initiating and propagating action potentials.
  • This process involves a positive feedback loop primarily driven by the opening of voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels. When a neuron is stimulated, these channels open, allowing Na+ to flow into the cell.
  • This influx causes the membrane potential to become more positive, leading to further opening of Na+ channels and rapid depolarization.
  • If the voltage-gated sodium channels are dysfunctional, the neuron may not achieve the necessary Na+ influx to reach the threshold potential of -55 mV.
  • As a result, the neuron cannot generate an action potential, leading to impaired neuronal communication and symptoms such as muscle weakness and coordination difficulties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Voltage-gated calcium channelopathy: This statement is incorrect. Voltage-gated calcium channels are primarily involved in neurotransmitter release at synaptic terminals and other cellular functions. They do not play a central role in the initial depolarization phase required to reach the firing threshold.

 

Option C. Voltage-gated potassium channelopathy impacting depolarization: This statement is incorrect. Voltage-gated potassium channels are mainly involved in repolarizing the membrane after an action potential. Their dysfunction would affect repolarization rather than the initial depolarization required to reach the threshold potential.

 

Option D. Dysfunction of the sodium-potassium pump: This statement is incorrect. The sodium-potassium pump maintains the resting membrane potential by actively transporting Na+ out of and K+ into the cell. Its dysfunction would affect the resting potential rather than the rapid depolarization process needed to reach the threshold.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Voltage-gated sodium channelopathy is most likely responsible for the impairment in the positive feedback loop crucial for neuronal depolarization, leading to the failure to reach the threshold level and initiate an action potential.

choices.text: Topical mupirocin
Topical gentamicin

questions.text: Which of the following is not a recommended treatment option for impetigo?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Topical gentamicin

 

  • Topical gentamicin is not typically recommended for the treatment of impetigo.
  • The other treatment options listed (topical mupirocin, systemic erythromycin, and systemic cephalosporins) are all valid choices, depending on the extent and severity of the infection, and are particularly effective against the bacteria most commonly responsible for impetigo, such as Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic erythromycin: Suitable for more extensive cases of impetigo, particularly if topical treatments are insufficient.

 

Option B. Systemic cephalosporins: Used for extensive or severe cases, effective against the bacterial strains that cause impetigo.

 

Option C. Topical mupirocin: Widely recommended for localized cases of impetigo due to its efficacy against both Staphylococcus and Streptococcus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While systemic antibiotics like erythromycin and cephalosporins and topical treatments like mupirocin are effective for treating impetigo, topical gentamicin is not a standard treatment for this condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He is conscious but anxious, with a pulse rate of 130 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute, and urine output of 10 mL/hr. What class of shock is this patient experiencing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Class III

 

  • Class III shock is characterized by 30-40% blood loss, a pulse rate of 120-140 beats per minute, decreased blood pressure, decreased pulse pressure, a respiratory rate of 30-40 breaths per minute, anxious/confused mental status, and urine output of 5-15 mL/hr.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Class I: Blood loss <15%, pulse rate <100, normal blood pressure, normal or increased pulse pressure, respiratory rate 14-20, slightly anxious mental status, urine output >30 mL/hr.

 

Option B. Class II: Blood loss 15-30%, pulse rate 100-120, normal blood pressure, decreased pulse pressure, respiratory rate 20-30, mildly anxious mental status, urine output 20-30 mL/hr.

 

Option D. Class IV: Blood loss >40%, pulse rate >140, greatly decreased blood pressure, decreased pulse pressure, respiratory rate >35, confused/lethargic mental status, minimal urine output.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Class III shock involves 30-40% blood loss, rapid pulse, decreased blood pressure, increased respiratory rate, and low urine output.
  • Recognition is crucial for timely intervention.

choices.text: Biopsy specimen showing mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate
Positive serologic test for herpes simplex virus type 1
Cytologic scraping showing budding cells with pseudohyphae
Peripheral blood smear showing atypical lymphocytes

questions.text: A 25-year-old man develops several clear vesicles on his upper lip after an episode of the flu. The vesicles rupture, forming shallow, painful ulcers that heal over 4 weeks. Months later, after sun exposure during a skiing trip, he experiences a recurrence of similar lesions with the same healing pattern. Which of the following findings is most likely associated with these lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Positive serologic test for herpes simplex virus type 1

 

  • The patient’s recurrent vesicular lesions on the upper lip, triggered by factors such as flu or sun exposure, are indicative of herpes labialis, caused by herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1).
  • HSV-1 causes primary infection and then remains latent in the trigeminal ganglia. Reactivation of the virus due to stress or UV exposure results in the recurrence of the vesicular lesions.
  •  A positive serologic test for HSV-1 indicates the presence of antibodies against the virus, confirming previous infection and supporting the diagnosis of recurrent herpes labialis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biopsy specimen showing mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate: This is a nonspecific finding that can occur in various inflammatory conditions but does not specifically indicate HSV-1 infection.

 

Option C. Cytologic scraping showing budding cells with pseudohyphae: This finding is indicative of a fungal infection, such as candidiasis, which does not typically present with recurrent vesicular lesions on the lips.

 

Option D. Peripheral blood smear showing atypical lymphocytes: This is characteristic of infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), not HSV-1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recurrent vesicular lesions on the lips triggered by events such as illness or sun exposure are characteristic of herpes labialis, caused by herpes simplex virus type 1.
  • A positive serologic test for HSV-1 confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a study to identify gene mutations associated with a rare genetic disorder. The researcher decides to use DNA microarrays for this purpose. Which of the following techniques allows DNA microarrays to detect gene mutations?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hybridization

 

  • DNA microarrays detect gene mutations through the process of hybridization.
  • This technique involves binding complementary DNA sequences from the sample to probes on the microarray, allowing for the detection of specific gene mutations or expression levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR is a technique used to amplify DNA sequences but is not the primary method used in DNA microarrays for detecting gene mutations.

 

Option B. Cloning: Cloning involves creating copies of DNA but is not used in the context of DNA microarrays.

 

Option C. Southern blotting: Southern blotting is a method used for detecting specific DNA sequences but is not the technique used in DNA microarrays.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • DNA microarrays detect gene mutations through hybridization, a process where complementary DNA sequences bind to probes on the microarray, enabling the analysis of gene mutations or expression levels.

questions.text: A forensic expert is investigating a sexual assault case and needs to determine the timeline of the incident using Lugol's iodine test. What is the maximum duration after an assault that this test can yield positive results?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 days

 

Explanation:

 

  • Lugol's iodine test can detect the presence of vaginal epithelial cells for up to 4 days post-assault.
  • Glycogen-rich squamous epithelial cells of the vaginal tract may be stained with Lugol’s iodine.
  • This test is used to help establish the timeline of the incident in forensic investigations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Lugol's iodine test can detect vaginal epithelial cells up to 4 days after a sexual assault. Test is redundant now.

questions.text: A research associate is studying the effects of a new drug that mimics the action of catecholamines. The researchers observe that this drug, like nor-adrenaline, adrenaline, and dopamine, activates some specific receptors. Through which of the following receptors does this drug act?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Seven pass transmembrane receptors

 

  • Nor-adrenaline (NA), adrenaline (A), and dopamine (DA) act through G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs), which are characterized by their seven transmembrane domains.
  • These receptors span the cell membrane seven times, hence the term "seven pass transmembrane receptors."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single pass transmembrane receptors: Incorrect. Single pass transmembrane receptors span the membrane only once and are not typically associated with nor-adrenaline, adrenaline, and dopamine signaling.

 

Option B. Four pass transmembrane receptors: Incorrect. Four pass transmembrane receptors span the membrane four times.

 

Option D. Ligand gated receptors: Incorrect. Ligand gated receptors are ion channels that open in response to the binding of a ligand, such as neurotransmitters like GABA or acetylcholine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neurotransmitters (A, NA, DA) act through G-protein coupled receptors which are also known as seven transmembrane domain receptors, heptahelical receptors and serpentine receptors.

questions.text: In a clinical study examining visual processing abnormalities, a patient displays significant issues with contrast perception. Imaging studies pinpoint disruptions in the interactions between photoreceptors and certain retinal cells critical for visual contrast and information processing. Given the cells shown in the accompanying diagram, which are primarily implicated in modulating the input from rod and cone cells for enhanced visual contrast?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Horizontal cells

 

  • Horizontal cells, highlighted in the imaging studies, play a pivotal role in modulating and integrating signals from rod and cone photoreceptors, directly influencing contrast perception and the processing of visual information.
  • They achieve this through lateral connections that allow for the adjustment of the photoreceptor output, which is crucial for the enhancement of visual contrast and detailed spatial processing.
  • This modulation helps balance the signals received from different parts of the visual field, enhancing overall visual clarity and contrast.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bipolar diffuse cells: Incorrect because these cells primarily connect to multiple photoreceptors to relay specific, localized visual information directly to the ganglion cells, without the broad lateral integration seen in horizontal cells.

 

Option C. Rod bipolar cells: Incorrect as these cells are specialized for transmitting signals from rod cells under low-light conditions and do not typically engage in the modulation of input across different photoreceptor types for contrast enhancement.

 

Option D. Midget bipolar cells: Incorrect because they are involved in high-acuity vision by connecting to individual cone cells in the central retina, focusing on detailed color discrimination rather than the broad-based contrast modulation associated with horizontal cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Horizontal cells are crucial for the integration and modulation of input from both rod and cone cells, essential for optimizing contrast perception and visual information processing in the retina.
  • This capability is fundamental in disorders affecting contrast sensitivity and visual acuity.

questions.text: In a clinical scenario involving gastrointestinal tract studies, a patient experiences a complete cessation of colonic mass movements. Which condition would lead to the cessation of mass movements in the colon?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Destruction of Auerbach’s plexus

 

  • Destruction of Auerbach’s plexus is primarily responsible for the cessation of colonic mass movements.
  • Auerbach's plexus, or the myenteric plexus, is a critical component of the enteric nervous system located between the muscular layers of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • It directly controls the peristaltic movements of the gut.
  • When this plexus is damaged or destroyed, the ability of the colon to perform coordinated muscular contractions, essential for mass movements that propel fecal matter, is significantly impaired or completely halted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrocolic reflex: Incorrect because the gastrocolic reflex enhances colonic motility in response to stomach filling with food, thus promoting, not ceasing, mass movements.

 

Option B. Extrinsic denervation: Incorrect because while the extrinsic nervous system influences gut motility by modulating the intensity and rate of contractions, its denervation does not typically result in the complete cessation of mass movements as the intrinsic myenteric plexus can independently manage basic gut motility.

 

Option C. Distension of the colon: Incorrect as distension usually triggers mass movements rather than stopping them. It is a physiological response to the presence of a substantial amount of fecal material in the colon, necessitating movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The destruction of Auerbach's plexus leads to a significant disruption in the normal peristaltic functions of the colon, specifically abolishing the mass movements necessary for the proper transit of feces.
  • This highlights the critical role of the myenteric plexus in coordinating gastrointestinal motility.

choices.text: It forms half of the portion of the enzyme.
It binds with the substrate by non-covalent bonds.
It is not usually a cleft or crevice.
Binding of the substrate to the site is independent of the alignment of specific groups.

questions.text: A PG resident from biochemistry is studying enzyme kinetics and the factors that influence enzyme activity for his recent publication. He is particularly interested in how substrates interact with enzymes at their active sites, so which of the following statements is true about the active site of an enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It binds with the substrate by non-covalent bonds.

 

  • The active site of an enzyme is a specific region where the substrate binds and undergoes a chemical reaction.
  • The binding of the substrate to the active site involves non-covalent interactions, such as hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, and van der Waals forces.
  • These interactions ensure proper alignment and positioning of the substrate for the reaction to occur efficiently.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It forms half of the portion of the enzyme: This statement is incorrect because the active site typically comprises a small part of the enzyme's overall structure, not half of it.

 

Option C. It is not usually a cleft or crevice: This statement is incorrect because the active site of an enzyme is often a cleft or crevice on the enzyme's surface where the substrate binds.

 

Option D. Binding of the substrate to the site is independent of the alignment of specific groups: This statement is incorrect because the binding of the substrate to the active site is highly dependent on the precise alignment of specific groups on both the enzyme and the substrate, ensuring proper interaction and catalysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The active site of an enzyme binds with the substrate by non-covalent bonds, ensuring proper alignment for the biochemical reaction to occur.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman visits the outpatient department (OPD) due to experiencing postmenopausal bleeding. An ultrasound examination reveals an endometrial thickness of 7 mm. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial aspiration biopsy

 

  • Endometrial aspiration biopsy is the appropriate next step in the management of a postmenopausal woman with an endometrial thickness of 7 mm and postmenopausal bleeding.
  • In postmenopausal women, any bleeding should be evaluated promptly due to the increased risk of endometrial cancer.
  • An endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm is concerning and warrants further investigation.
  • Endometrial biopsy is a minimally invasive procedure that allows for the sampling of endometrial tissue to rule out or confirm malignancy or other endometrial pathology.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Prepare for hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is a definitive surgical treatment that may be considered if endometrial cancer is diagnosed. However, it is not the initial step in the diagnostic process. Before considering such an invasive procedure, it is essential to perform an endometrial biopsy to determine the underlying cause of the bleeding.

 

Option B. CA 125: CA 125 is a tumor marker that is primarily used in the evaluation of ovarian cancer, not endometrial cancer. While it can be elevated in various malignancies, including endometrial cancer, it is not a diagnostic tool for postmenopausal bleeding and does not provide specific information about endometrial pathology.

 

Option C. Pap smear: A Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer and is not used to evaluate endometrial pathology. Although important for cervical health, it does not provide information regarding the endometrial lining or the cause of postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a postmenopausal woman with an endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm and postmenopausal bleeding, the next step in management is an endometrial aspiration biopsy to rule out endometrial cancer.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after suddenly losing consciousness. She exhibits loss of movement on the right side of her body. Cerebral angiography reveals an occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery. To mitigate further ischemic damage to the cerebral cortex which of the following mediators would be most beneficial to prevent further ischemic injury to the cerebral cortex?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nitric oxide

 

  • Nitric oxide is a potent vasodilator that helps maintain vascular homeostasis.
  •  It plays a crucial role in preventing ischemic injury by dilating blood vessels, improving blood flow, and increasing oxygen and nutrient delivery to tissues, including the brain.
  • In the context of a middle cerebral artery occlusion, nitric oxide can help to minimize ischemic damage by promoting vasodilation and enhancing blood supply to the affected cerebral cortex. Additionally, nitric oxide has anti-inflammatory and anti-thrombotic properties, further protecting the brain tissue during ischemic events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bradykinin:  Although bradykinin is a vasodilator, it also increases vascular permeability, leading to edema, which can exacerbate ischemic injury in the brain rather than prevent it.

 

Option B. Platelet-activating factor: This mediator promotes platelet aggregation and inflammation, which would likely worsen ischemic conditions by increasing the risk of further clot formation.

 

Option D. Thromboxane A2: Thromboxane A2 is a vasoconstrictor and promotes platelet aggregation, which would likely exacerbate ischemic injury by further reducing blood flow to the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nitric oxide is the most beneficial mediator to prevent further ischemic injury to the cerebral cortex due to its vasodilatory, anti-inflammatory, and anti-thrombotic properties.

questions.text: Dense calcification is found in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Synovial sarcoma  

 

  • Dense calcification is typically not found in synovial sarcoma.
  • Synovial sarcoma is a malignant soft tissue tumor that can occur near joints, although it is not derived from synovial tissue.
  • While calcifications can sometimes be seen in synovial sarcoma, they are typically not as dense as those seen in other tumors.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor characterized by the production of osteoid tissue. Calcifications present in osteosarcoma are usually dense but not denser than those seen in osteoblastoma.

 

Option B. Chondroblastoma: Chondroblastoma is a benign bone tumor that arises in the epiphyses of long bones. Dense calcifications can be seen within the tumor on imaging studies such as X-rays.

 

Option D. Osteoblastoma: Osteoblastoma is a benign bone tumor composed of osteoblast cells. Dense calcifications are often present within the tumor, which can be seen on imaging studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In synovial sarcoma, calcifications are present, but they are not much denser than those seen in osteosarcoma, chondroblastoma, or osteoblastoma.

choices.text: G proteins are bound to GTP in their resting state
All three subunits (alpha, beta, and gamma) must bind together after G protein activation
G proteins act as both inhibitory and excitatory due to variations in the alpha subunit
G proteins are not involved in signal transduction

questions.text: In a discussion on cellular signaling during a physiology lecture, a question arises about the characteristics of G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs). Which of the following statements accurately reflects the function of G proteins in GPCR signaling mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G proteins act as both inhibitory and excitatory due to variations in the alpha subunit

 

  • G proteins linked to GPCRs can either inhibit or excite various cellular responses depending on the type of alpha subunit they contain.
  • For example, Gα_s stimulates adenylyl cyclase, increasing cAMP levels and promoting cellular activity, while Gα_i inhibits adenylyl cyclase, reducing cAMP levels and suppressing cellular activity.
  • This variability allows G proteins to mediate a wide range of physiological responses based on the signaling needs of the cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G proteins are bound to GTP in their resting state: Incorrect because in their resting state, G proteins are bound to GDP (guanosine diphosphate). Upon activation by a GPCR, GDP is exchanged for GTP.

 

Option B. All three subunits (alpha, beta, and gamma) must bind together after G protein activation: Incorrect because the activation of G proteins involves the dissociation of the alpha subunit from the beta and gamma subunits upon GTP binding; they do not need to be bound together to act.

 

Option D. G proteins are not involved in signal transduction: This statement is incorrect. G proteins are central to the signal transduction mechanisms mediated by GPCRs. They act as molecular switches that relay signals from the activated receptor to various intracellular signaling pathways, modulating cellular responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • G proteins function as molecular switches within G protein-coupled receptor pathways, acting either as inhibitors or exciters of cellular responses based on the type of alpha subunit they possess.

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn presents with respiratory distress and abdominal distension. A nasogastric tube was inserted, and an X-ray was performed as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophageal atresia

 

  • The X-ray image shows a nasogastric tube coiled in the upper esophagus, indicating esophageal atresia with distal tracheoesophageal fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital diaphragmatic hernia: This condition typically presents with a scaphoid abdomen and bowel sounds in the chest, and the X-ray would show bowel loops in the thoracic cavity, which is not seen here.

 

Option C. Pyloric stenosis: Pyloric stenosis presents with projectile vomiting and a palpable olive-shaped mass. The X-ray typically shows a dilated stomach with minimal gas in the intestines, which is not consistent with the findings in this image.

 

Option D. Hirschsprung disease: Hirschsprung disease presents with a failure to pass meconium and abdominal distension. An X-ray would show a distended colon with a transition zone, which is not evident in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Esophageal atresia with distal tracheoesophageal fistula presents with respiratory distress, difficulty with feeding, and an X-ray showing a coiled nasogastric tube in the upper esophagus with a gasless abdomen.
  • Early diagnosis and surgical intervention are crucial.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic for a routine check-up. The pediatrician performs a neurological examination. Which reflex is being tested?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parachute reflex

 

  • The parachute reflex is a protective reflex that appears around 6-8 months of age.
  • When the infant is held upright and tilted forward, they will extend their arms forward as if to break a fall.
  • This reflex is important for assessing the development of motor coordination and protective responses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moro reflex: The Moro reflex, or startle reflex, is seen in newborns up to 4-6 months of age. When the infant is startled, they will extend their arms and legs, then bring them back towards the body.

 

Option B. Babinski reflex: The Babinski reflex is a primitive reflex seen in infants up to 1 year of age. When the sole of the foot is stroked, the big toe extends upward and the other toes fan out.

 

Option D. Rooting reflex: The rooting reflex is seen in newborns up to 4 months of age. When the infant's cheek is stroked, they will turn their head towards the stimulus and open their mouth in search of a nipple.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The parachute reflex appears around 6-8 months of age and is a protective response where the infant extends their arms forward when tilted as if falling.
  • This reflex is crucial for evaluating the development of motor coordination and protective mechanisms in infants.

questions.text: Which of the following groups would benefit most from receiving the pneumococcal vaccine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sickle cell anemia

 

  • Patients with sickle cell anemia are at increased risk for invasive pneumococcal disease due to functional asplenia.
  • The pneumococcal vaccine is crucial for these patients to prevent serious infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cystic fibrosis patient: While patients with cystic fibrosis may benefit from the pneumococcal vaccine, it is not as critical as for those with sickle cell anemia.

 

Option C. Recurrent otitis and sinusitis: Children with recurrent otitis and sinusitis can benefit from the pneumococcal vaccine, but they are not at as high a risk as those with sickle cell anemia.

 

Option D. Child less than 2 years: Children under 2 years old are recommended to receive the pneumococcal vaccine, but the risk of invasive disease is particularly high in sickle cell anemia patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indications for pneumococcal vaccine:

 

  • After birth (as a part of routine childhood immunization)
  • Age ≥65 years
  • Age 19–64 years with underlying risk factors
  • Immunocompetent persons: With alcoholism and smoking, chronic heart, liver and lung disease, diabetes mellitus
  • Immunocompetent persons: With cochlear implants and CSF leaks
  • Splenic dysfunction: Congenital or acquired asplenia, sickle cell disease/other hemoglobinopathies
  • Immunocompromised persons: Chronic renal failure, congenital or acquired immunodeficiencies, HIV infection, malignancy and solid organ transplant

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with leprosy, and the public health team is planning prophylactic measures for her close contacts. Which of the following conditions must be met for prophylaxis to be given?

 

  1. Sharing towels, clothes, etc.
  2. Living together for 6 months since onset
  3. Spending 20 hours or more a week in close contact
  4. If age >2 years
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4

 

  • According to WHO guidelines, post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for leprosy is recommended for individuals who have been in close contact with the index case for 20 hours or more per week for more than 3 months.
  • Additionally, the contacts should be older than 2 years, but it must be combined with the condition of spending 20 hours or more a week in close contact.
  • Children younger than 2 years can receive single-dose rifampicin (SDR) at follow-up visits if they meet other criteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-exposure prophylaxis for leprosy is given as chemoprophylaxis, where Rifampicin single dose is given
  • Inclusion Criteria for PEP Leprosy:
    • Being identified as a contact, i.e. a person who has been in close contact with the index case for 20 hours or more per week for more than 3 months
    • Age: more than 2 years; if younger than 2 years, the child can be given SDR at the age of 2, in follow up visits of contacts (if meeting all other inclusion criteria)

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with hypertension and diabetes presents with decreased urine output, weakness, and nausea after starting a new hypertension medication. Labs show elevated serum creatinine, BUN, and hyperkalemia. Urinalysis is shown below. What is the likely cause of acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute tubular necrosis

 

  • The image likely shows muddy brown casts, which are a characteristic finding in acute tubular necrosis (ATN), typically seen in the setting of ischemic or nephrotoxic acute kidney injury (AKI). Features of ATN:

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Prerenal azotemia: It is caused by decreased renal perfusion and is usually reversible with the restoration of adequate blood flow to the kidneys. It is often associated with conditions that lead to hypovolemia or decreased cardiac output.

 

Option C. Acute glomerulonephritis: This could cause AKI, but urinalysis would likely show red blood cell casts and dysmorphic red blood cells, and the patient would have other signs such as hypertension, hematuria, and proteinuria.

 

Option D. Postrenal obstruction: This leads to AKI due to the obstruction of urine flow, which would be suggested by symptoms of urinary retention or findings such as hydronephrosis on imaging, not typically by the presence of muddy brown casts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute tubular necrosis is characterized by the presence of muddy brown casts on urinalysis and is a common cause of acute kidney injury, often associated with recent changes in medication that may have nephrotoxic effects.

questions.text: A six-month-old infant is brought to the ophthalmology outpatient department with symptoms of excessive tearing and sensitivity to light, as seen in the image provided. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Congenital Glaucoma

 

  • Congenital Glaucoma is a rare condition that can occur in babies and young children. It's caused by an abnormal development of the eye's drainage system, leading to increased intraocular pressure, which can damage the optic nerve.
  • Symptoms can include photophobia, excessive tearing (lacrimation), and cloudy, enlarged corneas. Given the symptoms described, congenital glaucoma is a likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucopolysaccharidoses: These are a group of metabolic disorders, not typically presenting with isolated eye symptoms like those observed. But in eyes it shows corneal clouding. Other symptoms includes – short stature, intellectual disability, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, joint contractures, dysostosis multiplex, etc

 

 

Option B. Congenital Cataract: Would show as a cloudy lens, which is not indicated by the clear lens seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Ophthalmia Neonatorum: Typically presents with pus-like discharge from the eyes, not primarily with photophobia or lacrimation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In infants presenting with symptoms like photophobia and lacrimation, along with signs like corneal haziness and eyeball enlargement, congenital glaucoma should be considered as a potential diagnosis.
  • Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent permanent visual impairment.

questions.text: Which of the following condition is Tolvaptan is used for?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SIADH

 

  • Vaptans like tolvaptan are vasopressin receptor antagonists.
  • V1 receptor antagonists may be useful when total peripheral resistance is increased (e.g. CHF and hypertension) whereas V2 antagonists may be useful for the treatment of SIADH.
  • Relcovaptan is selective V1 antagonist whereas lixivaptan, mozavaptan and tolvaptan are V2 selective antagonists.
  • Conivaptan is V1a/V2 receptor antagonist used as an aquaretic (increase water excretion without affecting electrolytes like sodium) in CHF.
  • Conivaptan is administered by iv injection whereas lixivaptan and tolvaptan can be given orally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Central DI: Incorrect. Central Diabetes Insipidus (DI) is characterized by a deficiency of ADH. Treatment typically involves desmopressin, a synthetic ADH analog, not a vasopressin receptor antagonist.

 

Option C. Von Willebrand disease: Incorrect. Von Willebrand disease is a bleeding disorder treated with desmopressin or factor replacement, not with a vasopressin receptor antagonist like Tolvaptan.

 

Option D. Catecholamine resistant shock: Incorrect. Catecholamine-resistant shock is usually managed with vasopressors and inotropes, not with a vasopressin receptor antagonist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tolvaptan is used to treat SIADH by antagonizing the vasopressin receptor, promoting water excretion, and correcting hyponatremia.
  •  It is not indicated for Central DI, Von Willebrand disease, or catecholamine-resistant shock.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the mechanisms of protein synthesis and is particularly interested in the enzymes that ensure the accuracy of translation. During a discussion on the fidelity of protein synthesis, the focus turns to the enzyme known for its role in maintaining high accuracy during translation. So, which enzyme involved in translation often referred to as ‘Fidelity enzyme'?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aminoacyl tRNA synthetase

 

  • Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases are critical enzymes in the process of translation, responsible for attaching the correct amino acid to its corresponding tRNA molecule.
  • This step is crucial for ensuring the accuracy of protein synthesis.
  • Each aminoacyl tRNA synthetase has a high degree of specificity for its amino acid and corresponding tRNA, and it includes proofreading mechanisms to correct any errors.
  • This high level of accuracy is why aminoacyl tRNA synthetases are often referred to as 'Fidelity enzymes' in the context of translation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA polymerase: This enzyme is involved in DNA replication, ensuring the fidelity of DNA synthesis by incorporating the correct nucleotides and proofreading errors.

 

Option B. RNA polymerase: This enzyme synthesizes RNA from a DNA template during transcription. While it plays a role in fidelity, it is not referred to as the 'Fidelity enzyme' in translation.

 

Option D. Aminoacyl reductase: This is not a standard enzyme involved in translation and does not play a role in maintaining translational fidelity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases ensure the accuracy of protein synthesis by correctly attaching amino acids to their corresponding tRNAs, making them essential for the fidelity of translation.

choices.text: Trans-cervical resection of the endometrium

questions.text: A 52-year-old menopausal woman presents with 3 days of bleeding. She has a history of heavy periods and is on antihypertensives. Examination reveals stable vitals and an unremarkable abdominal exam. Speculum exam shows a normal cervix with blood at the os, and a transvaginal scan reveals an endometrial thickness of 8 mm with normal ovaries. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial biopsy

 

  • Endometrial biopsy is the next best step in the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, especially when the endometrial thickness is greater than 4 mm.
  • This procedure is critical for ruling out endometrial hyperplasia or endometrial cancer, which are important causes of postmenopausal bleeding.
  • An endometrial thickness of 8 mm warrants further investigation to ensure there are no malignancies or precancerous conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-fibrinolytics: These medications are used to reduce bleeding but do not address the underlying cause of postmenopausal bleeding and are not appropriate for initial evaluation.

 

Option B. Hysterectomy: This is a definitive treatment option for various gynecological conditions but is not the first step in the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding without a confirmed diagnosis.

 

Option C. Trans-cervical resection of the endometrium: This procedure is used to treat endometrial pathology but is not the first-line approach in the evaluation process. Diagnosis via biopsy is essential before considering this treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endometrial biopsy is the appropriate next step for evaluating postmenopausal bleeding, especially when the endometrial thickness is greater than 4 mm, to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or cancer.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is diagnosed with Dravet syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy. The neurologist decides to prescribe an oral antiepileptic drug that enhances GABAergic activity. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stiripentol

 

  • Stiripentol is an oral antiepileptic drug that increases GABAergic activity.
  • It has recently been approved for the treatment of Dravet syndrome, a severe and rare form of epilepsy that typically begins in infancy.
  •  Stiripentol is used in combination with other antiepileptic medications to help control seizures in patients with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbamazepine: Incorrect. Carbamazepine is used for various types of epilepsy but is not specifically approved for Dravet syndrome and does not increase GABAergic activity.

 

Option C. Phenytoin: Incorrect. Phenytoin is another antiepileptic drug used for generalized tonic-clonic and partial seizures but is not specifically indicated for Dravet syndrome.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Incorrect. Topiramate is used for multiple seizure types but is not specifically approved for Dravet syndrome and does not primarily increase GABAergic activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Stiripentol is an oral antiepileptic drug that enhances GABAergic activity and has been recently approved for the treatment of Dravet syndrome, making it a suitable choice for managing this severe form of epilepsy.

 

Additional Information –

 

  • Rufinamide is approved drug for adjunctive treatment of seizures associated with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. It is thought to act by inhibiting Na+ channels.
  • Retigabine (also called ezogabine) is approved as add-on drug for partial seizures in adults. Urinary retention is its major adverse effect.
  • Cannabidiol is a CB1 receptor agonist. It is approved for Lennox Gastaut syndrome and Dravet syndrome. It is first drug approved by FDA containing a purified marijuana derivative.

choices.text: Administration of naloxone.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female is brought to the emergency department by her friends after being found unresponsive at home. On examination, her respiratory rate is 6 breaths/min, pupils are pinpoint, and oxygen saturation is 78% on room air. Her friends mentioned she might have used some pills. Which of the following is the most immediate and appropriate intervention for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Administration of naloxone.

 

  • The patient's presentation — unresponsiveness, markedly reduced respiratory rate, pinpoint pupils, and hypoxia — is indicative of opioid overdose. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist that rapidly reverses the effects of opioids and is the most appropriate immediate intervention in suspected opioid overdose cases.
  •  It can quickly restore normal respiration in a person whose breathing has slowed or stopped as a result of opioid overdose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric lavage: This is not the first-line treatment for opioid overdose. Immediate attention should be given to reverse respiratory depression, which is the most life-threatening complication.

 

Option B. Intravenous fluid administration: While fluid resuscitation might be beneficial in certain overdose situations or if hypotension is present, it does not directly address the primary life-threatening complication of opioid overdose: respiratory depression.

 

Option C. Administration of flumazenil: Flumazenil is an antagonist for benzodiazepine receptors and is used for benzodiazepine overdose. It has no effect on opioid receptors and will not reverse opioid-induced respiratory depression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The opioids are lethal in overdose. The drug of choice for treatment of opioid overdose is i.v. naloxone (short-acting opioid antagonist).

choices.text: Acute exacerbation of rheumatoid arthritis with pulmonary involvement

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with severe rheumatoid arthritis is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to severe pneumonia. On the second day, she develops increased respiratory distress, a marked increase in peak inspiratory pressures, decreased oxygen saturation to 85%, and an increased heart rate to 110 bpm. What is the most likely cause of her acute ventilatory deterioration?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumothorax

 

  • The sudden onset of respiratory distress, increased peak inspiratory pressures, decreased oxygen saturation, and increased heart rate suggests pneumothorax, likely due to barotrauma from mechanical ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary embolism: Pulmonary embolism causes hypoxemia and hemodynamic instability but not the marked increase in inspiratory pressures.
 

Option B. Ventilator-associated pneumonia: Ventilator-associated pneumonia develops over days and includes infection signs, not just acute changes in ventilatory mechanics.
 

Option D. Acute exacerbation of rheumatoid arthritis with pulmonary involvement: Acute exacerbation of rheumatoid arthritis with pulmonary involvement would not cause the sudden changes seen in pneumothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The sudden development of increased respiratory distress, marked increase in peak inspiratory pressures, and decreased oxygen saturation in a mechanically ventilated patient is highly suggestive of pneumothorax, particularly in the setting of acute lung injury or underlying lung disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a history of Crohn's disease presents with multiple skip lesions throughout the intestine. He has been experiencing severe abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and significant weight loss. His physician is planning a surgical resection of the damaged areas to alleviate his symptoms. During the surgical planning, the physician explains that removing certain parts of the intestine can lead to malabsorption issues. Which part of the intestine, if removed, is most likely to cause steatorrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ileum

 

  • The ileum is responsible for the absorption of bile acids and vitamin B12.
  • Resection of the ileum can lead to bile acid malabsorption, resulting in steatorrhea due to inadequate fat digestion and absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenum: Involved in the initial digestion of food but not primarily responsible for bile acid absorption.

 

Option B. Jejunum: Absorbs most nutrients but not bile acids, hence resection does not typically cause steatorrhea.

 

Option D. Caecum: Primarily involved in the absorption of water and electrolytes, not bile acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ileum is crucial for bile acid absorption.
  • Its resection can lead to steatorrhea due to bile acid malabsorption.

questions.text:
Mark the following statements regarding xenodiagnosis as true or false:

 

  1. Blood from a suspected dengue patient can be used for cultivation in Aedes mosquitoes
  2. Effect on rabbit ileal loop is used for diagnosis of ETEC
  3. Coxiella is cultivated in eggs to synthesize antigen required for antibody detection
  4. Sandfly can be grown in Hamster eggs
  5. Useful in Chagas’ disease
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-T, 2-T, 3-T, 4-F, 5-T

 

True: Blood from a suspected dengue patient can be used to infect Aedes mosquitoes, which can then be analyzed for the presence of the dengue virus.

 

True: The effect on the rabbit ileal loop is a diagnostic method used for Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC), which secretes enterotoxins affecting the intestinal mucosa.

 

True: Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, can be cultivated in eggs to produce antigens necessary for serological tests to detect antibodies.

 

False: Sandflies are not grown in hamster eggs. Sandflies are typically reared in laboratory conditions but not in eggs.

 

True: Xenodiagnosis is particularly useful in diagnosing Chagas’ disease, caused by Trypanosoma cruzi. Laboratory-reared vectors, like triatomine bugs, are used to detect low levels of parasites in chronic stages of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Xenodiagnosis uses laboratory reared vectors to detect low levels of parasites during chronic stages of the disease, when their numbers in the blood will be very low.
  • This technique is employed to diagnose Chagas’ disease.

choices.text: 3 and 4
1, 2 and 3
1, 3 and 4
Only 4

questions.text:
Which of the following is / are not a sub-type of lichen planus?

 

  1. Lichen planus hypertrophicus
  2. Ulcerative lichen planus
  3. Lichen nitidus
  4. Lichen scrofulosorum
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 and 4

 

  • Lichen nitidus and Lichen scrofulosorum are not considered subtypes of lichen planus.
  • Lichen nitidus is a separate dermatological condition characterized by tiny, shiny, flat-topped bumps typically found on the chest, abdomen, and genitals.
  • It is clinically and histopathologically distinct from lichen planus.

 

 

  • Lichen scrofulosorum, on the other hand, is a tuberculid, a skin manifestation associated with tuberculosis, and is not related to lichen planus at all.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Lichen planus hypertrophicus: This is a well-recognized variant of lichen planus characterized by hypertrophic or thickened lesions, often found on the legs.

 

 

2. Lichen planus erosive (previously referred to as ulcerative lichen planus): This is a severe, painful variant of lichen planus affecting mucosal surfaces, typically presenting with erosions or ulcers.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lichen nitidus and Lichen scrofulosorum are not subtypes of lichen planus; they are distinct dermatological entities with different clinical and pathological features.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) is being treated for hypertension. His nephrologist advises against the use of certain beta-blockers due to the risk of drug accumulation and toxicity in patients with renal failure. Which of the following beta-blockers should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atenolol

 

  • Atenolol is primarily excreted by the kidneys. In patients with renal failure, the reduced clearance of atenolol can lead to accumulation and increased risk of toxicity.
  • Therefore, atenolol is contraindicated in patients with renal failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoprolol: Incorrect. Metoprolol is primarily metabolized by the liver, not the kidneys, making it safer for use in patients with renal failure.

 

Option C.  Propranolol: Incorrect. Propranolol is metabolized in the liver and does not primarily depend on renal clearance.

 

Option D. Carvedilol: Incorrect. Carvedilol is metabolized by the liver and has a complex elimination pathway, but it is not primarily dependent on renal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Beta-blockers like Atenolol, Nadolol, and Sotalol (Mnemonic - ANS) are contraindicated in renal failure due to their dependence on renal clearance.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with eye discomfort and visible changes in the corneal region. Examination reveals circumcorneal vascularization. The physician suspects a vitamin deficiency as the underlying cause of her symptoms and orders relevant laboratory tests to confirm the diagnosis. Which vitamin deficiency is associated with circumcorneal vascularization?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Riboflavin

 

  • Circumcorneal vascularization, characterized by the formation of new blood vessels around the cornea, is commonly associated with riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency.
  • Riboflavin is crucial for maintaining healthy mucous membranes, including those in the eye.
  • Its deficiency can lead to ocular symptoms such as photophobia, tearing, and corneal vascularization due to impaired epithelial integrity and inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biotin: Deficiency typically presents with symptoms such as dermatitis, alopecia, and neurological issues, not corneal vascularization.

 

Option B. Thiamine: Deficiency leads to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which affect the cardiovascular and nervous systems, respectively.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Deficiency primarily affects bone health, causing rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, without direct ocular manifestations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency is associated with circumcorneal vascularization and other ocular symptoms due to its role in maintaining mucous membrane health.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of intense eye redness, watery discharge, and noticeable bleeding under the conjunctiva. She reports that several family members of her neighbour have experienced similar symptoms recently. She is suspected of having acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Which of the following viruses is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enterovirus 70

 

  • Acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by enterovirus 70, a picornavirus.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterovirus 68: Generally associated with respiratory illnesses, not with conjunctivitis.

 

Option B. Enterovirus 69: Not a recognized serotype associated with human diseases.

 

Option D. Enterovirus 71: Mainly causes hand, foot, and mouth disease and neurological complications, not conjunctivitis.

 

Other causative agent of acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis are Picornavirus, Adenovirus, Coxsackie virus, and Echo Virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enterovirus 70 is the causative agent of acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis; is essential for effective diagnosis and management of the condition, especially in outbreak situations.

choices.text: AUC from the above graph reflects the rate of absorption.
Tmax for drug X is 7 hours.
Instead of 100 mg, drug X should be given in divided doses.

questions.text: A new drug X is given orally to a healthy volunteer in a dose of 100 mg. Plasma concentration of the drug is measured at hourly intervals and a graph is plotted between plasma concentration and time as shown in the figure. Which of the following statements about drug X is TRUE?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Instead of 100 mg, drug X should be given in divided doses.

 

  • The graph shows that the peak plasma concentration (Cmax) of drug X exceeds the minimum toxic concentration, indicating that the dose of 100 mg may lead to toxicity.
  • Therefore, giving the drug in divided doses could help maintain therapeutic levels while avoiding toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Its Cmax is 20 μg/dl: Incorrect. The graph shows a peak concentration (Cmax) of around 27 μg/dl, not 20 μg/dl.

 

Option B. AUC from the above graph reflects the rate of absorption: Incorrect. The area under the curve (AUC) represents the total drug exposure over time, not the rate of absorption.

 

Option C.  Tmax for drug X is 7 hours: Incorrect. The time to reach maximum concentration (Tmax) is around 4 hours, not 7 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cmax is the maximum plasma concentration obtained.
  • Tmax is the time to reach Cmax. It tells about rate of absorption.
  • AUC reflects extent of absorption and not the rate of absorption.
  • To avoid the toxic effects, Cmax must be lower and to produce a lower Cmax, the dose has to be reduced.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is developed from the paraxial mesoderm?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Skeletal muscles

 

  • The paraxial mesoderm is a key germ layer in embryonic development that specifically contributes to the formation of skeletal muscles.
  • This mesoderm segment organizes into structures called somites, which further differentiate into various tissues, including the skeletal muscles that control voluntary movements throughout the body.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Parietal peritoneum: Incorrect. The parietal peritoneum is derived from the lateral plate mesoderm, not the paraxial mesoderm. The lateral plate mesoderm forms the somatic mesoderm, which contributes to the body’s cavities’ lining, including the parietal peritoneum.

 

Option B. Peritoneal cavity: Incorrect. The peritoneal cavity itself is not formed from any mesoderm but is a space located between the parietal and visceral peritoneum. It essentially represents a cavity within the body and does not arise from germ layer differentiation.

 

Option C. Visceral peritoneum: Incorrect. Like the parietal peritoneum, the visceral peritoneum is developed from the splanchnic mesoderm portion of the lateral plate mesoderm, which lines the external surfaces of the internal organs, not the paraxial mesoderm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The paraxial mesoderm plays a crucial role in developing skeletal muscles.

questions.text: Identify the surgery in which the instrument, as shown in the image below, is commonly used.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroidectomy

 

  • Joll's thyroid retractor is a specialized surgical instrument used primarily in thyroidectomy procedures. It is designed to retract the skin flaps, providing better exposure and access during the surgery.
  • Usually, two retractors are used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholecystectomy: Involves removal of the gallbladder, typically using different types of abdominal retractors.

 

Option C. Appendectomy: Involves removal of the appendix, typically using different types of abdominal retractors.

 

Option D. Herniorrhaphy: Involves repair of a hernia, typically using different types of skin retractors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Joll's thyroid retractor is specifically designed for use in thyroidectomy, helping to provide optimal exposure during the procedure.

questions.text: Identify the shown antibody isotype:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgA

 

  • The image shows two molecules of antibodies joined together by a J chain and a secretory component, which is indicative of secretory IgA.
  • Secretory IgA is primarily found in mucosal areas and secretions such as saliva, tears, and breast milk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgM: IgM is typically found as a pentamer (five antibody units joined together), not as the dimeric structure shown in the image.

 

Option C. IgE: IgE is a monomeric antibody associated with allergic reactions and parasitic infections.

 

Option D. IgG: IgG is the most common antibody in blood and extracellular fluid, but it is a monomer and does not have the dimeric structure shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with generalized lymphadenopathy, skin lesions, and hypercalcemia. He reports a history of intravenous drug use and multiple sexual partners. Laboratory tests reveal elevated white blood cell counts with atypical lymphocytes. Further investigation and serological tests confirm the presence of Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus type 1 (HTLV-1). Which of the following malignancies is most likely caused by HTLV-1?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma

 

  • Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL) is a malignancy caused by Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus type 1 (HTLV-1).
  •  This retrovirus infects T-lymphocytes and can lead to their uncontrolled proliferation.
  • ATLL is characterized by generalized lymphadenopathy, skin lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, lytic bone lesions leading to hypercalcemia, and elevated white blood cell counts with atypical lymphocytes.
