  •  HTLV-1 infection is primarily transmitted through blood transfusion, sexual contact, and from mother to child via breastfeeding. ATLL is most commonly seen in regions where HTLV-1 is endemic, such as Japan, the Caribbean, and parts of Central and South America.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma: This is a rare type of lymphoma associated with chronic inflammation of the gut, often seen in patients with celiac disease. It is not caused by HTLV-1.

 

Option C. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma: This is the most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, originating from B lymphocytes. It is not associated with HTLV-1 infection.

 

Option D. B-cell lymphomas: B-cell lymphomas, in general, are malignancies arising from B lymphocytes and are not caused by HTLV-1. HTLV-1 specifically targets T lymphocytes, leading to T-cell malignancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma is a malignancy caused by HTLV-1, characterized by generalized lymphadenopathy, skin lesions, and hypercalcemia, primarily affecting T lymphocytes.

questions.text: A 34-year-old scientist working on metabolic pathways is focusing on the Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt. He is reviewing the key metabolites involved in this pathway. Which of the following is not a metabolite in the HMP shunt?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycerol-3-phosphate

 

  • The HMP shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway, is a metabolic pathway parallel to glycolysis.
  • It serves two primary functions: the generation of NADPH and the synthesis of ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide biosynthesis.
  • This pathway involves several intermediates, including Sedoheptulose-7-phosphate, Xylulose-5-phosphate, and Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate.
  • However, Glycerol-3-phosphate is not an intermediate in the HMP shunt. Instead, Glycerol-3-phosphate is part of lipid metabolism and glycolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sedoheptulose-7-phosphate: This is a seven-carbon sugar phosphate that is an intermediate in the HMP shunt. It plays a role in the non-oxidative phase of the pathway.

 

Option C. Xylulose-5-phosphate: This is another intermediate in the non-oxidative phase of the HMP shunt. It is involved in the conversion of ribose-5-phosphate and other sugars.

 

Option D. Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate: This three-carbon molecule is also an intermediate in the HMP shunt and glycolysis. It is involved in several metabolic pathways, reflecting its central role in cellular metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glycerol-3-phosphate is not a metabolite in the HMP shunt.

choices.text: Located on the long arm of chromosome 13

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a family history of breast cancer is found to have a BRCA1 mutation. Which of the following characteristics is associated with a BRCA1 mutation compared to a BRCA2 mutation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Associated with medullary carcinoma

 

  • BRCA1 mutations are located on the long arm of chromosome 17 and are associated with poorly differentiated tumors and a triple-negative hormone receptor status (ER/PR-negative, HER2-negative).
  • They are also linked to medullary carcinoma. BRCA2 mutations are located on chromosome 13.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Located on the long arm of chromosome 13: BRCA2 mutations are located on chromosome 13.

 

Option B. Well-differentiated tumors: BRCA1 mutations are associated with poorly-differentiated tumors.

 

Option C. ER/PR-positive hormone receptor status: BRCA1 mutations are ER/PR negative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • BRCA1 mutations are linked to chromosome 17, poorly differentiated tumors, triple-negative status, and medullary carcinoma, while BRCA2 mutations are linked to chromosome 13.

choices.text: Zidovudine is used as monotherapy in post-exposure prophylaxis
Washing hands with soap and water is advised
Baseline viral markers of healthcare personnel should be done at the time of prick
Follow-up viral markers of healthcare personnel should be measured at 6 weeks

questions.text: A nurse at a busy district hospital accidentally sustains a needle-stick injury while treating a patient known to be HIV-positive. The incident occurs during a night shift, and the nurse is immediately concerned about the risk of HIV transmission. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this nurse?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zidovudine is used as monotherapy in post-exposure prophylaxis

 

  • The statement is false. The current recommendation for post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) involves a combination of antiretroviral drugs, typically including tenofovir, lamivudine, and efavirenz, rather than zidovudine alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Washing hands with soap and water is advised: This is true and is an essential immediate action after exposure to potentially infectious material to reduce the risk of infection.

 

Option C. Baseline viral markers of healthcare personnel should be done at the time of prick: This is true. Baseline testing for HIV, hepatitis B (HBsAg), and hepatitis C (HCV) is recommended immediately following the exposure.

 

Option D. Follow-up viral markers of healthcare personnel should be measured at 6 weeks: This is true. Follow-up testing for viral markers should be conducted at 6 weeks, 3 months, and 6 months post-exposure to monitor for seroconversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PEP regimen for HIV include tenofovir, lamivudine and efavirenz (TLE)
  • The first dose need to be given within 2 hours of exposure
  • If source found to be positive or unknown, the PEP need to be continued for 28 days
  • HCW should be tested for viral markers (HBsAg, HCV and HIV) at baseline (time of exposure) and follow-up 6 weeks, 3 months and 6 months after exposure

choices.text: It does not terminate directly into the axillary vein
In the arm, the cephalic vein lies along the lateral side of the biceps brachii
In the Deltopectoral Groove, it is accompanied by the pectoral branch of the thoraco-acromial artery
The cephalic vein lies deep to the roof of the anatomical snuff box

questions.text: A patient is set for total hip replacement surgery, and as part of the preoperative preparation, a venous line is inserted in the anatomical snuff box on the left wrist. Evaluate the following statements regarding this venous access point and identify the incorrect one:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) In the Deltopectoral Groove, it is accompanied by the pectoral branch of the thoraco-acromial artery

 

This statement is incorrect

 

  • In the Deltopectoral Groove, it is accompanied by the pectoral branch of the thoraco-acromial artery this statement is incorrect because, while the cephalic vein does indeed pass through the deltopectoral groove, it is not typically described as being accompanied by the pectoral branch of the thoraco-acromial artery.
  • Instead, in this area, it is generally accompanied by the deltoid branch of the thoracoacromial artery, a distinct branch that supports the deltoid muscle, not the pectoral muscle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It  does not terminat directly into the axillary vein: This statement is incorrect.

 

It pierces the clavipectoral fascia and terminates into the axillary vein.

 

 

Option B. In the arm, the cephalic vein lies along the lateral side of the biceps brachii: It undergoes a spiral course in the radial border of the lower forearm. In front of the elbow, it is connected to the basilic vein by the median cubital vein. In the arm, it runs along the lateral side of the biceps brachii This statement is correct.

 

 

Option D. The cephalic vein lies deep to the roof of the anatomical snuff box: This statement is also correct. The cephalic vein runs deep to the roof of the anatomical snuff box.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cephalic vein is a superficial vein of the upper limb.
  • It runs along the preaxial border of the upper limb.
  • It passes through the deltopectoral groove.
  • It is a significant landmark for certain surgical procedures, running between the deltoid and pectoralis major muscles before it drains into the axillary vein.

choices.text: Lewy body dementia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his wife, who reports a year-long history of the patient's declining memory and cognitive abilities. The patient was previously diagnosed with a type of cortical dementia. Which of the following is NOT classified as a cortical dementia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lewy body dementia.

 

  • Lewy body dementia (LBD) is not classified as a purely cortical dementia.
  • LBD involves both cortical and subcortical brain regions, which distinguishes it from typical cortical dementias.
  •  LBD is characterized by the presence of Lewy bodies (abnormal protein deposits) in the brain and exhibits a mix of symptoms that include cognitive impairment, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonian motor symptoms.
  • The involvement of subcortical structures contributes to the motor and autonomic symptoms seen in LBD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alzheimer's disease: This is the most common form of cortical dementia. Patients with Alzheimer's typically present with memory impairment, especially short-term memory.

 

Option B. Frontotemporal dementia: Another form of cortical dementia. Symptoms may vary but often include personality and behavior changes or language disturbances.

 

Option D. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease: A rare, rapidly progressive form of cortical dementia caused by prions. It leads to severe cognitive impairment, myoclonus, and neurological deficits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lewy body dementia, while involving the cortex, is not purely cortical dementia as it affects both cortical and subcortical structures.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man, who recently recovered from a viral infection, visits his primary care physician for a follow-up. The physician orders a blood test to assess the patient's immune status, specifically focusing on identifying memory T cells, which are crucial for long-term immunity. Which of the following markers will the lab use to identify the memory T cells in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CD45RO

 

  • Memory T cells are a critical component of the adaptive immune system, providing long-term immunity by "remembering" past infections and responding more rapidly upon re-exposure to the same pathogen.
  • The marker CD45RO is specifically used to identify memory T cells.
  • CD45RO is an isoform of the CD45 molecule that is expressed on the surface of memory T cells, distinguishing them from naïve T cells, which express CD45RA.
  •  The presence of CD45RO indicates that the T cell has previously encountered an antigen and has differentiated into a memory cell, ready to mount a quick and effective response upon re-exposure to the antigen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD45RB: CD45RB is another isoform of the CD45 molecule but is not specifically associated with memory T cells. It is found on both naïve and some subsets of effector T cells.

 

Option C. CD45RA: CD45RA is the marker used to identify naïve T cells, which have not yet encountered an antigen. These cells are in a resting state and ready to respond to new infections.

 

Option D. CD45RC: CD45RC is another isoform of the CD45 molecule, but it is not typically used as a marker for distinguishing memory T cells. Its expression pattern is less specific and includes various subsets of T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CD45RO is the marker used to identify memory T cells, indicating they have previously encountered an antigen and can mount a rapid immune response upon re-exposure.

choices.text: Left anterior cerebral artery (ACA) stroke
Left middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke
Right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) stroke

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation experiences sudden left-sided weakness and speech difficulties while having breakfast. Her blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, heart rate is 78 bpm with an irregular rhythm, and she shows right facial droop, non-fluent aphasia, and left hemiplegia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke

 

  • The symptoms of left-sided weakness, right facial droop, expressive aphasia, and left hemiplegia suggest a stroke in the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory.
  • This artery supplies regions responsible for motor control of the face and limbs on the opposite side and speech production areas, including Broca's area in the left hemisphere.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left anterior cerebral artery (ACA) stroke: Left anterior cerebral artery (ACA) stroke usually affects the lower extremity due to its supply areas.

 

Option C. Right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) stroke: Right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) stroke often leads to visual field defects, not motor or speech issues.

 

Option D. Right basilar artery stroke: Right basilar artery stroke would present differently, typically not with expressive aphasia and left hemiplegia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A stroke affecting the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory can present with right facial droop, non-fluent aphasia, and left hemiplegia, as the MCA supplies a large portion of the lateral cerebral hemisphere, including areas responsible for motor control and speech production.

choices.text: Neuronal loss with gliosis in caudate
Loss of pigmented neurons in substantia nigra
Hemosiderosis and gliosis of mammillary bodies

questions.text: A 62-year-old man has had increasing difficulty with voluntary movements due to muscular rigidity. On physical examination, he has difficulty initiating movement, but he can keep moving if he follows someone walking ahead of him. He has an expressionless facies, and when he is sitting, his hands have a “pill-rolling” tremor. Which pathologic finding in the brain is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of pigmented neurons in substantia nigra

 

  • The patient's symptoms, including difficulty with voluntary movements, muscular rigidity, expressionless facies, and “pill-rolling” tremor, are classic signs of Parkinson's disease.
  •  Parkinson's disease is characterized by the degeneration and loss of pigmented neurons in the substantia nigra, a region of the brain that plays a key role in movement control.
  •  This neuronal loss leads to decreased dopamine production, which is critical for smooth and coordinated muscle movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neuronal loss with gliosis in caudate: This finding is more typical of Huntington's disease, which presents with choreiform movements, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms, rather than the rigidity and tremor seen in Parkinson's disease.

 

Option C. Hippocampal neurofibrillary tangles: Neurofibrillary tangles in the hippocampus are a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease, which is characterized by progressive memory loss and cognitive decline, not the motor symptoms seen in Parkinson's disease.

 

Option D. Hemosiderosis and gliosis of mammillary bodies: This finding is associated with Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, typically seen in chronic alcoholism, and presents with symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, rather than the motor symptoms described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Parkinson's disease is characterized by the loss of pigmented neurons in the substantia nigra, leading to symptoms such as muscular rigidity, bradykinesia, expressionless facies, and a “pill-rolling” tremor.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has lived in an orphanage for the past 10 years. He spends most of his day rocking, muttering softly to himself, or looking at his reflection in a mirror. He needs help with bathing and grooming. He often giggles and laughs for no apparent reason. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schizophrenia

 

  • The presentation of the 40-year-old man, who lives in an orphanage and exhibits behaviors such as rocking, muttering to himself, looking at his reflection in a mirror, needing help with daily activities, and inappropriate affect (giggling and laughing for no apparent reason), is most consistent with schizophrenia.
  • Schizophrenia is characterized by positive symptoms (such as hallucinations and delusions), negative symptoms (such as social withdrawal, apathy, and impaired self-care), and cognitive symptoms (such as disorganized thoughts).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delusional disorder: involves development of single or set of related delusions for a month or longer. Hallucinations are usually absent. If hallucinations are present, they have the same content as the delusion. Apart from the direct impact of delusions, the functioning is not markedly impaired.

 

Option C. Schizoaffective disorder: This involves symptoms of schizophrenia and a major mood disorder (depression or mania). The mood symptoms should be present for a majority of the illness. The patient does not have any evident mood symptoms that would suggest this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Bipolar disorder: This is characterized by episodes of mania and potentially depression. Though inappropriate laughter could be misconstrued as manic behavior, the patient lacks other symptoms like increased energy, decreased need for sleep, or grandiosity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Schizophrenia is a chronic psychiatric disorder that has diverse presentations. Symptoms are typically divided into positive (hallucinations, delusions), negative (flat affect, anhedonia, asociality), and cognitive (disorganized thoughts, impaired attention).
  •  Other features may include catatonia, inappropriate affect, and impaired insight. Treatment includes antipsychotic medications.

choices.text: FISH in the peripheral blood smear

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient presents with complaints of fatigue and early satiety. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly. Blood tests show myeloid hyperplasia. Given these findings, what is the next best investigation to be performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) FISH in the peripheral blood smear

 

  • In a patient presenting with splenomegaly and myeloid hyperplasia, the next best investigation is Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH) in the peripheral blood smear.
  • This test is crucial for detecting specific genetic abnormalities associated with myeloproliferative disorders, such as the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL translocation) in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Identifying such genetic markers helps in confirming the diagnosis and guiding appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunophenotyping: Immunophenotyping is used to analyze the types of cells present and their surface markers, which is valuable in diagnosing lymphomas and leukemias. However, it is not the most specific test for myeloid hyperplasia with splenomegaly compared to FISH.

 

Option B. Leucocyte alkaline phosphatase: Leucocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score can help differentiate between CML and a leukemoid reaction. However, it is not as definitive as FISH for diagnosing specific genetic abnormalities.

 

Option D. Bone marrow biopsy: Bone marrow biopsy can provide information about the cellularity and architecture of the bone marrow, which is useful in diagnosing various hematologic disorders. However, it is more invasive and not as specific as FISH for identifying genetic abnormalities in myeloproliferative disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FISH in the peripheral blood smear is the next best investigation for a patient with splenomegaly and myeloid hyperplasia to identify specific genetic abnormalities associated with myeloproliferative disorders.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false
The assertion is false but the reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion: In a patient admitted to the hospital for community-acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta-lactams and azithromycin is given.

 

Reason: This combination covers Gram-positive organisms and anaerobes.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Assertion is true, but the reason is false

 

Explanation:

 

Assertion: The assertion is true. Combination therapy of beta-lactams and azithromycin is commonly given for community-acquired pneumonia to provide broad-spectrum coverage, including atypical pathogens.

 

Reason: The reason is false. The combination of beta-lactams and azithromycin is not primarily aimed at covering Gram-positive organisms and anaerobes. Instead, it provides coverage for typical bacteria (like Streptococcus pneumoniae) with beta-lactams, and atypical pathogens (like Mycoplasma pneumoniae and Chlamydia pneumoniae) with azithromycin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In community-acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta-lactams and azithromycin is given
  • Beta-lactams are used to cover gram-positives like pneumococcus, and azithromycin to cover atypical agents such as Mycoplasma or Chlamydia or Legionella

questions.text: Which of the following is the lethal granuloma of the nose?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stewart's granuloma

 

  • Stewart's granuloma, also known as midline granuloma, is a destructive condition of the nose.
  •  It is also referred to as malignant granuloma or non-healing granuloma.
  • The exact etiology is unknown, but it may be associated with an autoimmune disorder.
  •  Histopathology shows a predominance of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and histiocytes with tissue necrosis in the midline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wegener’s granulomatosis:  A type of vasculitis affecting small and medium-sized vessels, not specific to the nose as a lethal granuloma.

 

Option B. Rhinosporidiosis:  A chronic infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, not typically presenting as a lethal granuloma.

 

Option C. Lupus:  An autoimmune disease affecting multiple organs, not specifically presenting as a lethal granuloma of the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Stewart's granuloma is a lethal granuloma of the nose characterized by midline tissue necrosis, often requiring surgical debridement and radiotherapy for treatment.

choices.text: Avoidance of bag of mask ventilation
Defect is in the left posterior aspect of diaphragm
Mortality occurs due to pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension
Surgical repair is performed immediately at diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a feature of Bochdalek hernia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Surgical repair is performed immediately at diagnosis

 

  • Bochdalek hernia commonly involves herniation of abdominal viscera the posterolateral defect in the diaphragm.
  • Surgical repair is performed after 2-3 days after stabilising the respiratory status, and not immediately.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avoidance of bag of mask ventilation: Bag and mask ventilation is avoided as the swallowed air will worsen the herniation of stomach.

 

Option B. Defect is in the left posterior aspect of diaphragm: This is the correct location of defect.

 

Option C. Mortality occurs due to pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension: Mortality occurs due to compression of ipsilateral lung leading to hypoplasia and pulmonary artery hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bochdalek hernia is a congenital left posterior diaphragmatic defect, requiring surgery after stabilising the lung function of the neonate.

choices.text: The most common primary thyroid malignancy is papillary carcinoma.
Follicular carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy associated with lymphatic spread.
Medullary carcinoma is associated with MEN 2 syndrome.
Anaplastic carcinoma is the most aggressive thyroid malignancy with the worst prognosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding thyroid malignancies?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follicular carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy associated with lymphatic spread.

 

  • Papillary carcinoma is the most common primary thyroid malignancy and is also the most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation exposure and lymphatic spread.
  • Follicular carcinoma is known for its association with blood and bone metastasis and is most common in iodine-deficient areas.
  • Medullary carcinoma is associated with MEN 2 syndrome and amyloid deposits.
  • Anaplastic carcinoma is the most aggressive thyroid malignancy with the worst prognosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The most common primary thyroid malignancy is papillary carcinoma: Correct. Papillary carcinoma is the most common primary thyroid malignancy.

 

Option C. Medullary carcinoma is associated with MEN 2 syndrome: Correct. Medullary carcinoma is associated with MEN 2 syndrome.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma is the most aggressive thyroid malignancy with the worst prognosis: Correct. Anaplastic carcinoma is the most aggressive thyroid malignancy with the worst prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy, known for its association with radiation and lymphatic spread.
  • Follicular carcinoma is associated with blood and bone metastasis, medullary carcinoma with MEN 2 syndrome, and anaplastic carcinoma with the worst prognosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old postmenopausal woman with a history of hormone receptor (HR)-positive metastatic breast cancer presents to the oncology clinic for follow-up. Her oncologist decides to initiate a treatment that works as an estrogen receptor antagonist by promoting receptor downregulation. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fulvestrant

 

  • Fulvestrant is an estrogen receptor antagonist used for the treatment of hormone receptor (HR)-positive metastatic breast cancer in postmenopausal women.
  • It works by binding to the estrogen receptor and promoting its downregulation, thus blocking the estrogen signaling that drives the growth of HR-positive breast cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mifepristone: Incorrect. Mifepristone is a progesterone receptor antagonist used for medical termination of pregnancy and Cushing's syndrome, not for HR-positive metastatic breast cancer.

 

Option C. Estradiol: Incorrect. Estradiol is a form of estrogen used in hormone replacement therapy (HRT) and is not indicated for treating HR-positive metastatic breast cancer.

 

Option D. Tamoxifen:  Incorrect. Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used to treat HR-positive breast cancer, but it works differently from Fulvestrant by blocking estrogen receptors without promoting their degradation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fulvestrant is specifically used to treat hormone receptor (HR)-positive metastatic breast cancer in postmenopausal women by promoting the downregulation of estrogen receptors and inhibiting estrogen signaling.

choices.text: Delivery should be ideally performed in a lithotomy position
Maintain continuous deflexion of the head
A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum
Episiotomy should be performed as a routine

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman in active labor is in the second stage and experiencing perineal discomfort. According to WHO guidelines on the management of labor, which of the following is an appropriate measure to prevent perineal trauma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum

 

  • The WHO guidelines on the management of the second stage of labor recommend the application of a warm cloth to the perineum to help prevent perineal trauma.
  • This practice helps to soften and stretch the perineal tissues, reducing the risk of tears during delivery.
  • Warm compresses provide comfort and facilitate the natural stretching of the perineum, which can lead to fewer perineal injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delivery should be ideally performed in a lithotomy position: The WHO guidelines do not specify that delivery should be performed in a lithotomy position. They encourage allowing the woman to choose the position she finds most comfortable, which could include upright, lateral, or squatting positions. The lithotomy position is not specifically recommended as the ideal position for delivery.

 

Option B. Maintain continuous deflexion of the head: The guidelines do not advocate for maintaining continuous deflexion of the head during labor. Proper support and guidance during crowning are important, but continuous deflexion is not emphasized in the guidelines.

 

Option D. Episiotomy should be performed as a routine: The WHO guidelines advise against the routine use of episiotomy. Episiotomy should only be performed when clinically indicated, such as in cases of fetal distress or when there is a need to expedite delivery. Routine episiotomies are not recommended as they can lead to unnecessary maternal trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The WHO recommends applying a warm cloth to the perineum during the second stage of labor to help prevent perineal trauma.

choices.text: Adrenal incidentaloma with a size >4 cm

questions.text: When is a unilateral adrenalectomy advised?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adrenal incidentaloma with a size >4 cm

 

  • Unilateral adrenalectomy is typically advised in cases of adrenal incidentaloma when the tumor size exceeds 4 cm.
  • This approach is taken due to the increased risk of malignancy in larger adrenal masses.
  • The decision to perform a unilateral adrenalectomy is based on the size of the tumor and the potential for autonomous hormone secretion, which could negatively impact the patient's health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral ACTH-independent disease: This condition usually warrants bilateral adrenalectomy rather than unilateral.

 

Option B. Ectopic ACTH-dependent Cushing's Syndrome: This condition also typically requires a different treatment approach, often involving bilateral adrenalectomy.

 

Option C. Irresectable or unlocalized primary tumor: This scenario may not be suitable for unilateral adrenalectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Unilateral adrenalectomy is recommended for adrenal incidentalomas larger than 4 cm due to the higher risk of malignancy in such masses.

questions.text: During a clinical examination of a neurology patient, a discussion arises about the role of various thalamic nuclei in brain connectivity. Which of the following thalamic nuclei is known not to project directly to the neocortex?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reticular nuclei

 

  • The reticular nuclei of the thalamus are unique among thalamic nuclei because they do not project to the neocortex.
  • Instead, they are involved in the modulation of activity across other thalamic nuclei by forming inhibitory synapses with them.
  • This modulation is crucial for regulating thalamocortical rhythms and overall cortical activity, playing a significant role in attention and arousal mechanisms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior thalamic nuclei: Incorrect. The anterior thalamic nuclei are part of the limbic thalamus and project to the cingulate cortex, thus directly influencing neocortical functions related to emotions and memory.

 

Option B.  Pulvinar nuclei: Incorrect. The pulvinar nuclei are involved in sensory integration and attention processes, projecting extensively to the association areas of the neocortex, thereby influencing a range of sensory and cognitive processes.

 

Option D. Intralaminar nuclei: Incorrect. The intralaminar nuclei project to wide areas of the cerebral cortex and are implicated in consciousness and alertness. They facilitate the integration of sensory and motor pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The reticular nuclei of the thalamus do not project directly to the neocortex but play a crucial role in modulating the activity of other thalamic nuclei and regulating thalamocortical rhythms.
  • This unique feature distinguishes them from other thalamic nuclei, which typically have direct cortical projections.

questions.text: A 45-year-old men presents with chronic, warty cutaneous lesions on his lower extremities that have gradually worsened over several years. He reports a history of minor skin trauma while working. Histopathological examination of a skin biopsy reveals the presence of the structures shown in the image below. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chromoblastomycosis

 

  • The image shows Medlar bodies, also known as "copper pennies" or "sclerotic bodies," which are characteristic of chromoblastomycosis.
  • This condition is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue often seen in individuals with a history of skin trauma in tropical or subtropical regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sporotrichosis: Sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii, typically presents with nodular and ulcerative lesions along lymphatic channels, but does not feature Medlar bodies.

 

Option C. Mycetoma: Mycetoma is a chronic granulomatous infection characterized by the presence of granules, but not Medlar bodies.

 

Option D. Candidiasis: Candidiasis is caused by Candida species and typically affects mucosal surfaces and skin without producing Medlar bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Medlar bodies are characteristic feature of Chromoblastomycosis; characterized by formation of brown thick walled round cells (5–12 μm size) with multiple internal transverse septa.
  • They are also called Medlar bodies or muriform cells or golden-brown septate or copper pennies

choices.text: Straightening of the fetal axis
Resistance from the pelvic floor

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in active labor presents to the labor and delivery unit. The obstetrician discusses the factors that facilitate the descent of the baby's head through the birth canal during labor with the junior residents. So, which of the following factors does not aid in the descent of the presenting part during labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Resistance from the pelvic floor

 

  • Resistance from the pelvic floor does not help in the descent of the presenting part during labor; rather, it provides an opposing force that the fetus must overcome to progress through the birth canal.
  • This resistance can slow down labor and sometimes necessitates interventions to facilitate the descent and delivery of the fetus.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Uterine contraction and retraction: Uterine contractions are the primary force driving the fetus downward and outward during labor. Retraction helps in thinning and dilating the cervix, which facilitates fetal descent.

 

Option B. Straightening of the fetal axis: This refers to the alignment of the fetal body, which optimizes the position for passage through the pelvis and aids in effective descent.

 

Option C. Bearing down efforts: These are voluntary maternal efforts during the second stage of labor that aid in pushing the fetus down the birth canal, complementing uterine contractions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Resistance from the pelvic floor does not aid in the descent of the presenting part during labor; instead, it provides an opposing force that must be overcome.

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary defect in Paget’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoclast

 

PAGET’S DISEASE

 

  • It is characterized by excessive, disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation.
  • It is the osteoclast that appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. 
  • The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular, and larger (deforms and fractures) than pre-existing bone which leads to cortical widening and contributes to the deformity.
  • Thus, it is the osteoclast cells that have the primary defect in the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoblast: Osteoblasts are bone-forming cells responsible for synthesizing and depositing new bone tissue. In Paget's disease, osteoblast activity is increased as a compensatory response to the excessive bone resorption by osteoclasts. Osteoblasts attempt to repair the bone by laying down new bone tissue, leading to the characteristic mixed pattern of bone formation and resorption seen in Paget's disease.

 

Option C. Osteocyte: Osteocytes are mature bone cells embedded in the bone matrix and are responsible for maintaining bone tissue. They communicate with osteoblasts and osteoclasts to regulate bone remodelling. While osteocytes may be affected indirectly in Paget's disease due to the changes in bone structure and remodelling, they are not the primary defect.

 

Option D. Fibroblast: Fibroblasts are a type of cell found in connective tissue and are involved in producing collagen and extracellular matrix components. They are not directly related to bone metabolism or the pathology of Paget's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Paget’s disease, the primary defect occurs in the osteoclast cells of the bone which encompasses excessive activity of these cells, leading to disorganised excessive new bone formation.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conjugation

 

  • The figure shows the transfer of a transposon from a donor cell to a recipient cell through a direct cell-to-cell connection.
  • This process is known as conjugation. Conjugation involves the transfer of genetic material, often in the form of plasmids, between bacteria through a pilus or mating bridge. This mechanism is a common way for drug resistance genes to spread among bacterial populations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transformation: Incorrect. Transformation involves the uptake of free DNA from the environment by a bacterial cell. It does not require direct cell-to-cell contact.

 

Option C. Transduction: Incorrect. Transduction involves the transfer of genetic material from one bacterium to another via a bacteriophage (virus). It does not involve direct cell-to-cell contact.

 

Option D. Mutation: Incorrect. Mutation refers to changes in the DNA sequence within a single organism. It does not involve the transfer of genetic material between cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods of horizontal transfer of drug resistance

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a known diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis presents with new-onset dyspnea and a non-productive cough. On physical examination, you note fine inspiratory crackles at the lung bases. CT Chest is as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely pulmonary complication in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interstitial lung disease

 

  • Interstitial lung disease is a common pulmonary manifestation of RA and aligns with the patient's symptoms, physical examination findings, and diagnostic test results.
  • ILD in the context of RA presents with dyspnea, a dry cough, bilateral interstitial infiltrates on imaging, and a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function testing.
  • The CT scan also shows features s/o Interstitial lung disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchiectasis: It is characterized by chronic productive cough, recurrent respiratory infections, and on imaging, shows dilated airways with thickened walls.

 

Option B. Pulmonary nodules: It can occur in patients with RA, often manifesting as rheumatoid nodules within the lungs. These nodules are usually asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on imaging. They do not typically present with the restrictive pattern seen on pulmonary function tests or with the specific symptoms and findings described in this case.

 

Option D. Pleural effusion: It can occur in patients with RA but typically presents with dyspnea and dullness to percussion at the lung bases on physical examination. The chest radiograph would show a fluid level rather than interstitial infiltrates, and pulmonary function tests would show a restrictive pattern but not specifically reduced diffusion capacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with rheumatoid arthritis presenting with dyspnea, a non-productive cough, and bilateral interstitial infiltrates, interstitial lung disease is the most likely pulmonary complication, characterized by a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests and reduced diffusion capacity.

questions.text: A patient was started on anticoagulant therapy for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The next day, he presented with the features shown in the figure below. Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Warfarin

 

  • The image shows extensive bruising and skin necrosis, which is a known complication of warfarin therapy.
  •  Warfarin-induced skin necrosis typically occurs within the first few days of therapy due to a transient hypercoagulable state.
  • This condition results from the rapid decline in protein C levels, a natural anticoagulant, before the anticoagulant effects of warfarin are fully established.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heparin: Incorrect. Heparin-induced complications typically include heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), which does not present with skin necrosis as shown in the image.

 

Option C. Rivaroxaban: Incorrect. Rivaroxaban is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) that inhibits factor Xa. It is less likely to cause the skin necrosis seen in the image.

 

Option D. Dabigatran: Incorrect. Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor and is also less likely to cause the skin necrosis shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Warfarin can cause skin necrosis as a rare but serious side effect, typically occurring within the first few days of therapy due to a transient hypercoagulable state.
  • Recognizing this complication is important for prompt management and discontinuation of the drug.

questions.text: Research associate from a Public Health Institute is developing a new questionnaire to assess the quality of life among rural populations. To ensure the reliability of this questionnaire, the researcher uses Cronbach's alpha. What does Cronbach's alpha measure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal consistency

 

  • Internal consistency: Cronbach's alpha is a measure of internal consistency, which assesses the extent to which all items in a test measure the same concept or construct and are thus related to each other.
  • It is an indicator of the reliability of a scale.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Criterion validity: This refers to the extent to which a measure is related to an outcome. It is not measured by Cronbach's alpha.

 

Option C.  Values are between 1 and 100: This is incorrect because Cronbach's alpha values range between 0 and 1.

 

Option D. Content validity: This refers to the extent to which a measure represents all facets of a given construct. Cronbach's alpha does not measure content validity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cronbach’s alpha (Syn. Coefficient alpha, Guttman’s lambda 3, Hoyt method, KR-20)

 

  • A measure of Internal consistency, that is, how closely related a set of items are as a group
  • It is considered to be a measure of scale reliability
  • Value lies between 0 to +1: Higher the alpha coefficient, the more the items have shared covariance and probably measure the same underlying concept (Internal consistency)
  • Interpretation: + 0.7 or more is considered satisfactory.

choices.text: It can cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB)
Paramagnetic material which can shorten the T1 relaxation time
Long-term studies show gadolinium deposition in the basal ganglia at high doses

questions.text: During a radiology department seminar, a discussion focuses on the properties and safety of gadolinium-based contrast agents. Which of the following statements about gadolinium is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It can cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB)

 

  • This statement is false because gadolinium-based contrast agents, when properly chelated, do not typically cross the intact blood-brain barrier.
  • The use of gadolinium is common in MRI studies because it does not normally cross into brain tissue unless there is a disruption in the blood-brain barrier, such as from inflammation, infection, or tumors, which then can be highlighted by the contrast agent due to this breakdown.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Paramagnetic material which can shorten the T1 relaxation time : Correct. Gadolinium is a paramagnetic material, which means it can enhance the relaxation rates of water protons in its vicinity, particularly shortening the T1 relaxation time, thereby improving the contrast of MRI images.

 

Option C. Long-term studies show gadolinium deposition in the basal ganglia at high doses: - Correct. Recent studies and findings have indicated that gadolinium, despite being chelated, can deposit in brain tissues such as the basal ganglia, especially after multiple high doses, raising concerns about potential long-term effects.

 

Option. D: Injected as gadolinium chelates - Correct. Gadolinium is toxic in its free form and is therefore used in chelated form for medical imaging to reduce toxicity while allowing it to function as an effective MRI contrast agent.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Gadolinium-based contrast agents do not normally cross the intact blood-brain barrier, a key point in understanding their use and safety profile in clinical imaging.

questions.text: A young boy presents with staining of the teeth and an elevated level of Coproporphyrin-I. He also has an increased risk of photosensitivity. Given these clinical features, the underlying condition involves a deficiency in a specific enzyme in the heme biosynthesis pathway. Which enzyme deficiency is associated with his staining of teeth, raised Coproporphyrin-I levels, and increased risk of photosensitivity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Uroporphyrinogen III Synthase

 

  • The clinical presentation of teeth staining, elevated Coproporphyrin-I levels, and photosensitivity is characteristic of congenital erythropoietic porphyria (CEP), also known as Günther's disease.
  • CEP results from a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen III synthase.
  • This enzyme is essential in the heme biosynthesis pathway, catalyzing the conversion of hydroxymethylbilane to uroporphyrinogen III.
  • When this enzyme is deficient, there is an accumulation of uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I, which leads to the symptoms of photosensitivity, severe cutaneous lesions, and staining of teeth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uroporphyrinogen Synthase: Deficiency in this enzyme leads to acute intermittent porphyria, which presents with acute neurovisceral attacks rather than photosensitivity and teeth staining.

 

Option C. Uroporphyrinogen Decarboxylase: Deficiency in this enzyme causes porphyria cutanea tarda, characterized by blistering photosensitivity and elevated uroporphyrin levels, but it does not typically result in teeth staining.

 

Option D. Coproporphyrinogen Oxidase: Deficiency in this enzyme leads to hereditary coproporphyria, presenting with neurovisceral symptoms and photosensitivity, but it does not primarily cause elevated Coproporphyrin-I levels or teeth staining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (CEP) is caused by a deficiency in uroporphyrinogen III synthase, leading to symptoms such as teeth staining, elevated Coproporphyrin-I levels, and increased risk of photosensitivity.

questions.text: A 5-day post-operative patient on intravenous fluids presents with angular stomatitis. Laboratory tests show an abnormally low urinary excretion of 15 µg riboflavin/mg creatinine. Which of the following TCA cycle enzymes is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Succinate dehydrogenase

 

  • Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is a crucial component of flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), which are coenzymes for various oxidative reactions in the body.
  • A deficiency in riboflavin can lead to reduced activity of enzymes that require these coenzymes.
  • Succinate dehydrogenase is a key enzyme in the TCA cycle and the electron transport chain, requiring FAD as a coenzyme to catalyze the oxidation of succinate to fumarate.
  • Therefore, riboflavin deficiency can impair the function of succinate dehydrogenase, leading to metabolic disturbances that may manifest as symptoms such as angular stomatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malate dehydrogenase: This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of malate to oxaloacetate in the TCA cycle and does not directly require FAD or FMN. Therefore, its function is less likely to be impacted by riboflavin deficiency.

 

Option B. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: This enzyme catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of isocitrate to α-ketoglutarate in the TCA cycle and requires NAD+ as a coenzyme, not FAD or FMN. Thus, it is not directly affected by riboflavin deficiency.

 

Option D. Fumarase: This enzyme catalyzes the reversible hydration of fumarate to malate in the TCA cycle and does not require FAD or FMN as coenzymes. Hence, its function is not dependent on riboflavin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Riboflavin deficiency affects enzymes that require FAD or FMN as coenzymes, such as succinate dehydrogenase in the TCA cycle.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to your clinic seeking advice on contraceptive options. Out of which of the following condition is the absolute contraindication for prescribing normal contraceptive pills?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital hyperlipidemia

 

  • Women with congenital hyperlipidemia are at an increased risk for cardiovascular events when taking normal contraceptive pills.
  • This condition significantly increases the risk of severe side effects such as thromboembolic events, making it an absolute contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epilepsy: While epilepsy is a condition that requires careful management, it is the relative contraindication for normal contraceptive pills. Some antiepileptic drugs can interact with contraceptive pills, but they can often be managed with adjustments.

 

Option B. Diabetes mellitus: Women with well-controlled diabetes mellitus can usually take normal contraceptive pills. However, caution is advised, especially if there are complications such as vascular disease.

 

Option C.  Mild hypertension: Mild hypertension requires monitoring and management, but it is a relative contraindication for the use of normal contraceptive pills. However, women with severe or uncontrolled hypertension should avoid these pills.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contraindications for use of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs):

choices.text: It is a part of Input-Output analysis
It is visualized in a graphical representation of all events/activities carried out
It is the longest path of the network
Any delay in the Critical Path delays the whole project

questions.text: A project manager is using the Critical Path Method (CPM) to plan the rollout of a new vaccination program in multiple rural districts across India. All of the following statements are true regarding the CPM, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a part of Input-Output analysis

 

  • This is incorrect.
  • The Critical Path Method (CPM) is a project management tool used to schedule project activities, not a part of Input-Output analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is visualized in a graphical representation of all events/activities carried out: This is correct. CPM involves creating a visual representation, often a flowchart, of all tasks and their dependencies.

 

Option C. It is the longest path of the network: This is correct. The critical path represents the longest sequence of tasks that determines the shortest possible project duration.

 

Option D. Any delay in the Critical Path delays the whole project: This is correct. Any delay in activities on the critical path directly impacts the project completion date.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Critical Path Method (CPM) is a project management tool that identifies the longest sequence of dependent tasks and is visualized in a graphical representation.
  • Delays in the critical path affect the entire project's timeline.
  • It is not part of Input-Output analysis.

choices.text: It is slower acting than clopidogrel
Due to a higher risk of bleeding, prasugrel is contraindicated in stroke
It is a reversible antagonist of ADP receptors
It is effective orally unlike clopidogrel

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease is being evaluated for antiplatelet therapy. His physician is considering switching him from clopidogrel to prasugrel. Which of the following statements about prasugrel is true as compared to clopidogrel?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Due to a higher risk of bleeding, prasugrel is contraindicated in stroke.

 

  • Prasugrel is an irreversible antagonist of ADP receptors (P2Y12) on platelets, similar to clopidogrel.
  • However, prasugrel is generally considered faster acting and more potent than clopidogrel.
  •  Due to its higher potency, prasugrel carries a higher risk of bleeding, which makes it contraindicated in patients with a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is slower acting than clopidogrel: Incorrect. Prasugrel is actually faster acting and more potent than clopidogrel.

 

Option C. It is a reversible antagonist of ADP receptors: Incorrect. Both prasugrel and clopidogrel are irreversible antagonists of ADP receptors.

 

Option D. It is effective orally unlike clopidogrel: Incorrect. Both prasugrel and clopidogrel are effective when administered orally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prasugrel is a potent antiplatelet agent that is faster acting and carries a higher risk of bleeding compared to clopidogrel.
  •  Due to this increased bleeding risk, prasugrel is contraindicated in patients with a history of stroke or TIA.

choices.text: Distal to origin of chorda tympani
Between second genu and midportion of vertical segment
Distal to geniculate ganglion and proximal to second genu

questions.text: Lesion at which point along the course of the facial nerve would lead to loss of lacrimation and taste?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proximal to geniculate ganglion

 

  • A lesion proximal to the geniculate ganglion affects the greater superficial petrosal nerve, which carries secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland, and the chorda tympani, which carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • This results in loss of lacrimation and taste.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Distal to the origin of chorda tympani: would not affect lacrimation.

 

Option B. Between second genu and midportion of vertical segment: would primarily affect the nerve to stapedius.

 

Option C. Distal to geniculate ganglion and proximal to second genu: would not affect lacrimation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A lesion proximal to the geniculate ganglion leads to loss of lacrimation and taste due to involvement of the greater superficial petrosal nerve and chorda tympani.

choices.text: Removal with a 26 gauge needle

questions.text: A 25-year-old male, who works as a welder, visits the emergency department with complaints of eye pain, redness, and a sensation of something being in his eye since this morning. Examination reveals an iron foreign body embedded in the cornea, consistent with his occupational exposure. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Removal with a 26 gauge needle

 

  • The best initial management for an impacted ferrous foreign body in the cornea, particularly in a welder, is -
    • Removal with a 26 gauge needle: This technique involves using the needle with the bevel pointing away from the cornea to carefully extract the foreign body.
    • This method minimizes the risk of pushing the foreign body deeper into the corneal layers and prevents complications such as secondary infection and potential corneal ulceration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty: This surgical procedure is not indicated in this scenario as it is used for deeper corneal diseases and is not a first-line treatment for superficial foreign bodies.

 

Option B. Topical antibiotics and steroids: Should be administered post-removal to prevent secondary infection. However, steroids are not recommended initially as they can impair epithelial healing.

 

Option D. Copious saline irrigation: While important for flushing out any loose particles, it is insufficient alone for an embedded ferrous foreign body and should be used adjunctively to ensure all residual particles are removed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prompt and careful removal of an embedded corneal foreign body in a welder is crucial to prevent further ocular damage and complications.
  • Following the extraction, appropriate antibiotic therapy should be initiated to prevent infection, and careful monitoring of the healing process is essential.

choices.text: The tibial nerve lies posterolateral to the flexor hallucis longus tendon
The heel pain is due to injury to the medial plantar nerve
The flexor retinaculum forms the medial wall of the tarsal tunnel
The medial malleolus lies in front of the tunnel

questions.text: A 41-year-old man has been experiencing progressive intermittent pain and a burning sensation in his right foot for the last two months, which extends from the medial malleolus along the plantar surface to the toes, including heel pain. Symptoms worsen with prolonged standing and walking. Identify the incorrect statement about the possible anatomical implications related to his condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The heel pain is due to injury to the medial plantar nerve

 

  • The heel pain is due to injury to the medial plantar nerve, this statement is incorrect as heel pain in the context described, particularly in relation to tarsal tunnel syndrome symptoms, is more commonly associated with injury or compression of the tibial nerve rather than specifically the medial plantar nerve.
  • The tibial nerve branches into the medial and lateral plantar nerves within the tarsal tunnel, and while these nerves can contribute to foot pain, primary heel pain is typically more directly linked to issues with the tibial nerve itself or its branches collectively rather than one specific branch.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  The tibial nerve lies posterolateral to the flexor hallucis longus tendon:  This is correct. In the anatomical arrangement within the tarsal tunnel, the tibial nerve is positioned posterolateral to the flexor hallucis longus tendon, one of the key anatomical landmarks for identifying nerve relationships in this area.

 

Option C. The flexor retinaculum forms the medial wall of the tarsal tunnel - This is correct. The flexor retinaculum is a fibrous band that spans over the foot's medial side, forming the medial wall of the tarsal tunnel and serving as a protective and supportive structure for the structures passing underneath it.

 

Option D. The medial malleolus lies in front of the tunnel:  This is correct. The medial malleolus actually forms part of the tarsal tunnel's structure, located on the inner aspect of the ankle. It acts as a bony landmark for the tarsal tunnel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Heel pain related to nerve issues in the foot is most commonly due to broader involvement of the tibial nerve or general inflammation/compression within the tarsal tunnel, rather than specific injury to the medial plantar nerve.

choices.text: It increases skin thickness, making it difficult to find a site for injectable drugs
It increases the metabolism of oral hypoglycemic agents

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus is under evaluation for hyperlipidemia treatment. His endocrinologist is considering the addition of niacin to his regimen. Given his diabetic condition, the use of niacin requires caution. What is the primary reason for this precaution?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It impairs insulin sensitivity

 

  • Niacin, also known as vitamin B3, is frequently used in the treatment of hyperlipidemia due to its beneficial effects on high-density lipoprotein (HDL) levels.
  • However, in patients with diabetes, niacin can exacerbate glucose control. The mechanism involves niacin's effect on insulin resistance; it reduces the efficacy of insulin in promoting glucose uptake by tissues, thereby impairing insulin sensitivity.
  • This effect can lead to higher fasting blood glucose levels and a potential worsening of glycemic control, which is a significant concern in diabetes management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It causes hypoglycemia: Incorrect. Niacin is more likely to cause hyperglycemia rather than hypoglycemia in diabetic patients by impairing glucose regulation.

 

Option C. It increases skin thickness, making it difficult to find a site for injectable drugs: Incorrect. This is not a recognized side effect of niacin and has no basis in the clinical management of diabetes.

 

Option D. It increases the metabolism of oral hypoglycemic agents: Incorrect. While drug interactions are a concern with any medication, niacin’s primary issue in diabetes is its impact on insulin resistance rather than altering the metabolism of other diabetic medications.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Niacin can result in insulin resistance and hyperglycemia, thus should be avoided in diabetic patients.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has been experiencing recurrent miscarriages. Upon visiting the clinic, a transvaginal ultrasound (USG) is performed, revealing the presence of a septate uterus. What is the best management option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transcervical resection of septum

 

  • Transcervical resection of the septum is the recommended treatment for a septate uterus, which is a congenital uterine anomaly characterized by a fibrous or muscular septum dividing the uterine cavity.
  • This condition is often associated with recurrent pregnancy loss.
  • The resection procedure is performed hysteroscopically, which is minimally invasive and allows for the direct visualization and removal of the septum.
  • This intervention has been shown to improve reproductive outcomes, reducing the risk of miscarriage and increasing the chances of a successful pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tompkins metroplasty: This procedure is primarily used to correct bicornuate uterus, not a septate uterus. It involves an abdominal approach to unify the two uterine cavities but is more invasive and not indicated for septate uterus.

 

Option C. Johns metroplasty: Similar to Tompkins metroplasty, Johns metroplasty is another surgical technique aimed at correcting bicornuate uterus. It is not applicable to septate uterus as the anatomical defect differs.

 

Option D. Strassman metroplasty: This is a surgical procedure designed for the treatment of bicornuate uterus by uniting the two uterine horns. It is not indicated for septate uterus, which requires the removal of the septum rather than unification of the uterine cavities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The best management for a septate uterus, which is associated with recurrent miscarriages, is transcervical resection of the septum.

questions.text: A patient has difficulty in breathing. On examination, there is unilateral lengthening of the vocal cord in the adducted position. The patient is not able to abduct the vocal cord. Which of the following muscles is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior cricoarytenoid

 

  • The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is the only muscle responsible for abducting the vocal cords.
  • It is innervated by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
  •  Dysfunction or paralysis of this muscle results in the inability to abduct the vocal cords, leading to the symptoms described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroarytenoid: This muscle acts as an adductor and tensor of the vocal cords, not an abductor.

 

Option C. Cricothyroid: This muscle is involved in tension and elongation of the vocal cords but does not abduct them.

 

Option D. Interarytenoid: This muscle acts as an adductor of the vocal cords.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The posterior cricoarytenoid is the only muscle that abducts the vocal cords.
  •  Its paralysis leads to the inability to abduct the vocal cords, resulting in difficulty breathing and lengthening of the vocal cords in the adducted position.

choices.text: Deep cervical fascia

questions.text: During surgical access to the brachial plexus, a surgeon must navigate through various layers of fascia. Identifying the correct fascial layer that envelops the nerve bundles of the brachial plexus is crucial for avoiding iatrogenic injury. Which of the following fasciae is the source of the sheath that surrounds the brachial plexus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prevertebral fascia

 

  • The fascia around the nerve bundles of the brachial plexus, crucial for safe surgical navigation, is derived from the prevertebral fascia.
  • This specific layer of deep cervical fascia extends laterally to form the axillary sheath, which provides a protective covering around the brachial plexus and associated vascular structures as they pass from the neck into the upper limb.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectoral fascia: Incorrect. This fascia primarily covers the pectoralis major muscle and is not involved in surrounding the brachial plexus.

 

Option B. Deep cervical fascia: Partially correct, but too broad. The deep cervical fascia includes several distinct layers, and the specific layer responsible for encasing the brachial plexus is the prevertebral fascia.

 

Option C.  Clavipectoral fascia: Incorrect. While important in the pectoral region for covering the subclavius and pectoralis minor muscles, the clavipectoral fascia does not extend to form the sheath around the brachial plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The prevertebral fascia, as part of the deep cervical fascia, extends to form the axillary sheath that encloses the brachial plexus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with weight loss, abdominal pain, and jaundice. Imaging reveals a mass in the head of the pancreas. Which of the following hormonal tumor markers is most commonly elevated in pancreatic cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CA 19-9 (carbohydrate antigen 19-9)

 

  • CA 19-9 (carbohydrate antigen 19-9) is a tumor marker commonly used in the diagnosis and monitoring of pancreatic cancer.
  • It is elevated in approximately 70-90% of patients with pancreatic cancer, particularly in those with advanced disease.
  • However, it is important to note that CA 19-9 is not specific for pancreatic cancer and can be elevated in other conditions, such as bile duct obstruction, liver disease, and other gastrointestinal cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AFP (alpha-fetoprotein): It is a tumor marker associated with liver cancer (hepatocellular carcinoma) and some germ cell tumors.

 

Option B. hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin): It is a tumor marker associated with gestational trophoblastic disease and some germ cell tumors.

 

Option D. IGF-1 (insulin-like growth factor 1): It is usually elevated in patients with acromegaly

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CA 19-9 is the tumor marker most commonly elevated in pancreatic cancer, used for diagnosis and monitoring the disease progression.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman undergoes a minor elective laparoscopic procedure as part of a day-care surgery. Considering the need for rapid postoperative recovery and minimal residual sedation, which opioid is most suitable for intraoperative analgesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Remifentanil

 

  • Remifentanil has a rapid onset and extremely short duration of action due to its rapid metabolism by plasma esterases.
  • This makes it ideal for day-care surgeries where quick patient recovery and discharge are necessary.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Sufentanil: Incorrect. Although sufentanil is potent and has a rapid onset, it has a longer duration of action than remifentanil, which may not be ideal for day-care surgery due to prolonged sedation.

 

Option C. Morphine: Incorrect. Morphine has a longer duration of action and can lead to postoperative sedation and respiratory depression, which are not desirable in a day-care setting.

 

Option D. Butorphanol: Incorrect. Butorphanol can cause sedation and has a longer duration of action compared to remifentanil, making it less favorable for short procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For day-care surgeries, remifentanil is the opioid of choice due to its ultra-short-acting properties, which allow for a rapid recovery and minimal postoperative sedation, enabling patients to be discharged sooner.

choices.text: Perform ultrasound assessment including MCA-PSV
Give steroid cover and deliver

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, G2A1, at 28 weeks gestation with blood type B negative, has an Indirect Coombs Test (ICT) result of 1:32. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perform ultrasound assessment including MCA-PSV

 

  • An ICT titer of 1:32 indicates a significant level of alloimmunization, suggesting that the fetus may be at risk for hemolytic disease.
  • The next best step is to perform an ultrasound assessment, including the measurement of the middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA-PSV). MCA-PSV is a non-invasive method used to assess fetal anemia.
  • An increased MCA-PSV is indicative of fetal anemia, which helps guide further management, including the timing of delivery or the need for intrauterine transfusion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give steroid cover and deliver: While steroid administration may be considered to promote fetal lung maturity if early delivery is anticipated, immediate delivery at 28 weeks without assessing the severity of fetal anemia is premature. The priority is to evaluate the fetal condition via ultrasound.

 

Option C. Repeat ICT after 2 weeks: Repeating the ICT may provide additional information about the progression of alloimmunization but does not directly assess the current status of the fetus. An immediate ultrasound assessment is more crucial to determine the need for urgent intervention.

 

Option D. Perform intrauterine transfusion: Intrauterine transfusion is indicated if significant fetal anemia is confirmed by ultrasound assessment, including MCA-PSV. It is not the immediate next step without confirming the severity of fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a pregnant woman with a significant ICT titer (1:32) indicating potential fetal anemia, the next best step is to perform an ultrasound assessment, including MCA-PSV, to evaluate the severity of anemia and guide further management.

choices.text: Double the current PEEP setting
Start inhaled nitric oxide therapy

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with severe ARDS secondary to influenza pneumonia is intubated and mechanically ventilated with high FiO2 and PEEP but has a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 100. Which intervention is most appropriate to improve his oxygenation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Initiate prone positioning

 

  • Prone positioning improves oxygenation in severe ARDS by enhancing ventilation-perfusion matching, promoting uniform lung inflation, and reducing lung tissue compression by the heart and abdomen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase the FiO2 to 100%: Increasing FiO2 to 100% risks oxygen toxicity and doesn't address ventilation-perfusion mismatch.
 

Option C. Double the current PEEP setting: Doubling PEEP without individual assessment can cause over distension, increased intrathoracic pressure, and barotrauma.
 

Option D. Start inhaled nitric oxide therapy: Inhaled nitric oxide improves oxygenation but is considered after other strategies like prone positioning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prone positioning is an effective intervention to improve oxygenation in patients with severe ARDS by enhancing ventilation-perfusion matching and reducing lung compression.
  • It is often considered when conventional ventilation strategies, including optimized PEEP and FiO2 adjustments, fail to achieve adequate oxygenation.

questions.text:
Determine whether the following statements are true or false regarding the public health classification of water-related diseases:

 

  1. Scabies is a water-borne disease caused by drinking contaminated water.
  2. Schistosomiasis is a water-based disease transmitted through an aquatic invertebrate animal.
  3. Malaria is a water-washed disease occurring due to inadequate use of water or improper hygiene.
  4. Dengue is a water-related disease spread by insects that depend on water.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) False, True, False, True

 

1. Scabies is a water-borne disease caused by drinking contaminated water: False. Scabies is a water-washed disease that occurs due to inadequate use of water or improper hygiene, not a water-borne disease.

 

2. Schistosomiasis is a water-based disease transmitted through an aquatic invertebrate animal: True. Schistosomiasis is indeed a water-based disease transmitted through an aquatic invertebrate animal.

 

3. Malaria is a water-washed disease occurring due to inadequate use of water or improper hygiene: False. Malaria is a water-related disease spread by insects that depend on water.

 

4. Dengue is a water-related disease spread by insects that depend on water: True. Dengue is spread by Aedes mosquitoes, which depend on water for breeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Public Health Classification of Water Borne Diseases

questions.text: As a medical officer at a district hospital, you are analyzing skeletal remains discovered during an excavation to determine the sex of the deceased. Which of the following indices is typically higher in the male pelvis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chilotic line index

 

  • It is an anthropometric line extending from the posterior aspect of the iliopectineal eminence to the closest point on the anterior auricular margin (the pelvic segment) and then to the iliac crest (the sacral portion).
  • Since the pelvic segment is predominant in females and the sacral segment is predominant in males, the chilotic index may be used to identify the sex of human skeletal remains. 

 

Sacral part of Chilotic line is more in males as compared to females. 

 

Males - 120.22 (83-151) & Females - 97.58 (72- 161)

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Ischiopubic index: Pubic length in mm. x 100/ Ischial length in mm.

Males -  73-94    &   Females - 93-115

 

Option B. Sciatic notch index: Width of sciatic notch x 100/ Depth of sciatic notch

Males -  4-5 & Females - 5 - 6
 

 

Option D. Sacral index: Transverse diameter of base of sacrum x 100/ Anterior length of sacrum

Males -  <114   &  Females - >114

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The sternal index, Sacral index, ischiopubic index and sciatic notch index are more in females.
  • Greater sciatic notch is the ideal feature to determine the sex of a female child

questions.text:
You are reviewing different types of evidence used in evidence-based medicine to determine their utility in clinical decision-making. Which of the following types of evidence are NOT considered useful in evidence-based medicine?

 

  1. Personal exposure
  2. Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT)
  3. Case report
  4. Meta-analysis
  5. Systematic review
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 & 3

 

1. Personal exposure: Personal experience or anecdotal evidence is subjective and not considered reliable or useful in evidence-based medicine due to the lack of systematic data and potential biases.

 

3. Case report: While case reports can provide insights into rare conditions or novel treatments, they are based on individual cases and lack the rigor and generalizability of higher levels of evidence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option (2) Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): RCTs are considered the best in clinical research due to their ability to minimize bias and establish causality. This comes next to meta-analysis and systemic review

 

Option (4) Meta-analysis: Meta-analyses combine data from multiple studies, increasing the power and reliability of the findings. It is of the highest clinical relevance (GOLD STANDARD)

 

Option (5) Systematic review: Systematic reviews provide comprehensive summaries of the evidence on a specific question, following a rigorous and transparent methodology. This comes next to Meta-analysis

 

Evidence-Pyramid in Research 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Evidence Based Medicine/Practice

 

  • Is considered ‘Gold standard for clinical practice’
  • Aims to apply best available evidence gained from scientific method to clinical decision making
  • Highest importance is given to strongest epidemiological studies:
    • Most important: Meta-analyses, Systematic reviews, Blinded trials
    • Least importance: Opinions and conventional wisdom of researchers and experts
  • Statistical parameters used:
    • Likelihood ratios
    • Receiver operator characteristic curve

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer presents to the OPD at district hospital with fever, headache, and muscle pain. You suspect a vector borne illness and decide to perform a Giemsa stain of a peripheral blood smear. This stain is not useful for detecting infection with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxiella burnetii

 

  • The diagnosis of Coxiella burnetii cannot be made using Giemsa stain of peripheral blood smear.
  • It is usually diagnosed by serology detecting specific antibodies in patient’s serum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bartonella bacilliformis: Giemsa stain can be used to detect Bartonella bacilliformis, which causes Oroya fever and verruga peruana.

 

Option C. Toxoplasma gondii: Giemsa stain can be used to detect Toxoplasma gondii, especially in the identification of tachyzoites in blood smears.

 

Option D. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: Giemsa stain is useful for detecting Ehrlichia chaffeensis by identifying morulae within white blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Giemsa stain is not useful for detecting Coxiella burnetii infections.
  • However, Bartonella, Toxoplasma (tachyzoites) and Ehrlichia can be detected by peripheral blood smear examination.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic with vaginal bleeding and a mass protruding from her vagina. On examination, the mass appears as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sarcoma botryoides

 

  • Sarcoma botryoides, a subtype of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, typically presents in young children with a characteristic "bunch of grapes" appearance protruding from the vagina.
  • This appearance is due to the tumor cells and edematous stroma forming grape-like clusters.

 

Other Options:
