Option A. Fibrosarcoma: Fibrosarcoma is a malignant tumor of fibroblasts and does not present with the characteristic "bunch of grapes" appearance. It is also less common in the vaginal region of young children.

 

Option C. Leiomyosarcoma: Leiomyosarcoma is a smooth muscle tumor that typically does not occur in the vagina of young children and does not present with a grape-like appearance.

 

Option D. Inflammatory polyp: Inflammatory polyps are benign lesions that can occur in various parts of the body, including the vagina. However, they do not have the characteristic "bunch of grapes" appearance seen in sarcoma botryoides.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sarcoma botryoides, a type of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, presents in young children with a characteristic "bunch of grapes" appearance of a mass protruding from the vagina.
  • Early recognition and diagnosis are crucial for appropriate management and treatment.

choices.text: 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D
1-D, 2-F, 3-E, 4-C
1-D, 2-A, 3-C 4-E
1-D, 2-C, 3-F, 4-E

questions.text: Match the following drugs with their ocular adverse effects:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-D, 2-C, 3-F, 4-E

 

  1. Amiodarone: Causes optic neuritis and corneal deposits (cornea verticillata). This can lead to vision changes and, in severe cases, optic neuropathy.
  2. Hydroxychloroquine: Causes retinopathy, specifically bull’s eye maculopathy. This condition can lead to significant visual impairment and is often dose-dependent.
  3. Systemic steroids: When given systemically, they can cause posterior subcapsular cataract. Topically, they can cause open-angle glaucoma due to increased intraocular pressure.
  4. Digoxin: Known for causing yellow vision (xanthopsia). This is a visual disturbance where objects appear yellow, and it is often a sign of digoxin toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ocular adverse-effects of drugs:

 

  • Amiodarone: Corneal deposits (cornea verticallata) Optic neuritis
  • Hydroxychloroquine: Bull’s eye maculopathy (retinopathy).
  • Systemic steroids: Given topically – cause Open angle Glaucoma
  • Given systemically – cause Posterior subcapsular cataract.
  • Digoxin: Yellow vision

choices.text: Children aged less than 14 years are prohibited from any employment
Adolescents aged from 15-18 years can work between 7:00 pm to 6:00 am
Women and children can be employed in all types of work
Adolescents of 16 years need not be duly certified as fit for work by a certifying surgeon

questions.text: During a recent inspection of a textile factory in India, the inspector needs to ensure the factory's compliance with the Factories Act of 1976, particularly concerning the employment of young workers. Which of the following statements is true under the Factories Act of 1976?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Children aged less than 14 years are prohibited from any employment

 

  • Children aged less than 14 years are prohibited from any employment: The Factories Act of 1976 strictly prohibits the employment of children under the age of 14 in any factory setting to protect their health and safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adolescents aged from 15-18 years can work between 7:00 pm to 6:00 am: This is incorrect. The Factories Act restricts adolescents from working during nighttime hours to ensure their well-being.

 

Option C. Women and children can be employed in all types of work: This is incorrect. There are specific restrictions on the types of work that women and children can perform to safeguard their health and safety.

 

Option D. Adolescents of 16 years need not be duly certified as fit for work by a certifying surgeon: This is incorrect. Adolescents must be certified as fit for work by a certifying surgeon before being employed to ensure they are capable of handling the work environment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Factory Act, 1948

 

  • No child <14 years age shall be required or allowed to work in any factory
  • A child >14 years age or an adolescent (15-18 years age) shall be allowed to work in any factory if they get a certificate of fitness from a Surgeon
  • No child shall be employed to work in any factory for > 4 ½ hours in any day and during night
  • No female child shall be allowed to work in any factory except between 8AM to 7PM
  • No female/male adolescent shall be allowed to work except between 6AM to 7 PM
  • Women and children cannot be employed in dangerous works

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with hematuria and left flank pain. Imaging studies reveal a renal mass, and a subsequent biopsy confirms the diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is most characteristic of papillary chromophilic renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trisomy 7/17

 

  • Papillary chromophilic renal cell carcinoma is characterized by distinct cytogenetic abnormalities.
  • The most characteristic finding in this type of renal cell carcinoma is trisomy of chromosomes 7 and 17.
  • This genetic abnormality is a hallmark of papillary renal cell carcinoma and helps differentiate it from other subtypes of renal cell carcinoma.
  • Trisomy 7 and 17 are commonly found in both hereditary and sporadic forms of papillary renal cell carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loss of 3p: Loss of the short arm of chromosome 3 (3p) is characteristic of clear cell renal cell carcinoma, not chromophilic (papillary) renal cell carcinoma.

 

Option C. Loss of 5q: Loss of chromosome 5q is not typically associated with chromophilic renal cell carcinoma. It can be seen in other types of cancers but is not a defining feature of this subtype of renal cell carcinoma.

 

Option D. Mutant VHL gene: Mutations in the VHL (Von Hippel-Lindau) gene are associated with clear cell renal cell carcinoma. These mutations lead to dysregulation of hypoxia-inducible factors (HIF) and are not characteristic of chromophilic renal cell carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chromophilic (papillary) renal cell carcinoma is characterized by trisomy of chromosomes 7 and 17, which distinguishes it from other types of renal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: An infant born at term is noted to have cyanosis during the first week of life. On examination, a heart murmur is auscultated. Echocardiography reveals an overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect, right ventricular thickening, and pulmonic stenosis involving the fetal heart. This infant is most likely to have an inherited mutation involving which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NOTCH2

 

  • The clinical findings in this infant—cyanosis, heart murmur, overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect, right ventricular thickening, and pulmonic stenosis—are characteristic features of Tetralogy of Fallot.
  • Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect that is often associated with mutations in the NOTCH2 gene.
  • Mutations in this gene disrupt normal heart development, leading to the structural abnormalities observed in Tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibrillin-1: Mutations in the Fibrillin-1 gene are associated with Marfan syndrome, which typically involves cardiovascular abnormalities such as aortic aneurysms but not the specific defects seen in Tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Option B. KCNQ1:  Mutations in KCNQ1 are associated with long QT syndrome, a disorder affecting cardiac repolarization, rather than structural heart defects like those seen in Tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Option D. β-myosin heavy chain (β-MHC): Mutations in the β-myosin heavy chain gene are associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which involves thickening of the heart muscle but not the specific structural heart defects of Tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tetralogy of Fallot, characterized by an overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect, right ventricular thickening, and pulmonic stenosis, is often associated with mutations in the NOTCH2 gene.

choices.text: Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures
Maintain urine output > 50 ml/h; IV crystalloids can be given
Discharge if afebrile for 72 hours, continue antimicrobials for 5 days

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman is diagnosed with acute pyelonephritis. Which of the following statements about the management of acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Discharge if afebrile for 72 hours, continue antimicrobials for 5 days

 

  • Discharging a patient if afebrile for 72 hours and continuing antimicrobials for only 5 days is incorrect.
  • The standard practice for managing acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy involves continuing antimicrobial therapy for a longer duration, typically 10-14 days, even after discharge to ensure complete eradication of the infection and to prevent recurrence or complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral antibiotics once afebrile: Once the patient is afebrile and stable, it is appropriate to switch from intravenous to oral antibiotics. This helps in the transition from hospital care to home care while ensuring the infection is still being treated effectively.

 

Option B. Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures: Hospitalization and sending urine and blood cultures are essential steps in managing acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy. These cultures help identify the causative organism and tailor antibiotic therapy accordingly.

 

Option C. Maintain urine output > 50 ml/h; IV crystalloids can be given: Maintaining adequate urine output and hydration with intravenous crystalloids is critical in the management of acute pyelonephritis. It helps prevent dehydration and supports renal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy requires hospitalization, cultures, and intravenous antibiotics initially.
  • Treatment should transition to oral antibiotics after the patient is afebrile, with a total course of 10-14 days of antimicrobials, not just 5 days.

choices.text: Piecemeal hepatocellular necrosis at the interface of portal tracts
Portal bridging fibrosis with nodular hepatocyte regeneration

questions.text: A 41-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice over several months. He underwent a colectomy 5 years ago for ulcerative colitis. Physical exam reveals generalized jaundice without abdominal pain or masses. Lab results show a serum alkaline phosphatase level of 285 U/L. Cholangiography indicates widespread obliteration of intrahepatic bile ducts and a beaded appearance in remaining ducts. Which of the following morphologic features is most likely present in his liver?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Concentric "onion-skin" bile duct fibrosis

 

  • The patient's clinical presentation, including progressive fatigue, pruritus, jaundice, and a history of ulcerative colitis, strongly suggests primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC).
  •  This condition is characterized by chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts, leading to their obliteration.
  • The "onion-skin" fibrosis, described as concentric layers of fibrosis around bile ducts, is a hallmark histologic feature of PSC. The beaded appearance on cholangiography is due to alternating strictures and dilations of the bile ducts, which is typical of PSC.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Piecemeal hepatocellular necrosis at the interface of portal tracts: This is typically seen in chronic hepatitis, such as chronic viral hepatitis or autoimmune hepatitis, but it is not specific to PSC.

 

Option B. Portal bridging fibrosis with nodular hepatocyte regeneration: This is characteristic of cirrhosis, which can occur in advanced stages of various liver diseases, including chronic hepatitis and non-alcoholic steatohepatitis, but is not specific for PSC.

 

Option C. Granulomatous bile duct destruction: This is characteristic of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), which is an autoimmune liver disease primarily affecting the small intrahepatic bile ducts, but is not a feature of PSC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by "onion-skin" fibrosis of bile ducts and is commonly associated with ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: Autoinfection is NOT seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hymenolepis diminuta

 

  • Unlike Hymenolepis nana, Hymenolepis diminuta does not undergo autoinfection. Its life cycle typically involves ingestion of infected arthropods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hymenolepis nana: Hymenolepis nana is capable of autoinfection, allowing the larvae to develop into adult worms within the same host.

 

Option C. Strongyloides stercoralis: Strongyloides stercoralis is known for its ability to cause autoinfection, leading to persistent infection in the host.

 

Option D. Taenia solium: Autoinfection with Taenia solium can occur if eggs are ingested by the same host, leading to cysticercosis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mnemonic

 

CHEST: Autoinfection is observed in Cryptosporidium parvum, Hymenolepis nana, Enterobius vermicularis, Strongyloides stercoralis and Taenia solium.

choices.text: Lateral striate branches of middle cerebral artery
Direct branches of internal carotid artery

questions.text: A 63-year-old male arrives at the emergency department exhibiting sudden onset of weakness and sensory loss on the right side of his body. Neurological examination shows contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss affecting his face, arm, and leg. What is the most common cause of a stroke that impacts the internal capsule?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lateral striate branches of middle cerebral artery

 

  • Lateral striate branches of middle cerebral artery, also known as lenticulostriate arteries, are small, deep penetrating arteries that supply blood to critical subcortical structures within the brain, including parts of the internal capsule, basal ganglia, and thalamus.
  • Due to their size and the high-pressure flow they handle, these arteries are particularly vulnerable to rupture and occlusion, commonly resulting in lacunar infarcts within the internal capsule.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Anterior cerebral artery: Incorrect. The anterior cerebral artery primarily supplies the medial portions of the frontal lobes and superior medial parietal lobes. It is not typically involved in strokes affecting the internal capsule.

 

Option B.  Recurrent artery of Heubner: Incorrect. The recurrent artery of Heubner, a branch of the anterior cerebral artery, primarily supplies the head of the caudate and adjacent parts of the anterior limb of the internal capsule, not typically involved in extensive internal capsule strokes.

 

Option D. Direct branches of internal carotid artery: Incorrect. While the internal carotid artery gives rise to several important cerebral arteries (including the anterior and middle cerebral arteries), it does not directly supply the internal capsule with the same specificity or vulnerability as the lateral striate arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The lateral striate branches of the middle cerebral artery are the most common cause of stroke involving the internal capsule, making them critical to understanding the vascular anatomy related to cerebrovascular accidents.
  • Their role highlights the importance of managing risk factors for small vessel disease to prevent such strokes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of chronic heart failure is being evaluated for a new medication to improve her symptoms. Her cardiologist wants to prescribe a drug that can both inhibit neprilysin and block the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), as illustrated in the diagram.  Which of the following drugs can act at both sites labelled as 1 and 2 in the diagram?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sampatrilat

 

  • Sampatrilat is a dual inhibitor that targets both neprilysin (NEP) and the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), acting at both sites 1 and 2 in the diagram.
  • This dual inhibition leads to increased levels of natriuretic peptides and decreased levels of angiotensin II, promoting natriuresis, vasodilation, and reducing sodium and water retention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sacubitril: Incorrect. Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor that acts at site 2 but does not target the angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) at site 1.

 

Option C. Losartan: Incorrect. Losartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) that acts on AT1 receptors but does not inhibit neprilysin.

 

Option D. Nesiritide: Incorrect. Nesiritide is a recombinant form of B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) and does not act on neprilysin or ACE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sampatrilat and omapatrilat are vasopeptidase inhibitors that inhibit both neutral endopeptidase as well as ACE.

questions.text: A child presents with the skin lesions shown in the image. The infection causing these lesions is most likely due to which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herpes simplex virus (HSV)

 

  • The image shows vesicular lesions on the face, which are characteristic of herpes simplex virus infection, commonly known as erythema multiforme.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus: Staphylococcal infections can cause skin lesions, but they typically present as impetigo, folliculitis, or abscesses, not the vesicular pattern shown.

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis (TB): TB primarily affects the lungs, but it can cause skin lesions in rare cases. These lesions do not typically present as vesicles.

 

Option D. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV): EBV is associated with infectious mononucleosis and can cause various systemic symptoms but does not typically present with vesicular skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes simplex virus accounts for majority of cause erythema multiforme.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is recognized as an AMPA antagonist?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perampanel

 

  • Perampanel selectively inhibits AMPA receptors, which are involved in excitatory neurotransmission in the brain.
  • By blocking these receptors, Perampanel helps reduce the excessive neuronal excitation that leads to seizures.
  • It is specifically approved for the management of focal seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lacosamide: Lacosamide works by enhancing the slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, not as an AMPA antagonist.

 

Option C. Rufinamide: Rufinamide acts by prolonging the inactivation of sodium channels, primarily used in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome rather than as an AMPA antagonist.

 

Option D. Felbamate: Felbamate affects NMDA receptors and enhances GABA receptors; it is not an AMPA antagonist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perampanel is an AMPA receptor antagonist approved for the treatment of focal seizures in patients with epilepsy.
  • It works by reducing excitatory neurotransmission in the brain to control seizure activity.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) experiences sudden onset of chest pain and difficulty breathing. Examination reveals no breath sounds on the left side. To best diagnose his condition via chest x-ray, which view should be used?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PA view in full expiration

 

  • In cases where a pneumothorax is suspected—indicated by sudden onset chest pain, shortness of breath, and absent breath sounds on one side—an expiratory PA view is often more diagnostic than inspiratory views.
  • The expiratory view enhances the visibility of any potential pneumothorax because the lung volume is reduced, making even a small pneumothorax more apparent as there is less air in the lungs to mask its presence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PA view in full inspiration : Incorrect for diagnosing pneumothorax. While PA views in full inspiration are standard for most chest x-rays, they may not as effectively reveal a small pneumothorax compared to an expiratory view.

 

Option B. AP view in full inspiration: Incorrect. AP views are typically used when the patient cannot be positioned properly for a PA view, such as in very ill or bedridden patients. While it can be useful, it is not the optimal choice for diagnosing a pneumothorax as the heart and mediastinum can obscure parts of the lungs.

 

Option D. DAP view in full expiration : Incorrect. The DAP (Dorsal Anterior Posterior) view is not a standard chest x-ray view and does not provide the clarity needed for diagnosing conditions like a pneumothorax compared to PA or AP views.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For diagnosing a suspected pneumothorax, particularly in a case presenting with symptoms like sudden chest pain and shortness of breath with unilateral absent breath sounds, a PA view in full expiration is most effective.
  • This view helps in better visualization of the lung fields by reducing lung volume, thereby enhancing the detection of any air collections that are not normal.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most likely to be represented by drug X in the figure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Denosumab

 

  • Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits the RANKL (Receptor Activator of Nuclear Factor Kappa-Β Ligand).
  • By binding to RANKL, denosumab prevents it from interacting with its receptor RANK on the surface of osteoclast precursors and osteoclasts.
  • This inhibition reduces the formation, function, and survival of osteoclasts, leading to decreased bone resorption and increased bone mass.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teriparatide: Incorrect. Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) that stimulates bone formation by increasing osteoblast activity, not by inhibiting the RANKL-RANK interaction.

 

Option B. Alendronate: Incorrect. Alendronate is a bisphosphonate that inhibits osteoclast-mediated bone resorption by binding to bone mineral and interfering with osteoclast activity.

 

Option D. Estrogen: Incorrect. Estrogen helps maintain bone density by inhibiting osteoclast activity and promoting osteoblast survival, but it does not specifically target the RANKL-RANK pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody against RANK ligand.
  • It inhibits interaction of RANK with its ligand on the surface of osteoclasts and thus prevents its activation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the pediatric endocrinology clinic with short stature, a triangular face, and asymmetry of the limbs. Genetic testing reveals uniparental disomy. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Russell-Silver syndrome

 

  • Russell-Silver syndrome (RSS) is a congenital condition characterized by intrauterine growth retardation, postnatal growth deficiency, a triangular face, and body asymmetry.
  • Genetic testing often reveals uniparental disomy (UPD) or hypomethylation of the imprinting control region 1 (ICR1) on chromosome 11p15.5, leading to overexpression of maternal alleles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Turner syndrome: Turner syndrome is characterized by the presence of a single X chromosome (45, X karyotype) and features such as short stature, webbed neck, and gonadal dysgenesis, but it is not associated with uniparental disomy.

 

Option B. Down syndrome: Down syndrome is caused by trisomy 21 and is characterized by intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and various congenital anomalies. It is not associated with uniparental disomy.

 

Option D. Marfan syndrome: Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder affecting connective tissue, characterized by tall stature, long limbs, and cardiovascular abnormalities. It is not associated with uniparental disomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Russell-Silver syndrome is associated with uniparental disomy and features include short stature, triangular face, and limb asymmetry.
  • Uniparental disomy occurs when both copies of a chromosome are inherited from one parent instead of one from each parent.
  • Genetic imprinting disorders like Russell-Silver syndrome result from abnormal gene expression due to epigenetic modifications.

questions.text: What is the standard usable length of rigid and flexible sigmoidoscopes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 25 and 60 cm

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Anoscope - 8 cm
  2. Proctoscope - 10-15 cm
  3. Rigid Sigmoidoscope and Rectoscope - 25 cm
  4. Flexible Sigmoidoscope - 60 cm
  5. Colonoscope - 160 cm

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The lengths of various endoscopic instruments are specific to their type and function, which is crucial for diagnostic and therapeutic procedures in gastroenterology.

choices.text: Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC)

questions.text: A 3.3 kg male infant, born at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery, develops respiratory distress shortly after birth and requires mechanical ventilation. The chest radiograph reveals a normal cardiothymic silhouette but a diffuse ground-glass appearance in the lung fields. Surfactant replacement fails to improve gas exchange, and hypoxemia worsens over the first week of life. Routine cultures and echocardiographic findings are negative. The infant had a sister who was born full term who died at 1 month of age with similar symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neonatal Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis

 

  • Neonatal Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis (PAP) is characterized by the intraalveolar accumulation of pulmonary surfactant due to a deficiency of the Protein-B component of surfactant.
  • This results in impaired spread and absorption of the major phospholipid of surfactant, leading to a functional deficiency and failure of alveolar expansion.
  • The presence of respiratory distress immediately after birth, which does not respond to surfactant replacement, along with a positive family history of similarly affected newborn infants, strongly suggests PAP.
  • A chest X-ray typically shows a ground-glass appearance. Histopathological examination of a lung biopsy specimen is the gold standard for diagnosis, revealing distal air spaces filled with a granular, eosinophilic material that stains positively with periodic-acid Schiff reagent and is diastase resistant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC): TAPVC usually presents with cyanosis and heart failure. A chest X-ray may show cardiomegaly with increased pulmonary vascular markings, which is not consistent with the ground-glass appearance seen in this case.

 

Option B. Meconium Aspiration Syndrome: Meconium Aspiration Syndrome typically occurs in term or post-term infants and presents with respiratory distress and coarse, patchy infiltrates on chest X-ray, not a ground-glass appearance. Additionally, it is usually associated with a history of meconium-stained amniotic fluid.

 

Option D. Disseminated Herpes Simplex Infection: Disseminated herpes simplex infection in neonates can present with respiratory distress, but it typically includes other systemic signs such as vesicular skin lesions, liver dysfunction, and CNS involvement. The absence of such signs and the presence of a ground-glass appearance on chest X-ray make this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neonatal Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis is characterized by respiratory distress, a ground-glass appearance on chest X-ray, and a lack of response to surfactant replacement.
  • A positive family history and worsening hypoxemia despite appropriate initial management are key indicators of this condition.
  • Histopathological examination of lung biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby presents to the hospital with a 2-day history of bloody diarrhea, abdominal distension, and episodes of screaming during examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intussusception

 

  • Intussusception is a common cause of abdominal pain in infants and typically presents with symptoms such as bloody diarrhea (often described as "currant jelly" stools), abdominal distension, and severe pain causing the baby to scream.
  • The typical age group affected is between 6 months and 3 years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS): HUS typically presents with symptoms such as pallor, oliguria, edema, petechiae, and lethargy following a history of severe gastroenteritis with bloody stools. However, it does not usually cause severe abdominal pain or screaming.

 

Option C. Appendicitis: Appendicitis usually presents with right lower quadrant pain, and is most common in older children and adolescents (peak incidence between 12 and 18 years). It is rare in infants and does not typically present with bloody diarrhea.

 

Option D. Acute enterocolitis: Acute enterocolitis often presents with fever, vomiting, colicky abdominal pain, and tenesmus. While it can cause bloody diarrhea, it is less likely to cause the severe abdominal pain and screaming seen in intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intussusception in infants typically presents with bloody diarrhea, abdominal distension, and severe pain causing the baby to scream.
  • It is a surgical emergency and prompt diagnosis is crucial.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is being evaluated for the severity of malnutrition. The child weighs 7 kg and measures 74 cm in length. The expected (median) weight for height and height for age for this child are 9 kg and 86 cm, respectively. According to the WHO classification of undernutrition, which of the following is the correct category for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wasted, stunted

 

Calculation for the child:

 

Weight for Height (%) = (Weight of child / Weight of normal child at that age) × 100 = (7 / 9) × 100 = 77.7%

 

Height for Age (%) = (Height of child / Height of normal child at that age) × 100 = (74 / 86) × 100 = 86%

 

The child's weight for height is 77.7%, indicating wasting (moderate malnutrition), and height for age is 86%, indicating stunting (moderate malnutrition).

 

Educational Objective:

 

WHO CLASSIFICATION OF MALNUTRITION

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida woman is in the second stage of labor. The obstetrician determines that an episiotomy is necessary to facilitate the delivery of the baby's head. When performing an episiotomy, which of the following instruments is commonly used?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Braun-Stadler scissors

 

  • Braun-Stadler scissors are specifically designed for performing episiotomies.
  • These scissors have a precise design that allows for a controlled and clean incision in the perineal tissue, which is crucial for minimizing trauma and facilitating the delivery of the baby's head.
  • The blunt tips of these scissors help avoid injury to the baby and surrounding tissues.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scalpel: While a scalpel is used for various surgical procedures, it is not typically used for episiotomies due to the lack of control and increased risk of an irregular or too deep incision.

 

 

Option B. Metzenbaum scissors: Metzenbaum scissors are primarily used for cutting delicate tissues and are not the most common choice for episiotomies. They are longer and more slender, designed for other types of soft tissue dissection.

 

 

Option D. Curved Mayo scissors: Curved Mayo scissors are generally used for cutting dense, fibrous tissues and are less suitable for the precise and controlled incisions required for an episiotomy. They are heavier and more robust than Braun-Stadler scissors, making them less ideal for this specific procedure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Braun-Stadler scissors are the preferred instrument for performing an episiotomy due to their ability to provide a controlled and clean incision, minimizing trauma to the perineal tissue and facilitating the delivery process.

questions.text: The most common organism causing osteomyelitis in drug abusers is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudomonas

 

OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium known for its ability to cause infections in various parts of the body, including the respiratory tract, skin, and soft tissues.
  • In the context of drug abuse-related osteomyelitis, Pseudomonas is the causative agent, especially if the individual has been exposed to contaminated needles or has compromised immune function.
  • Pseudomonas infections can be particularly challenging to treat due to their intrinsic resistance to many antibiotics and their ability to develop resistance during treatment.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. E.coli: While Escherichia coli (E. coli) is a common bacterium associated with urinary tract infections and gastrointestinal illnesses, it is not typically a primary cause of osteomyelitis in drug abusers. E. coli tends to infect the urinary tract and is less commonly associated with bone infections.

 

Option C. Klebsiella: Klebsiella species are gram-negative bacteria commonly associated with respiratory and urinary tract infections. While Klebsiella infections can sometimes lead to osteomyelitis, especially in immunocompromised individuals or those with underlying health conditions, they are not typically the primary cause in drug abuse-related cases.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus, particularly methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), is the most common organism causing osteomyelitis in all age groups. Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacterium commonly found on the skin and mucous membranes. It can enter the body through breaks in the skin, such as those caused by intravenous drug use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is most common organism in intravenous drug users and Salmonella is common in sickle cell anemia patients while staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism in all age groups.

questions.text: Which of the following reactions does not contribute to the production of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cytoplasmic malate dehydrogenase

 

  • This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of malate to oxaloacetate in the cytoplasm and uses NAD+ as a coenzyme, not NADP+. Thus, it does not produce NADPH and is not involved in NADPH generation for fatty acid synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

NADPH is an essential reducing agent in fatty acid synthesis, required for the reductive biosynthetic reactions. There are several key reactions that generate NADPH in the body:

 

Option A. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase: This enzyme catalyzes the first step in the oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway, converting glucose-6-phosphate to 6-phosphoglucono-δ-lactone while generating NADPH.

 

Option B. 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase: This enzyme catalyzes the third step in the oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway, converting 6-phosphogluconate to ribulose-5-phosphate and producing NADPH.

 

Option C. Malic enzyme: This enzyme catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of malate to pyruvate, producing NADPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cytoplasmic malate dehydrogenase does not contribute to the production of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man from a rural village visits the district hospital with a history of jaundice and fatigue that resolved two months ago. He mentions that several members of his community have had similar symptoms. To confirm recovery from hepatitis B infection, you review his serological test results. The serological marker indicated by the arrow in the image is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti-HBc antibody

 

  • The arrow in the image points to the line representing the anti-HBc antibody.
  • This marker indicates that the patient has had a past or ongoing hepatitis B infection.
    • Line-1: HBsAg and Line-5 anti-HBs antibody
    • Line-2: Anti-HBc antibody (marked in arrow)
    • Line-3 HBeAg and line-4 is anti-HBeAb

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-HBs antibody: This marker, represented by line 5 in the image, indicates recovery and immunity from hepatitis B.

 

Option C. HBsAg: Line 1 in the image represents HBsAg, which indicates an active hepatitis B infection.

 

Option D. HBeAg: Line 3 represents HBeAg, which indicates active viral replication and high infectivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interpretation of markers in various stages of Hepatitis B infection

choices.text: I- a, II - b, III - c, IV - d
I - f, II - e, III - d, IV - c
I - f, II - b, III - c, IV - e
I - a, II - c, III - f, IV - d

questions.text:
Match the following conditions with their most likely clinical features:

 

Column A

 

I. Fuch's endothelial dystrophy

II. Fuch's Heterochromic iridocyclitis

III. Dalen Fuchs nodules

IV. Foster-Fuchs spots

 

Column B

 

a. Cornea guttata

b. Amsler's sign

c. Sarcoidosis

d. Myopia

e. ARMD (Age-Related Macular Degeneration)

f. Krukenberg spindle
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  I- a, II - b, III - c, IV - d

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Fuch's endothelial dystrophy is typically associated with corneal changes such as cornea guttata.
  2. Fuch's Heterochromic iridocyclitis generally does not show typical signs of inflammation like redness and pain but may include Amsler's sign which indicates bleeding in Anterior Chamber on Paracentesis.
  3. Dalen Fuchs nodules are associated with diseases like sarcoidosis, Sympathetic Ophthalmia, VKH Syndrome
  4. Foster-Fuchs spots are commonly observed in conditions affecting the retina like myopia.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An eight-month-old child has a history of unusual crying, altered sensorium, and convulsions following previous vaccinations, including BCG, DPT, OPV (first dose), and Hepatitis B. The parents have brought the child for the next doses of vaccination. Which vaccine is contraindicated in this situation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DPT

 

  • The child exhibited signs of encephalopathy following the previous dose of DPT.
  • Absolute contraindications to any pertussis vaccination (including the DPT vaccine) include a history of anaphylaxis or development of encephalopathy within 7 days following previous DPT vaccination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measles: The measles vaccine is not contraindicated in this scenario and can be safely administered.

 

Option C. Hepatitis B: There are no contraindications to administering the Hepatitis B vaccine in this situation.

 

Option D. DT: The DT vaccine, which does not contain the pertussis component, can be administered safely if there is a contraindication to the pertussis component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Absolute contraindications to DPT vaccination include a history of anaphylaxis or development of encephalopathy within 7 days of the previous dose.
  • Events such as persistent inconsolable crying, hyperpyrexia, and seizures following DPT are precautions but not absolute contraindications.
  • Progressive or evolving neurological illnesses are relative contraindications to the first dose of DPT immunization.

questions.text:
Match the following organisms in Column A with their corresponding histopathological findings in Column B:

 

Column A

1. Molluscum contagiosum

2. BK polyoma virus

3. Human papillomavirus (HPV)

4. Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

 

Column B

A. Henderson-Paterson bodies

B. Owl’s eye

C. Decoy cells

D. Koilocytes
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-A; 2-C; 3-D; 4-B

 

Explanation:

 

  • Molluscum bodies, also called as Henderson-Paterson bodies - seen in Molluscum contagiosum infection
  • Owl’s eye inclusion bodies seen in CMV infection
  • Koilocytes, also known as halo cells, are a type of epithelial cell that develops following HPV infection
  • Decoy cells are virally infected epithelial cells that can be found in the urine; e.g. cytomegalovirus and Polyomavirus.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following structures does NOT form a boundary of the original Calot's triangle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior border of the liver

 

  • Calot's triangle, also known as the hepatobiliary triangle, is an anatomical space bordered by the cystic duct, the common hepatic duct, and the cystic artery.
  • The inferior border of liver is found within Calot's triangle but does not form a boundary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Calot's triangle is an important anatomical landmark in cholecystectomy surgeries, bordered by the cystic duct, common hepatic duct, and the cystic artery.
  • This has however been modified in contemporary literature, with inferior border of liver as superior boundary, known as hepato-cystic triangle.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a 5-day history of fever, irritability, and rash. On examination, he has conjunctival infection, a red and swollen tongue, red cracked lips, and a polymorphous rash on his trunk. He also has erythema and swelling of his hands and feet, and desquamation of the fingers. There is no history of cough or rhinorrhea. Laboratory results show elevated inflammatory markers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kawasaki disease

 

  • Kawasaki disease is an acute vasculitis that primarily affects children and is characterized by prolonged fever, conjunctival injection, changes in the oral mucosa (e.g., red, swollen tongue and cracked lips), a polymorphous rash, extremity changes (e.g., erythema and swelling of hands and feet), and cervical lymphadenopathy.
  • Desquamation of the fingers can also be seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scarlet fever: Scarlet fever is associated with group A streptococcal infection and presents with a characteristic "sandpaper" rash, fever, and a "strawberry" tongue. It typically follows a pharyngitis.

 

Option C. Measles: Measles presents with a high fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and a characteristic maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads downward. Koplik spots in the mouth are also a key feature.

 

Option D. Toxic shock syndrome: Toxic shock syndrome is caused by toxins produced by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes and presents with high fever, diffuse erythematous rash, hypotension, and multi-organ involvement. It usually follows a skin or wound infection or tampon use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kawasaki disease is an acute vasculitis seen in children and is characterized by prolonged fever, conjunctival injection, changes in the oral mucosa, a polymorphous rash, extremity changes, and cervical lymphadenopathy.
  • It is essential to recognize and treat Kawasaki disease promptly to prevent coronary artery aneurysms.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with hip pain for last 6 months. Hip X-ray is as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giant cell tumor

 

  • The given image shows the giant cell tumor of the hip joint as the lesion is extensively osteolytic.  

 

GIANT CELL TUMOR

 

  • They typically occur in patients who are 20–40 years old.
  • Radiographic findings often are diagnostic.
  • The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone.
  • Although rare in skeletally immature patients, giant cell tumors arise in the metaphysis in this age group.
  • Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic.
  • The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex; however, intraarticular extension is rare because the subchondral bone usually remains intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Simple bone cyst: Unicameral/simple bone cysts are most common in the proximal humerus and femur. The lesions are most active during skeletal growth and usually heal spontaneously at maturity. Unicameral bone cysts are often asymptomatic, unless a pathological fracture has occurred. Plain radiographs reveal a centrally located, purely lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline. Occasionally (20%), a thinned cortical fragment fractures and falls into the base of the lesion, confirming its empty cystic nature. This “fallen fragment” sign is pathognomonic and, bone fragment may also hinge around and move with fluid called as trap door sign.

 

 

Option C. Adamantinoma: Adamantinoma is seen in second or third decade of life. It is almost exclusively found in tibial diaphysis. The most common radiographic appearance is that of multiple, sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions in the tibial diaphysis – Soap Bubble appearance.

 

 

Option D. Ewing’s sarcoma: Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the lytic lesion in the femoral neck and the head, descriptive of giant cell tumor

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure is admitted to the hospital and is on diuretic therapy for the same, but reports reduced urine output over the last two days. On admission, his serum creatinine is 2.0 mg/dL, up from a baseline of 1.2 mg/dL one month ago. He has a urine output of 300 mL in the first 6 hours after admission. What stage of acute kidney injury (AKI) does this patient's presentation most likely correspond to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stage 1

 

  • Acute kidney injury (AKI) is classified into three stages based on changes in serum creatinine and urine output criteria according to the KDIGO (Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes) guidelines.

 

 

 

For this patient:

 

  • The increase in serum creatinine from 1.2 mg/dL to 2.0 mg/dL represents a 1.5 to 1.9 times increase from baseline, which meets the criterion for Stage 1 AKI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Stage 1 acute kidney injury (AKI) is defined by a 1.5-1.9 times increase in serum creatinine from baseline within 7 days or a urine output of <0.5 mL/kg/hour for 6-12 hours, according to the KDIGO criteria.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male sustains a degloving injury to his right lower leg in a motorcycle accident. Which triage color code is most appropriate for this injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Yellow

 

  • Degloving injuries involve extensive skin and tissue damage where the skin is torn away from the underlying tissue, often requiring early but not life-saving attention.
  • These injuries are triaged as yellow, indicating delayed care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red: For life-threatening conditions requiring immediate attention.

 

Option B. Black: For patients with injuries so severe that survival is unlikely.

 

Option C. Green: For minor injuries that can wait for extended periods.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Degloving injuries are triaged as yellow, indicating delayed care, while red indicates immediate care, black indicates unlikely survival, and green indicates minor injuries.

questions.text: A 50-year-old researcher is conducting a study to understand the structural properties of a newly discovered protein. Various techniques are considered to analyze the protein's structure. However, one of the methods listed is not typically used for studying protein structure. Which of the following methods is least likely used to study the structure of proteins?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. UV Spectroscopy.

 

Option B. UV Spectroscopy:

 

UV spectroscopy measures the absorption of ultraviolet light. The sources indicate that tyrosine, phenylalanine, and tryptophan absorb high-wavelength (250-290 nm) ultraviolet light, with tryptophan making the major contribution to most proteins' ability to absorb light around 280 nm. While this property is useful for quantifying protein concentration or detecting the presence of these aromatic amino acids, it does not provide detailed information about a protein's overall three-dimensional (secondary, tertiary, or quaternary) structure, nor its amino acid sequence (primary structure). It provides a generalized characteristic based on the presence of specific chromophores rather than a structural elucidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Spectroscopy:

 

NMR spectroscopy is a key technique used to study higher orders of protein structure. It measures the absorbance of radiofrequency electromagnetic energy by atomic nuclei and, from this, can be used to construct a three-dimensional structure by determining the spatial relationships between component atoms. This technique is particularly valuable because it analyzes proteins in aqueous solution, allowing for the observation of changes in protein conformation that occur during ligand binding or catalysis in real-time.

 

Option C. Edman's technique:

 

Edman's technique, using phenyl isothiocyanate (Edman reagent), was devised as the first practical method for peptide sequencing. This method selectively labels and removes the amino-terminal residue of a peptide, allowing for the determination of the amino acid sequence (primary structure). While labor-intensive and largely replaced by mass spectrometry for full protein sequencing, it is fundamentally a method for studying protein structure at the primary level.

 

Option D. X-ray Crystallography:

 

X-ray crystallography is a key technique used to study higher orders of protein structure. It has been instrumental in revealing the three-dimensional structures of thousands of biologic macromolecules, including proteins, by analyzing diffraction patterns from well-ordered crystals. This method provides detailed atomic-level resolution of protein structures, making it highly suitable for understanding their intricate folds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Edmans technique is used for sequencing amino acids in proteins, not for studying the three-dimensional structure of proteins.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with eye irritation and a sensation of dryness. Her thyroid function tests reveal elevated T4 and suppressed TSH levels. What is the name of this eye sign?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Joffroy's sign

 

  • Joffroy's sign is the absence of forehead wrinkling when looking upwards, associated with Thyroid ophthalmopathy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stellwag's sign: Stellwag's sign is incomplete and infrequent blinking, associated with Thyroid ophthalmopathy

 

Option B. Von Graefe's sign: Von Graefe's sign is the lag of the upper eyelid on downward gaze, also seen in Thyroid ophthalmopathy

 

Option D. Kocher's sign: Kocher's sign is a staring appearance and a rim of sclera visible above the iris when the patient looks down, also seen in Thyroid ophthalmopathy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Joffroy's sign is identified by the absence of forehead wrinkling when looking upwards, indicative of Thyroid ophthalmopathy

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with progressive dyspnea and fatigue over 2 years. Physical exam reveals pedal edema, jugular venous distention, and hepatomegaly, with clear lung fields. Chest CT shows right heart enlargement. Cardiac catheterization reveals increased pulmonary arterial pressure without valve gradients or shunts. A transbronchial biopsy shows plexiform lesions with smooth muscle hypertrophy and luminal narrowing. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone morphogenetic receptor 2 (BMPR2)

 

  • The patient exhibits sign and symptoms consistent with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), including progressive dyspnea, fatigue, pedal edema, jugular venous distention, and hepatomegaly.
  • The right heart enlargement seen on chest CT scan and the increased pulmonary arterial pressure without gradients across the pulmonic valve on cardiac catheterization further support this diagnosis.
  • The presence of plexiform lesions and smooth muscle hypertrophy in the pulmonary arteries seen on biopsy is characteristic of PAH.
  • BMPR2 gene mutations are the most common genetic cause of familial and idiopathic PAH.
  •  BMPR2 encodes a receptor in the transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β) superfamily, which is crucial for the regulation of cell growth and apoptosis in vascular smooth muscle cells.
  •  Mutations in BMPR2 lead to abnormal proliferation of these cells, contributing to the pathogenesis of PAH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelin: Although endothelin plays a role in PAH by causing vasoconstriction and vascular smooth muscle proliferation, mutations in the endothelin gene are not commonly implicated in the genetic form of PAH.

 

Option B. Fibrillin-1: Mutations in the Fibrillin-1 gene are associated with Marfan syndrome, which can lead to aortic aneurysms and dissections, but not typically with PAH.

 

Option C. Endothelial nitric oxide synthetase (eNOS): eNOS is involved in the production of nitric oxide, a vasodilator. While dysfunctional nitric oxide signaling is observed in PAH, eNOS gene mutations are not a primary cause of PAH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mutations in the BMPR2 gene are the most common genetic cause of pulmonary arterial hypertension, leading to abnormal proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells and characteristic pathological findings such as plexiform lesions.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is diagnosed to have endometrial carcinoma on biopsy. She wishes to understand the high-risk factors for development of endometrial cancer. Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for development of endometrial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiparity

 

  • Multiparity (having given birth to more than one child) is generally not considered a risk factor for endometrial carcinoma.
  • In fact, having multiple full-term pregnancies is often thought to be protective against the development of endometrial cancer.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Diabetes: Women with diabetes, especially type 2, are at a higher risk for developing endometrial cancer. Insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia, common in type 2 diabetes, are thought to contribute to this increased risk.

 

Option C. Obesity: Obesity is a well-known risk factor for endometrial cancer. Excess body fat can lead to increased estrogen levels, which, in the absence of progesterone, can stimulate the endometrial lining and increase the risk of cancer.

 

Option D. Tamoxifen therapy: Tamoxifen is a medication used primarily to treat and prevent breast cancer. However, one of its side effects is an increased risk of endometrial cancer. Tamoxifen has estrogenic effects on the uterine lining, which can lead to endometrial hyperplasia and, potentially, cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When discussing risk factors for endometrial carcinoma, it's important to recognize that multiparity is generally not associated with an increased risk of this type of cancer.
  • In fact, having multiple pregnancies is often considered to be protective.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is considering permanent contraception. Which of the following methods is NOT performed using an abdominal laparoscopic technique for tubal ligation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Essure

 

Explanation:

 

  • Essure is a hysteroscopic method of tubal occlusion, not an abdominal laparoscopic technique.
  • It involves placing a small metal coil into the fallopian tubes via the vagina and cervix.
  • Over time, this induces fibrosis and occludes the tubes, preventing pregnancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pomeroy: This is a common laparoscopic technique for tubal ligation where a loop of the fallopian tube is tied off and a segment is removed.

 

 

Option B. Parkland: This technique involves tying and cutting the fallopian tubes at two separate points and removing the segment in between, and it can be performed laparoscopically.

 

 

Option C. Irving: This laparoscopic technique involves ligating the tube and then burying the ends in the myometrium, thus preventing re-canalization.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Essure is not an abdominal laparoscopic technique for tubal ligation; it is a hysteroscopic method. In contrast, Pomeroy, Parkland, and Irving techniques are all abdominal laparoscopic methods used for tubal ligation.

choices.text: Foamy macrophages within the lamina propria

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has had diarrhea, fatigue, and a 3-kg weight loss over 6 months. She is afebrile with mild muscle wasting but normal motor strength. Lab studies show no occult blood, ova, or parasites in the stool. Upper jejunal biopsy shows specific changes, and she improves dramatically on a gluten-free diet. What microscopic feature is most likely seen in her biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Villous blunting and flattening

 

  • The patient’s symptoms, biopsy findings, and significant improvement on a gluten-free diet strongly suggest celiac disease.
  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten in genetically predisposed individuals.
  •  The hallmark microscopic feature of celiac disease in the small intestine is villous blunting and flattening, accompanied by intraepithelial lymphocytosis and crypt hyperplasia.
  •  These changes lead to malabsorption, which accounts for the patient's diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Noncaseating granulomas: Noncaseating granulomas are characteristic of Crohn's disease, a type of inflammatory bowel disease, but are not associated with celiac disease.

 

Option C. Foamy macrophages within the lamina propria: Foamy macrophages are typically seen in Whipple's disease, a rare bacterial infection that affects the intestines, but not in celiac disease.

 

Option D. Crypt abscesses: Crypt abscesses are a feature of ulcerative colitis, another type of inflammatory bowel disease, and are not seen in celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Villous blunting and flattening in the small intestine biopsy is the characteristic microscopic feature of celiac disease, which improves with a gluten-free diet.

choices.text: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), subjected to a test as shown below. Which of the following lung volumes or capacities cannot be measured by this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Total lung capacity (TLC)

 

  • Total lung capacity (TLC) cannot be measured directly by spirometry because it includes the residual volume (RV), which is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation.
  • Spirometry can measure volumes of air that can be inhaled or exhaled, but not the residual volume. TLC is typically measured using methods like body plethysmography or gas dilution techniques.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vital capacity (VC): Vital capacity (VC) can be measured by spirometry as it is the maximum amount of air that can be exhaled after a maximum inhalation.

 

Option B. Forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1): Forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) is a key spirometric measurement representing the volume of air expelled in the first second of a forceful exhalation.

 

Option D. Tidal volume (TV): Tidal volume (TV) is the volume of air inhaled or exhaled during normal breathing, which can also be measured by spirometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Total lung capacity (TLC) cannot be measured by spirometry as it includes residual volume (RV), requiring other methods like body plethysmography or gas dilution.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a headache and multiple scalp lesions. His skull X-ray is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Langerhans cell histiocytosis

 

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis often presents in children with lytic bone lesions, particularly in the skull, as seen on the X-ray.
  • It can cause headaches and scalp lesions due to involvement of the bone and surrounding tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma typically presents in older adults with multiple lytic bone lesions but is rare in children.

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma usually presents with a single, painful, and rapidly enlarging mass in the metaphysis of long bones, not multiple skull lesions.

 

Option D. Paget's disease of bone: Paget's disease of bone usually occurs in older adults and presents with enlarged, deformed bones, not multiple lytic lesions in the skull of a child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis should be suspected in children presenting with lytic bone lesions, especially in the skull, and associated symptoms like headaches and scalp lesions.

questions.text: A 24-year-old swimmer presents with sudden onset of fever, headache, nausea, and neck stiffness. After a few days, the patient develops confusion and seizures. The microscopic slide of CSF is shown below. Based on the clinical presentation and microscopic findings, which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Naegleria

 

  • The image shows Naegleria fowleri trophozoite in CSF, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E).
  • Naegleria fowleri is known to cause primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), a rapidly progressing and often fatal disease.
  • The clinical presentation of sudden onset of fever, headache, nausea, neck stiffness, confusion, and seizures is characteristic of this infection.
  • The infection typically occurs when contaminated water enters the nose, often during swimming in warm freshwater lakes and rivers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acanthamoeba: Acanthamoeba causes granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE), a chronic condition, rather than acute meningoencephalitis.

 

Option C. Meningococcus: Neisseria meningitidis (meningococcus) causes bacterial meningitis, which can lead to meningoencephalitis, but the presentation described is more typical of Naegleria fowleri.

 

Option D. Balamuthia: Balamuthia mandrillaris causes granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE), similar to Acanthamoeba, and not acute meningoencephalitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FREE-LIVING AMOEBAE

 

Free-living amoebae are small, freely living, widely distributed in soil and water and can cause opportunistic infections in humans. Human pathogens are:

 

  1. Naegleria fowleri is a causative agent of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM).
  2. Acanthamoeba species causes granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE) and amoebic keratitis in contact lens wearers.
  3. Balamuthia mandrillaris causes GAE.
  4. Sappinia species: causes encephalitis.

choices.text: Increased force of heart contraction
Increased R-R interval in ECG

questions.text: In a clinical setting, a physician evaluates a middle-aged man experiencing episodes of rapid heartbeat. To assess the impact of parasympathetic nervous system activity on his cardiac function, the physician administers a vagal stimulation test. What change in the ECG would be indicative of effective vagal stimulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased R-R interval in ECG

 

  • Vagal stimulation, involving the activation of the parasympathetic nervous system, generally results in a decrease in heart rate.
  • This physiological response is evident in the electrocardiogram (ECG) as an increased R-R interval, indicating a longer time between consecutive heartbeats.
  • The R-R interval is a direct measure of heart rate; hence, a longer R-R interval corresponds to a slower heart rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased cardiac output: Vagal stimulation typically decreases heart rate and may slightly decrease stroke volume, which collectively reduce cardiac output rather than increase it.

 

Option B. Increased force of heart contraction: Vagal stimulation does not enhance the contractility of the heart. Instead, it primarily affects heart rate and the electrical properties of the heart, with minimal to no effect on the force of contraction.

 

Option C. Increased heart rate: This is the opposite of the expected effect of vagal stimulation. Increased vagal activity typically slows down the heart rate as part of its function in the parasympathetic nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Increased vagal stimulation leads to a longer R-R interval on an ECG, reflecting a decrease in heart rate.
  • This effect is a key aspect of the parasympathetic influence on cardiac function.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of the Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus

 

  • The Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS) is used to discuss the likely prognosis and risk of complications with patients undergoing obesity surgery.
  • The OS-MRS includes the following components: age ≥ 45 years, BMI ≥ 50, male gender, hypertension, and history of DVT/PE.
  • Type-2 diabetes mellitus is considered a risk factor for surgery in general but is not included in the OS-MRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age ≥ 45 years: It is a component of the OS-MRS, indicating increased risk with advancing age.

 

Option B. BMI ≥ 50: It is a component of the OS-MRS, reflecting the risk associated with higher BMI.

 

Option D. Male gender: It is a component of the OS-MRS, showing increased risk in males.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type-2 diabetes mellitus is not a component of the Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS), which includes age ≥ 45 years, BMI ≥ 50, male gender, hypertension, and DVT/PE.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is most likely transmitted by this vector?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Visceral leishmaniasis

 

  • The sandfly is the vector for visceral leishmaniasis, a disease caused by the Leishmania parasite.
  • The clinical presentation of prolonged fever, weight loss, and splenomegaly is characteristic of visceral leishmaniasis, which is transmitted through the bite of infected sandflies.

 

SANDFLY (PHLEBOTOMUS):

 

  • Legs twice as long as body
  • Lanceolate (Flame shaped) wings
  • Fine hairs on margins of wings

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. West Nile fever: This disease is transmitted by Culex mosquitoes, not sandflies.

 

Option B. Filariasis: This disease is primarily transmitted by mosquitoes, including Culex, Anopheles, and Aedes species, not sandflies.

 

Option D. Yellow fever: This disease is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, not sandflies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Visceral leishmaniasis is transmitted by sandflies and presents with symptoms such as prolonged fever, weight loss, and splenomegaly.

choices.text: Pemphigus vulgaris
Solar keratosis

questions.text: An 11-year-old child is seen with itching and hyperpigmented plaques localized to the creases of the elbows and behind the knees, as illustrated below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atopic dermatitis

 

  • Atopic dermatitis (AD) is the correct diagnosis for this clinical presentation.
  • AD is a common chronic skin condition that often starts in childhood and is characterized by intense itching and recurrent eczematous lesions.
  • The plaques typically appear in the flexural areas of the body, such as the cubital and popliteal fossae, and are often accompanied by hyperpigmentation due to chronic scratching and inflammation, which aligns with the findings in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus vulgaris: An autoimmune blistering disorder that typically presents with fragile blisters and erosions on the skin and mucous membranes, rather than the hyperpigmented plaques seen in the image.

 

Option B.Psoriasis: This condition generally manifests with well-demarcated, thick, silvery scales and plaques on the skin, which differ from the eczematous lesions characteristic of AD.

 

Option C. Solar keratosis: Also known as actinic keratosis, this is a precancerous condition caused by sun damage, typically presenting with rough, scaly patches on sun-exposed areas, not the flexural hyperpigmented plaques typical of AD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atopic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin disease most common in children, characterized by itchy and hyperpigmented plaques primarily located in the flexural regions of the body.

questions.text: A public health researcher is studying the demographic transition model in India to understand population dynamics over time. The researcher is particularly interested in the contraction of the demographic gap, which is the difference between birth and death rates. At what stage of the demographic transition does the contraction of the demographic gap typically start?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Early Stage III

 

  • The contraction of the demographic gap typically starts in Early Stage III of the demographic transition model.
  •  In this stage, both birth and death rates begin to decline more noticeably.
  • The death rate continues to fall due to improvements in healthcare, nutrition, and sanitation, which began in Stage II.
  • Simultaneously, the birth rate starts to decline significantly due to changes in social norms and economic factors, including increased access to contraception, more women in education and the workforce, and urbanization. This convergence of lower birth and death rates reduces the demographic gap.

 

5 stages (phases) of demographic cycle through which a nation passes:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Demographic Cycle and Concepts

 

  • Demographic cycle is closely related to: Socio-economic progress of a country
  • India is in Stage III (Late Expanding Phase) of Demographic cycle

choices.text: Transposition of the great vessels

questions.text: A senior cardiologist discusses a congenital heart defect with residents, focusing on a developmental anomaly due to anterior displacement of the cono-truncal septum, which causes an unequal division of the conus cordis. Which condition is associated with this defect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tetralogy of Fallot

 

  • Tetralogy of Fallot is a complex congenital heart defect that arises from an anterior displacement of the cono-truncal septum, which leads to an unequal division of the conus cordis during embryonic development.
  • This malformation results in four associated heart defects: ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, pulmonary stenosis, and right ventricular hypertrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coarctation of the aorta: Incorrect. Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing of the aorta and does not typically result from cono-truncal abnormalities but rather from issues related to the ductal tissue and aortic arch development.

 

Option B.  Transposition of the great vessels: Incorrect. Transposition of the great vessels, where the aorta and pulmonary artery are switched from their normal positions, is related to a failure in the proper spiraling of the cono-truncal septum, not merely its anterior displacement.

 

Option D.  Persistent truncus arteriosus: Incorrect. Persistent truncus arteriosus, characterized by a failure to develop a separate pulmonary artery and aorta, results from the complete absence or improper formation of the cono-truncal septum, not just its displacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tetralogy of Fallot results from the anterior displacement of the cono-truncal septum leading to an unequal division of the conus cordis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation presents to the clinic for a follow-up. The physician considers prescribing digoxin but is cautious due to several potential contraindications. Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for digoxin therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome

 

  • Digoxin is contraindicated in WPW syndrome because it can enhance conduction through the accessory pathway, potentially leading to dangerous arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperkalemia: Incorrect. Hyperkalemia is not a contraindication for digoxin; in fact, hypokalemia increases the risk of digoxin toxicity.

 

Option B. Hypocalcemia: Incorrect. Hypocalcemia is not a contraindication; hypercalcemia increases the risk of digoxin toxicity.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Incorrect. While both hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism can affect the pharmacokinetics of digoxin, they are not strict contraindications. Digoxin's dose may need adjustment in these conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mnemonic

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department with palpitations. His ECG is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome

 

  • The ECG shows a short PR interval and a delta wave, which are characteristic findings of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, caused by an accessory pathway leading to pre-excitation of the ventricles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrial fibrillation: Atrial fibrillation is characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm and absence of distinct P waves.

 

Option B. Ventricular tachycardia: Ventricular tachycardia shows wide QRS complexes and a rapid heart rate, not the delta wave seen in WPW.

 

Option D. Long QT syndrome: Long QT syndrome presents with a prolonged QT interval, not the short PR interval and delta wave of WPW.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • WPW syndrome should be suspected in patients with a short PR interval and delta wave on the ECG.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
Assertion is independently true statement, but the Reason is independently false statement
Assertion is independently false statement, but the Reason is independently true statement

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Floaters are common in young myopes.

 

Reason (B): With increasing age, vitreous gel liquefies.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Both Assertion and Reason are independently true statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion

 

Assertion (A): Floaters are indeed more common in young individuals with myopia (short-sightedness). This is because myopic eyes are usually longer, which can cause more tension on the vitreous, leading to early degenerative changes.

 

Reason (B): It is true that with increasing age, the vitreous gel inside the eye tends to liquefy — a process known as syneresis. However, this reason does not directly explain why myopes, particularly young ones, experience floaters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Both floaters being common in young myopes and the age-related liquefaction of the vitreous gel are true, but they are not causally connected in the way described.
  •  Understanding these independent processes is important for accurate clinical assessment and patient education about visual symptoms.

choices.text: Treponema pallidum
Haemophilus ducreyi

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with a history of multiple sexual encounters reports a painful non-indurated ulcer on the glans penis that has been present for the past 5 days. The ulcer features undermined, sloughing edges. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Haemophilus ducreyi

 

  • Haemophilus ducreyi is the causative agent of chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful, non-indurated ulcers on the genitals, which commonly have undermined and sloughed edges as described in the scenario.
  • The presentation aligns well with the ulcer characteristics typically seen in chancroid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes: Herpes simplex virus typically causes painful, clustered vesicles or ulcers. While herpes lesions are painful, they are usually not described with undermined, sloughing margins.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Chlamydia infections primarily cause urethritis and cervicitis, not ulcers on the genitalia. It's unlikely to be the cause of a genital ulcer as described.

 

Option C. Treponema pallidum: This bacterium causes syphilis, which typically presents with a single, painless, firm, and round ulcer known as a chancre. The pain and characteristics of the ulcer in the question do not match those of syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which is characterized by painful, non-indurated ulcers with undermined, sloughing margins on the genitals.

questions.text: A physician is considering the prescription of a stool softener for a patient who has concerns about fat malabsorption issues. Which of the following stool softeners does not interfere with fat absorption?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Docusates

 

  • Docusates, such as docusate sodium, are stool softeners that work by increasing water absorption into the stool, making it softer and easier to pass without interfering with the absorption of nutrients, including fats, from the gut.
  • This makes docusates an ideal choice for patients who are concerned about fat malabsorption or are at risk of nutrient depletion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phenolphthalein: Incorrect, although not directly interfering with fat absorption. It is not a stool softener, it is a stimulant purgative. 

 

Option C. Liquid paraffin: Incorrect, liquid paraffin can impair the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K) as it coats the bowel and can interfere with the absorption of various substances, including fats.

 

Option D. Castor oil: Incorrect, castor oil acts as a stimulant laxative by irritating the intestinal lining to increase bowel movements, and while not specifically blocking fat absorption, its aggressive mode of action can affect overall nutrient uptake and digestion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Phenolphthalein and castor oil are stimulant purgatives whereas docussates (DOSS) and liquid paraffin are stool softeners.
  •  Liquid paraffin may cause deficiency of fat soluble vitamins.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with urinary incontinence and recurrent urinary tract infections. Imaging studies reveal a vesicovaginal fistula. The decision is made to manage the fistula conservatively. In which of the following scenarios does spontaneous healing of the fistula most likely occur?
questions.solution:
Ans: C) The fistula is small, 2 to 3 mm.

 

  • Spontaneous healing of a genitourinary fistula through continuous bladder drainage with an indwelling urinary catheter is more likely when the fistula is small, typically measuring 2 to 3 mm.
  • Small fistulas have a greater potential for closure with conservative management because continuous drainage keeps the affected area dry and allows the tissues to heal naturally without further irritation or infection. The smaller size of the fistula facilitates the natural healing process, increasing the likelihood of successful closure.

 

Other options

 

Option A. The fistula is related to pelvic radiation: Fistulas related to pelvic radiation are less likely to heal spontaneously because radiation can cause extensive tissue damage and fibrosis, which impairs the natural healing process. The compromised tissue integrity in irradiated areas makes spontaneous closure of the fistula less feasible.

 

Option B. The catheter is left in place for a minimum of 8 weeks: While prolonged bladder drainage can support healing, leaving the catheter in place for a specified duration does not guarantee spontaneous healing, especially if the fistula is large or if other complicating factors are present. The duration of catheter placement alone is not the primary determinant of spontaneous healing.

 

Option D. The fistula is large, greater than 2 cm: Large fistulas, greater than 2 cm, are less likely to heal spontaneously with conservative measures such as continuous bladder drainage. The larger the fistula, the more difficult it is for the tissues to approximate and close naturally, often necessitating surgical intervention.

 

Educational objective:

  • Spontaneous healing of a genitourinary fistula is more likely when the fistula is small, typically 2 to 3 mm, as continuous bladder drainage with an indwelling catheter can facilitate the natural healing process.
